description:
My boyfriend brought me here as a surprise for my birthday. It was an amazing and delicious experience. From the moment we entered and was greeted by the host you knew you were in a very classy establishment. 

Definitely choose to sit at the bar facing the chefs if you can. That way you can chat with the chefs and learn way more stuff about the food you are eating and all the effort it takes to procure quality ingredients. 

We had the $200 course and tbh if I was to ever go again, I would probably just pick the $150. The additional stuff you get I'm not sure I would have missed, save maybe the additional toro sashimi which was really good but the fried shrimp head and the wagyu beef sushi I could have passed on. I was so stuffed by the time we left I could barely finish my dessert which was amazing too. I felt bad leaving any of the food behind. 

By far the stand out dish was the uni on rice with roe and gold flakes? I dont even know what it was called but it was amazing. The most decadent dish i have had ever maybe. 

Highly recommend for an occasion. The waiters and host were all very polite and friendly. Our chef was the owner and he was extremely entertaining and great to talk to learning about all the ingredients and sharing his experiences.
author: Chung H.

description:
Whoa, what a treat. The bff and I have been trying to schedule an omakase experience at Omakase for some time, and I'm so glad we were finally able to coordinate for a special occasion! From beginning to end, the level of service provided was superb. 

But let's back track for a min. As soon as we sat down, I mentioned to the bud that I recognized our sushi chef, Chef Jason. I just couldn't pin point where I'd seen him though bc this was the first visit to Omakase. Well, turns out I'm not crazy and he'd recently come over from Sushi Hon, which was the last spot the bff and I went to grab omakase together! And the experience with Chef Jason at Sushi Hon was superb as well. Sushi Hon's loss is most definitely Omakase's gain!

Personalized, hand-written cards were ready for us before we even sat down. A lovely touch tbh. And the card was followed by a small glass of birthday sake. Color me impressed. Chef Jason took us through a journey, explaining each piece of fish's origin, the texture, the flavor profile, and his personal touches. Since he's only moved over to Omakase a month ago, he's slowly integrating some of his trainings from NYC (gave me some awesome recos to check out the next time I'm there!) into the existing menu. 

Our party opted for the $150 option, but it looked like everyone else went for the $200 (additional sashimi and an extra wagyu dish). We usually like to go thru the slightly cheaper option and choose a few pieces we either want to try again or try that we haven't had yet. Chef Jason ended up choosing for us the amaebi (sweet shrimp) and seared toro (fatty tuna) nigiri pieces. Both of which were amazingly fresh (perfect crunch on the shrimp and buttery goodness on the tuna). 

BUT I will say that the smaller sashimi platter we got vs the slightly more expensive menu was a bit of a let down. We only got two types of sashimi - red tuna (good, but nothing special) and smoked white fish (was not particularly a fan of the smoked flavor). In retrospect, we should've gone with the slightly more expensive option. The other patrons got amaebi sashimi (which we wouldn't have had to order), toro sashimi (which, again, we wouldn't have had to order - but ours was seared and AMAZING), and some sort of a whelk sashimi (which looked pretty freaking good). 

Throughout the meal, the wait staff was both informative and attentive. The manager also happened to be a high school classmate of ours - shout out to Gary for the wonderful service! As if we weren't impressed by the entire experience already, the staff ended the meal with a personalized dessert candle and a single rose (per person!) as a parting special occasion gift. And a chocolate truffle for the road. 

Was it pricey? Yes. About $200+pp. But was it worth it for the occasion? Abso-freaking-lutely! We were handed business cards to check out their other sister restaurant locations. Can't wait to come back or try out other locations. 

Top-notch 5 star experience!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Overrated price and disturbing  environment.

With $200, you would expect to have the best quality of sushi and nigiri. Instead, the sushi rice didn't hold together and fell apart when using a chopstick to pick. This is like the basic technique of making sushi. The chef saw the fallen rice and stared at me like I've done something wrong. He then said I NEED to use my fingers instead of chopsticks, which doesn't make sense. I've been to other places like Kusakabe and Sushi Ran.. I've never had this problem before. The quality of fish is okay but not as favorable as the other two places.
Disturbing environment - based on yelp, the atmosphere of this place should be intimate upscale, which offers diners an elegant atmosphere with high-quality service. Not sure what happened the entire night. We felt like we were in a low class night club with uneducated drunk people yelling with guffawed noise. The chef invites the atmosphere instead of considering the other guests' comfort zone. On the other hand, while the waiter is very friendly, I suggest him not to get too close when talking to the guests. I could smell the breath coming out from his mouth that was quite unpleasant.

Definitely won't go back.
author: Steph B.

description:
Omakase makes it to my list of the few Michelin-starred restaurants I would go back to. I managed to snag a late reservation for my fiancee's birthday, so we weren't able to sit by the sushi bar. Nevertheless, I don't think it detracted from the wonderful experience. They personalized the table a with a birthday message and a rose. Omakase definitely earns its name; this is one of my favorite omakase places in the States.

We decided to go with the larger omakase, costing only $50 extra. I was surprised that I was pretty full by the end of the course. All 12 nigiri pieces were fresh. I really enjoyed this small bowl of ikura and uni - a simple, flavorful combination. The sashimi was served in an impressive bowl of ice.
author: James N.

description:
I didn't know good restaurants until I met my girlfriend and her family.  They will spend years (!) talking about restaurants they want to try, and the amazing food they've had in the past.  I promised them a spectacular meal at a nice restaurant when I had the means to treat, which means I searched far and wide to meet their high expectations.  I knew it was going to be a difficult task.  

Omakase sure delivered!  It blew us away.  Side note: I'm super picky about sashimi, and most of the time I won't even eat it but my Japanese girlfriend would eat it every day if she could.  I knew the place had to be upscale and fresh if I was going to try it, and man, it was good!  The menu is, obviously, all "omakase style", which means the menu changes almost daily to accommodate the freshest ingredients. There's 2 menu choices; Hideaki ($150), includes less sashimi and 10 pieces of nigiri, and Yamato ($200) which includes more sashimi, 12 pieces of nigiri and A5 Wagu beef.  My girlfriend opted for the Hideaki because she doesn't eat red meat, and the rest of us got the Yamato.  Her mom got the sake sampler with her meal for an additional $80, more on that later.

I'm not going to go into each and every fish we had, because honestly, I couldn't tell you the names and it changes almost every day anyway.  However, the names of the fish, etc didn't matter, because no matter what I put in my mouth that night, the flavors were beyond memorable.  Hands down, the freshest, tastiest fish I've ever had, sashimi at that, melt in your mouth, leave you wanting more....the BEST.  And, yes, I don't normally like sashimi, but I loved this.  My sushi/sashimi connoisseur family had the same sentiments, and they've eaten at upscale restaurants in Japan.  Don't come here looking for the typical sashimi (sake, hamachi, maguro), because this is top notch in quality and freshness.

My girlfriend's mom was for sure drunk after her sake sampler, so be prepared for this.  We took little sips, and the sake was like nothing I've ever tasted.  Smooth and flavorful.  It was a good thing all 3 of us didn't order this, or we'd be abandoning the car and catching a ride home.  The sake just adds to the overall experience, but they give you a lot.

The best things about the restaurant:
- The service is top notch.  We ate at the sushi bar and I loved the way they served us each, carefully handcrafted before our eyes, piece of nigiri. Make sure to get a seat at the sushi bar, you're seriously missing out on a huge piece of the experience if you sit at the tables.
- There's no need to add wasabi or soy sauce to any of the nigiri.  It's pre-added so that one bite has everything you could ever want. 
- The sushi chefs.  They are so knowledgeable about the fish (and other ingredients) and they understand the flavors to the T.

Of course I'll be back, everything about this restaurant, including the price, was worth it!
author: Ashley S.

description:
Omakase is a gem. The food is great, but the service was the cherry-on-top of a great night. Literally the best service I have ever experienced. It's much better than other fine dining restaurants i've tried. 

Me and my girlfriends ordered the Yamato ($200) and a bottle of sake. Our bill with tip came out to $300 per person. Pricey- but you get what you pay for. The quality is over the top amazing! Shout out to Chef Jackson, Chef Tora, Gary & Kiki because they made our entire experience so memorable. From the moment we walked in, they took care of us with such detail and genuine kindness. 

We were lucky to get reservations less than a week in advance. The restaurant is pretty small and intimate. It would be great for a date night, though I don't recommend for groups larger than 4. We had 4 girls and that was already pretty tight. 

Overall, I absolutely loved it here. I would 100% recommend this restaurant to others.
author: Katherine N.

description:
Wow! On a recent trip to San Francisco I was looking for a top-notch sushi restaurant and found an open reservation for Omakase. It's Michelin rated so I knew it would be good but I was blown away. Everything about the experience was amazing! The service was also spectacular. 

Watching the chefs prepare the food was really cool. Each bite was prepared carefully and chef/owner Jackson Yu explained what every dish was as well as his recommended way of eating it. I came alone but the chef made sure to engage everyone and make sure we were having a good time. We ended up sharing sake with the chef by the end of the evening. Such a fun time! And everything I ate was delicious! So many new flavors! I thought I hated uni but Omakase's uni was so good! 

I've posted a few pics of my favorite dishes. Definitely check this place out!
author: Priscilla D.

description:
I had a worse omasaka experience at Omasake. 

A typical omasaka provides a peaceful dinning environment where you enjoy the foods and learn where the origin and history of the fish prepared. 

This was not the experience I had at Omasake. 

Chief Jackson and Jason were entertaining clients like it is at a local pub or your corner Japanese Restaurant.  The chiefs continued to convince the clients to drink lots of sake  to the point one of them talked so loud and the rest could not continue the omakasa experience any further.

Typical Japanese chief would respect the dinning experiences of other customers.  Chief Jackson and Jason who came from mainland China offer different style. 

If you love loud and non stop sake drinking like your typical corner Japanese Resturant plus overate price, this is your place!
author: Cola C.

description:
We did a last minute cancellation at a different restaurant and booked this place with no trouble (about three weeks before reservation date). We didn't get a spot at the sushi bar though. The restaurant only seats 10 at the sushi bar and two 2-seaters near the window. We were the first to arrive at the 5:30 dinner. Almost every pair of seats was a little stand with a card. Our own card said "Happy Anniversary" with all the chefs signatures and a little doodle by them, which I thought is super sweet and adorable. The dining area is pretty small so we could watch the chefs making sushi from our table. Food was outstanding. They had a unique platter to serve their sushi on. I also enjoyed the way they served their soup in a cup with a spout; drink it like sake. I also received a rose at the end of the meal. A memorable experience. Will definitely come again. 

Service - 5 / Ambiance - 5 / Food - 5 / Price - 4
author: Veronica N.

description:
My first upscale omakase meal and I really enjoyed it! Came here for a friend's birthday as she loves sushi and the three of us had a great time. It wasn't just the food (which was delicious) but also our sushi chef Taka-san who made it such a memorable experience :)

There are two seatings per day, one around 5:30 and one around 8-8:30 (they're flexible with your arrival time). We made reservations for 5:30 and were one of the first patrons to arrive. It's a very small and intimate restaurant; there were maybe 12 seats at the sushi bar and another two tables off to the side. It gets booked out so make sure you make your reservation early, especially for the weekend!

There are two set menus to choose from: the Hideaki ($150) and the Yamato ($200). The main difference between the two is that with the Yamato you get more sashimi and also A5 wagyu. I opted for the Hideaki while both my friends got the Yamato, so it's nice that not everyone in your group has to order the same thing.

This is what we had:
-Complimentary sake 
-Amuse bouche of hotaru ika (firefly squid) with mountain yam
-Eggplant with anchovies and salad
-Sashimi: lean tuna and amberjack (Yamato comes with pen shell scallop, chutoro, and surf clam as well)
-Nigiri: karei (Japanese flounder), aji (horse mackerel), ainame (grilled ling), shima aji (striped mackerel), sakura masu (cherry trout)
~Nigiri break: chawanmushi with Hokkaido uni~
-Nigiri: kinmedai (golden eye snapper), katsuo (bonito), saba (mackerel) with seasoned sea kelp, ootoro
-Uni with ikura
-Tamago
-Yamato set: A5 wagyu from Yamazaki prefecture with truffle and pickled onion
-Asari akadashi (red miso soup with clam)
-Dessert: Panna cotta with mango slice

Everything was pretty solid, but the ootoro really sticks out in my mind as the best thing I ate from this meal, unsurprisingly. It was incredibly rich and fatty, and even though there was a giant lump of wasabi on it, I could barely taste it! The tamago was really interesting as well, as it looked and tasted more like cake but Taka-san swore that there was no flour in it. Very curious.

We all got a "present" of a chocolate truffle to take away. Since it was my friend's birthday, they also wrote her a happy birthday card with some adorable pictures and gave her birthday roses. How sweet!

Service was impeccable, as you might imagine from a place like this. They offered to check in my friend's jacket for her, and the moment they noticed I had a small purse on me, they offered a box to put it in. No detail is too small for them to pay attention to. My birthday friend is left handed, so Taka-san placed her nigiri sushi in the opposite direction on the plate so that she could pick it up easier. It happened so seamlessly that my friend didn't even notice until I pointed it out to her!
author: Dianna H.

description:
Tucked away at the bottom of a residential complex in the design district, Omakase didn't have any large signs (other than the name on top of the awning which we couldn't see when we were walking by storefront). The interior is small and aside from two small tables, everyone else is seated at the sushi bar. We were greeted so politely and the attentive service was shown every minute during our 2 hour time slot there. 

We ordered the Yamato Omakase menu which consisted of a complimentary sake taste, appetizers, sashimi, nigiri, soup, Wagyu beef and dessert. This does not include the green tea and water that were billed separately. You can also order a la carte, though our multi course meal was filling as-is. 

Our chefs and hosts were very detailed in making sure we knew exactly what we were eating. They also made sure to time each next course accordingly! Some of my favorite and most memorable dishes were the otoro sashimi, sea bream nigiri, wagyu beef, tamago, and panna cotta. 

From the food to the service, you'll definitely get a good quality experience here at Omakase.
author: Lillian B.

description:
Best Meal Ever. Finally managed to get a spot at this place and man... It was worth the wait and every single penny. The omakase was one of the best I've ever had (and yes, it's even better than a lot of the ones that I tried out in Japan). Everything that came out was delicious. I'm super picky about what types of fish I like/will eat, but I even ate the ones I normally don't like - and they were amazing. The fish was super fresh and it just melted in your mouth. My only regret was not getting some of the add ons and just going for the slightly pricier omakase option. 

My favorite items of the night were definitely the uni with roe, the hamachi, and the monk fish liver. Normally I hate roe because of how fishy it is, but the roe here was marinated so it was sweet and refreshing. It paired perfectly with the giant scoop of uni. Hamachi is my personal favorite fish and so having being served a piece so fresh and so soft, I just couldn't say no. It literally melted in my mouth. The monk fish liver was also marinated and paired perfectly with its accompaniments. 

I'll definitely be back here again to try the other omakase option!

Cons: 
- Will set you back a paycheck or two... but worth!
- Not a lot of seats, so it can take up to a few months to get a seating

Pros: 
- Everything that was served was well thought out and tasted amazing
- Fish was super fresh and melted in your mouth
- Service was impeccable 
- Fun to watch the chefs make your food right in front of you
author: Diana C.

description:
Pricey but worth it for the experience! I was a little hesitant to drop $150 on a meal. The delicate pieces of fish from Japan you won't be able to experience anywhere else in the Bay Area. As a food lover and a sushi/sashimi fanatic, the fish far exceeded my expectations.

Two meal options:
- Hideaki Omakase: $150
- Yamato Omakase: $200

Restaurant:
- Quiet and traditional Japanese ambiance
- Very small! The entire restaurant is extremely small! It holds a sushi bar and a total of 2 tables for parties of 2.

Service is on another level with attention to the smallest details. For example, they pay attention to placing dishes or nigiri pieces in different positions depending on which hand is dominant (I'm a lefty!).

Each piece of nigiri was spot on and would melt right inside my mouth! I was especially surprised about how much I enjoyed the Hokkaido Uni. I wouldn't say I ever gravitated towards Uni but this Uni has changed my appreciation for Uni.

If you think this place is pricey for a meal, it is! But it's always important to remember to treat yo self once in awhile. Am I right or am I right? (:
author: Salena H.

description: Tried once, definitely would not return again. Way overpriced for what it is. Could go to other omakase places for half the price and just as good. 4 stars if price not involved, 3 if price is considered. The drawing and rose at the end if great extra touch though. The dessert was the best item. A few fishes were really tasty. Rest were so so.
author: Hai Y.

description:
Perhaps we didn't have the best luck, but while the sushi was good, service could have been better.  Came here for an anniversary on a Friday night with an 8pm reservation.

Venue: very chic with black wood accents and dim lighting (but not so dim that you need flashlights to look at the menu).  It is almost all counter seats, with the exception of one table that seats 2 people.  

Food: we had the Hideaki Omakase ($150 / person), which includes 2 appetizers, one sashimi, 10 piece nigiri, and one owan.  I'd say this was a decent size for a moderately hungry individual; we were full by the end.  Overall, the fish was fresh and the dishes were pretty well balanced.  You got what you paid for.

Service: the waiters were pretty good at clearing plates and filling waters.  They also were nice enough to have a card and rose for us in honor of our anniversary.  Not sure if this is normal, but only one of the chefs was there when we were there and he was doing all omakese.  I didn't mind this, if it weren't for the fact that it seemed as if his close friends were sitting next to us and we were starting to feel a bit... neglected.  Hard to ask him about dishes we were eating, especially when he was constantly taking shots with his friends as the night wore on (he was a decent shade of pink by the time we finished).  Totally fine with the chef chatting up with friends, though I felt it was somewhat unprofessional watching him take so many shots of sake and pretty much only talk with them- most chefs at other sushi places I've been to had accept a sake glass and wet their lips / sip it over a long period of time and seem to have a better handling of multiple guests.  Dunno if this ought to be a major complaint, but it sort of brought down our meal, especially for a Michelin starred restaurant. 

Who knows, maybe this was a one time fluke... but I'm more inclined to go to other sushi spots.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Everything from the the intimate seating to the preparation of the fish was incredible! I came here for Mothers Day with parents and sister, and had forgotten to tell the restaurant we were celebrating an occasion. They graciously procured a signed card and bouquet of flowers for my mom out of thin air! I really appreciated this kind gesture - service and decor is definitely a 5/5 here.

[Hideaki Omakase] 
The Omakase served at Omakase is on the traditional side. My family ordered the Yamoto Omakase - I definitely think this one is worth more than the basic Hideaki Omakase. The sashimi plate (where you can only get on the Yamoto) was beautiful and had amazing slices of o-toro and a selection of other fresh fish and shellfish. I did not like the wagyu as much. The piece was extremely small and did not have great texture. The pieces were pretty standard - but if you order the yamoto you do get the extra o-toro (if you can't tell this is my favorite fish). 

[Service]
Our sushi chef was extremely personable and gave us deep explanations on the origins of wasabi and the difference between Japanese ginger and American ginger. The meal was extremely filling as well as informative - I will definitely be coming back to this establishment for a reliable meal on a special occasion!
author: Alice Z.

description: Came for my boyfriends birthday - loved the intimacy of the place since there are only a few seats at the sushi counter. Each chef serves 4 people. We went with the more expensive omakase which definitely didn't disappoint! They started off with some complimentary sake which was cold and light. I usually don't like sake but this was sweet enough that I didn't mind! We had a very interesting assortment of sushi that were very fresh. The waiters were also super knowledgeable and friendly and made the whole experience wonderful!
author: Jen L.

description:
Omakase has been high on my must-try of great omakase restaurants in San Francisco and it did not disappoint! It did have some differences from the other omakase greats (Kusakabe, Ju-Ni) but I enjoyed some of the more unique fishes I got to try here.

The basic way the menu works is you can opt for the $150 or $200 omakase set meals. The $200 version has everything the $150 has with a few additional courses (worth it). What I really loved it they actually have $50 supplements that can be shared with the group and are more unique. On the Friday night we went they had 1. Dragonfish, 2. Uni, 3. Kobe beef ($50 per oz). We chose the Dragonfish and it was amazing!! First of all I never even knew a Dragonfish existed and it really and truly looked like a mini dragon (see picture). Like the dragon sizes of the remaining dragons in Game of Thrones when the dragons were starting to die out!! 

They prepared it three ways: 
1. Sashimi (seared) - it tasted very fatty because they live in Hokkaido where the water is very cold
2. Fried skin - basically a seafood chicharrone! 
3. Soup - very flavorful and perfect way to end of the meal. 

If the Dragonfish is available I highly recommend it! It's very unique and not something you can find just anywhere. 

The rest of the meal was very delicious with good quality fish. I have to say I did not enjoy the selection of nigiri fishes as much as I've enjoyed the fishes selected at other omakase restaurants but I will admit that they are very unique. There are several such as cherry trout and buri that I have never heard of before. I tried my best to take notes...we tried:
1. Golden eye snapper
2. Shima aji
3. Aji
4. Stone snapper
5. Gizzard shad
6. Cherry trout
7. Buri
8. Hokke (green ling)
9. Uni
10. A5 wagyu

The sushi chefs were very friendly, the rest of the diners festive and the servers very professional and good at making sure your sake glass is never empty. All in all a great experience!
author: Christina L.

description:
After my visit to Omakase, I can see why they received another michelin star. $HIT WAS LITTTTTTT.

As the restaurant name suggests, this is an omakase only establishment. If you don't know what that is, then I suggest you go elsewhere for your stupid rainbow and caterpillar rolls.

My friends and I opted in for the Yamato Omakase for $200 (excluding drinks, tax, and tip) which included two appetizers, two sashimi, one yakimono, two pieces of nigiri, and one owan.

Omakase has been high on my must-try of great omakase restaurants in San Francisco and it did not disappoint! It did have some differences from the other omakase greats (Kusakabe, Ju-Ni) but I enjoyed some of the more unique fishes I got to try here.

S/O to Chef Taka for being a dope and funny chef. Omakase, take all of my money. I'll be back soon!
author: Danny L.

description: I was highly recommended to try this place and it was everything I expected. Delicious food, beautiful presentation, very attentive staff and yummy Champagne! Thank you Chef Jackson for a fun night to remember!
author: Ceci B.

description:
3.5/5
It's hard to give a non 5 star rating to such a high end place especially when it has a Michelin star cause you're basically guaranteed to get a good meal. And we did. The meal was good with some great moments. But there were also some mediocre points and quite a few that were just average and when you combine that with a $270 (w/ tax & tip) price tag, I can't say that it's a place worth seeking out a second time.

Came here with a friend on a Sunday night because it was one of the few higher end sushi restaurants that still had spots open with a week's notice. We were seated at a table and service was great. I would've really liked to speak to the chefs but the waitresses were all very attentive. Our cups were never empty and they didn't mind my incessant note-taking and photographing. We decided to get the $200 Yamato option. Between this and the Hideaki for $150 I would say go for the $200 because my favorite dishes were the extras that weren't included in the $150 meal.

Courses were as followed: *GBS = Good but standard cause Yelp is basically my food diary but w/ a character limit.
1) Ankimo w/ yamaimo: Texturally great. Mountain yam's creamy crunch worked well. Ankimo was good but I've had better fluffier ones at other similarly priced spots. (3.75/5)
2) Eggplant w/ microgreens + baby anchovies: The anchovies broke up the creamy eggplant very well. It was almost like extra mini crunches. Otherwise I found the dish a bit bland but also a bit salty at the same time. The microgreens didn't work well for me (3/5)
2.5) Sake: A very nice freebie to "open our appetites". Light, sweet, very distinct fermented rice aroma.
3) Sashimi plate w/ smoke kanpachi, smoked amberjack, bluefin akami: The smoking on the kanpachi/amberjack were nice and not overpowering. Texture/fat wise GBS. The bluefin akami was GBS. (3.5/5)
4) Uni Chawanmushi: Well made. But also something I've had at a lot of spots for cheaper and done just as well. Was hoping for something a bit more inventive. That being said it's light-bodied w/ a very umami-filled stock. (4.25/5)
5) Deluxe Sashimi Plate: 1st stand out item of the night. Presentation was gorgeous (it's served in a pencil scallop shell) (4.75/5)
-Aoyagi: Best aoyagi I've had. They serve the meat +muscle. Very sweet and there's a chew but not in a rubbery way. Parts of it were like a firm scallop.
-Chutoro: GBS
-Pencil Scallop: A 1st and loved it. Had a konjac-like firmness without the extra kickback bite. 
6) Tsukemono w/ deep fried fish: My friend really enjoyed this but it wasn't for me. The fish was a bit dry and while I love the taste of carbs soaked in sweet vinegar, I didn't love the texture. I did enjoy the cucumber and wished there was more. (2/5)
7) Nigiri: Rice amount was small (not a bad thing) but proportionately it didn't always work. Rice taste/texture was meh. I found the kernels a bit too separated and I wish it was a bit more compact. Flavor-wise I prefer it stronger too. For the fish, quality was good but not the best I've had and for the most part not much was done to make anything stand out.
-Ika: Whatever they added really made it special though the ika itself was GBS. (4.25/5)
-Aji/Horse Mackerel: GBS (4/5)
-Greenling: A 1st. Reminded me of halibut. Very clean & soft but w/ a pop at the end & w/ more depth in the flavor. (4/5)
-Ishidai: Another 1st for me. My friend and I both found it funky. I felt like it was smoked or at least in the proximity of some very aromatic wood. The funk lingered (3/5)
-Cherry Salmon: A high point. Like chewing a cross between light jello + meat. Perfect amount of salt (5/5)
-King Mackerel: GBS (4/5)
-Kinmedai: One of my faves at most places. Wish it was torched more. GBS. (4/5)
-Shima Aji: Bit of citrus. Firm and fatty. (4.5/5)
-Hagashi Toro (no connective tissue): SO tender & fatty. High point (7/5)
-Uni w/ ikura: Quality uni. In the mid ground of the sweet/buttery scale. Ikura had a nice sweet marinade. (4/5)
8) A5 Wagyu w/ pickled onion, truffle, freeze dried fat over potato: Pickle wasn't too strong but brought just enough acidity to lift the fattiness. Freeze dried fat was like magic flavor powder. Truffle was magic part 2. Potato helped balance it out though almost wish there was a bit less of it.
9) Red miso w/ clams & tofu: GBS, a bit salty
10) Tamago w/ lobster: Another high point. Like a sponge cake but w/ lobster flavor swimming around your nostrils. (4.75/5)
11) Panna cotta w/ yuzu granita: 2nd main thing that made me go WOW. Base was creamy and dense w/ a salty kick that works so well w/ the granita. (6/5)
12) Matcha chocolate ganache: Gift for home. Ganache was good but exterior didn't have the chocolate snap. Still made me smile tho.

TLDR: It's good/HQ stuff and I enjoyed it but overall nothing too special given their reputation & price point.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Ordered Yamato Omakase $200 per person + Sake Pairing $80 per person, we felt really disappointed by the lack of quantity (not according to what was written on the fix price menu) and quality of the food. Sake choice is excellent, by the way.
The menu shows there are 8 different kind of dish, including 10 pcs Nigiri. 
We did not realize until we went home and looked at all the picture we took, the nigiri was served only 7 pcs total.
Now we really hope when the food was served, the server could also point us the item on the fix price menu, to tell us what actually they are and whether we get all items listed on the fix price menu.
A lot of the selection are really ordinary, including the clam miso soup, squid, and some of the sashimi. The wagyu beef and the veggie dish are not that impressive either.
At the end we were given small chocolate and a stem of rose which is nice.
However, we still feel one or two items of the dish were missing.
author: Irene X.

description: This is my favorite sushi place in the Bay Area. Jason was my chef during my last visit. His creativities and skills were totally mind-blowing. I enjoyed every dish I had. 5-star review, Good job!
author: Steven X.

description:
This place is truly deserving of its name. I had the premium omakase here and really enjoyed it.  All of the fish tastes extra fresh and at the highest grade.  They offer two omakase menus and I always get the premium one. The meal included:

(1). Appetizer was ankimo
(2).  Elevated eggplant dish
(3).  First sashimi dish included kampachi and lean toro
(4).  Hokkaido uni chawanmushi (real standout)
(5).  Premium sashimi including toro, clam and scallop
(6).  Cooked dish (delicious Japanese white fish)
(7).  10 pieces of nigiri which included rare pieces not common in the US - the standouts were the fluke with Osetra caviar, the kinmedai, the barracuda and the fatty toro
(8). Premium A5 wagyu nigiri with liberty duck breast
(9).  Tamago
(10).  Red miso with clams
(11).  Poached pear and orange as the perfect dessert. 

This restaurant is very traditional - they encourage you to use your fingers when eating nigiri. Service is attentive but not fussy. Chef Tora was a great host and chef and educated the diners on the different types of Japanese fish. 

The standouts for me were the uni chawanmushi and the uni/ikura bowl. The two extra supplemental dishes are definitely worth it. This is pricey for sure but worth the special trip for the special occasion.  Highly recommended.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Yes, this is your fancy, top-dollar sushi restaurant. The name Omakase already defines what to expect with re: to food -- it's a chef's choice sushi course. When my husband and I went, there were 2 options to chose from. Yes, the sushi was very good. Not the best I've ever had, but very good. And yes, it was very expensive. Maybe the most expensive my husband and I have ever had. I just wanted to set all those expectations ahead of time to weed out the readers used to your sushi buffets and bento box Japanese restaurants. 

Instead of going into the sushi itself, here are my notes about the extras and details from out experience:
- They call you ahead of time to ask if you're celebrating anything special so they can prepare a personalized card from the chefs to you. 
- Ladies get a nice wooden box to place their purse in on the floor. 
- If you're thinking about ordering a bottle of sake, go for the sake pairing instead. The cheaper bottles are around the price of the sake pairing. The pairings really go well with the courses and if you're looking at volume, you do get a good amount. 
- This probably changes with the seasons, but we didn't have any shellfish. Which I appreciate! I don't really care for shrimp or scallops, etc. 
- But the Hokkaido uni... !!! And I hate uni! But this was amazing!
author: Andrea L.

description:
There is no better omakase that I've tried in the bay area that surpasses Omakase SF in quality that hasn't been said in previous reviews.  What makes dining here a truly memorable experience is the atmosphere and service.  We did the more expensive Yamato ($200) with no drink pairings.  

I must commend Chef Takashi Song, who was serving us that night. The timing between courses was perfect (raise your hand if you've waited TOO long between each course before). Its like he has a spidey sense that tells him exactly when you're ready. He is very courteous and also possibly the nicest guy chef I've met.  While he is very serious most of the time, he will surprise you with a bit of genuine humor that's not offensive or improper (look at the photo I posted). Chef Takashi Song loves his job and it shows.  There's a small box with a truffle given to you at the end.  I jokingly asked if he could secretly put uni in there.  He smiles and points to the ceiling....I turn over and see a camera haha!  

Most importantly, it is kid friendly! Your family will be welcomed here.  You may be judged by others for bringing your kids to eat something they cant fully appreciate, but to be honest...I just thought they were the most awesome parents ever. Chef Jackson Yu even cut the younger daughter one of the longest slices of tamago I have ever seen, which made her SO happy while she ate it like a loaf of bread, not paying much attention to the more expensive uni, toro, or wagyu in front of her :) It was a pleasant change from the usually more formal omakase setting.  

Omakase SF's chefs, staff, and atmosphere was absolutely perfect in every way.  I mean, you kind of have to be pretty good and confident if the name of your restaurant is "Omakase"
author: Hua K.

description:
My visit to Omakase was pretty life changing. 

Remember that one review where I listed my top three omakases in the city? Yeah.. that has changed. 

Remember that other one review where I said I just had the most expensive meal of my life? Yeah.. that has changed too. 

My monthly omakase buddy Jennifer K. and I wanted to end our 2017 omakase shenanigans with a bang. We were pretty set on the Hideaki Omakase ($150) and planned on ordering a la carte afterwards, but once we saw the tokusen sashimi that came with the Yamato Omakase ($200), say no more fam - we knew it was game over. It was the most glorious sashimi display I've ever laid my eyes on, so of course we had to get it. 

From beginning to end, there was nothing I disliked. We started with some appetizers (ankimo was my favorite) and sashimi (pics speak for itself) before getting to the nigiri. My absolute favorite piece of the night was the flounder topped with liver - such a flavorful, savory bite. Toro was obviously melt in your mouth status. I don't eat meat so my wagyu substitute was artic char which was just as amazing as the seared toro it was paired with (extra two nigiris that come with the Yamato). Ikura was probably the best I've ever had, so perfectly marinated. I did not care too much for the poached pears, but could have eaten ten of those lobster egg nigiris for dessert. 

Worth every penny.
author: Laverne N.

description:
I am sad to report that Omakase was a disappointment for me. I had heard so much about it and was excited to try it out initially. I have now been to many of the omakase places in San Francisco, including all of the Michelin star ones and Omakase was by far the most disappointing. First, Omakase was one of the most expensive restaurants on the list -- costing more than Wako and Ju-Ni at the time. Second, their fish quality did not seem to be at the same level as Wako and Ju-No. Third, and the most disappointing of all, I felt like since their fish quality was not as high as their counter parts, they relied heavily on marinades and gimmicks in order to seem "high end." Think truffle infused EVERYTHING. If I wanted every fish doused in sauces I could have just gotten a roll and my neighbor sketchy sushi joint. For such a premium I definitely expect better.

I would never choose to return to Omakase when there are so many better options out there in sf. Sadly, this was a pass for me.
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
Great omakase experience in SF. Food was super fresh and each course was full of different flavors. We got the Yamato omakase which included the a5 waygu beef and a little more stuff than the other option. We went in expecting not to get full from these fancy meals but halfway in, I was scared I wasn't going to be able to finish everything!

Staff was super attentive and it was awesome being able to watch the chefs prepare the food right in front of you. If you want a more intimate setting, I would request your own table but keep in mind that they only have 2 available. If you want a good view of the chefs, request the bar but it is more crowded as you are almost shoulder to shoulder to the person sitting next to you.

I would say the best thing about the meal was their nigiri since you can't really find those types of fish anywhere else. The rest was still super good, but didn't really stand out.

Make reservations as the restaurant only sits about 20!
author: Denise J.

description:
Here is the 3-1-1: 

Food: Two months after vacationing in Japan I finally got to try Omakase and the preparation and quality of all the dishes felt like I stepped back into Tokyo. Each dish from sashimi to dessert and everything in between was very similar to what the flavors are in Japan. Since it is a set menu there is minimal amount of flexibility however they will call and ask for dietary restrictions and allergies, so the meal is adjusted at the time you are dining.

Service: There are 2 seating's and when we arrived for the 1st seating you are greeted in Japanese and you are brought to the counter and presented with the drink menu that has a great selection of higher end wines and sake. The staff is very attentive and when sitting at the counter you experience a very pleasing interaction with the sushi chef for your section. He describes each dish and provides insights on the origin and flavors to expect as well as suggest if your nigiri or sashimi needs the addition of shoyu or wasabi.

Ambiance: Once you are seated and the dining experience begins you have the feeling you are no longer in SF. The environment and the staff set the tone that you are now back in Japan and with every course and interactions between the chef and wait staff it is really does make for a memorable experience.
author: Irwan A.

description:
Classic elegant omakase-only restaurant. Chefs are japense and the ambiance is elegant and high end. They sport a Michelin Star for a reason. They offer two levels of omakase, and of course you should go with the premium. Épicurien. 

They have a very good sake menu and some champagnes and a beer. Service is outstanding. The maître d runs a tight ship and is formal while still personable. The waitresses are formally attired in traditional dress.  The bar is very clean wood and you can see all the fish and courses being prepared. Really ideal.  Reminds me of Kabuto in Las Vegas in terms of sushi bar and quality of fish. Much are imported from Japan and the selections are premium and varied. They have a lot of oilier fish and crustaceans which is hard to find in an American market. The large Asian population in San Francisco allows for elevated sushi. 

They serve a complimentary taste of sake. I extended with a delicious, clean yet layered Akitabare suirakuten. 

- Amuse-boche - ankimo. They open in a big way
- Gomae with baby anchovies and nasu. Loved this 
- Sashimi course - kanpachi and akami. Wakame seaweed
- Uni chawanmushi - Hokkaido uni very delicate 
- Sashimi course deux (premium) - perio clam, toro, aoyagi clam
- Unagi with cucumber and wakame. Delicious. Grilled over hot coals in bamboo leaf 
- Inada nigiri - wonderful way to start. Delicious rice very light vinegary some body but still soft
- Knife jaw - more substantial, wonderful
- Aji - wonderful cut. Chef is an expert 
- Cherry trout from Hokkaido with fermented cherry leaf. Wow. The sophistication here is next level
- Sawara - Japanese mackerel. Wonderful grilled
- Hokkaido uni and ikura from Japan - premium course. Very good and elegantly served. My rote response is I miss the gunkan style 
- Baby sea bream - with caviar next level again
- Kinmadai - fan favorite these days. Chef added that these goldeneye snapper come from 600-feet below in the Pacific Ocean 
- Shima-aji - fattiest silver fish according to the chef. Excellent knife skills on display to give it even more character 
- O-toro - from Spain. Really perfect
- Kohada - I added this. Lovely if you like vinegary fish
- Saba - cured with komba. I added this too. All from Japan
- House-made tamago - so light and airy. Loved it. Just a touch sweet
- Waygu - was a bit cool for me. They may have grilled it too early
- Red miso soup with clam
- Dessert - vanilla crème panna cotta with yuzu sorbet mango sesame and edible flower

They brought my check out with the dessert which I found odd. Potentially they were trying to squeeze someone else in but still for such an elegant dinner it was a shame. 

Otherwise, the chef has outstanding knife skills and etiquette. He bantered with me quite a bit and even shared an old picture of a sushi chef with whom we're both acquainted.
author: David D.

description:
Experience my first upscale omakase at Omakase, and it exceeded my expectations.

Right when you walk in, the staff will kindly guide you to your table. Since this was for a special occassion, they had a sign to celebrate the occasion at your seat (highly recommend booking a bar seat). The chefs were all very friendly and will gladly interact with you throughout your dining experience.

The menu has two options -- a $150 and $200 option. You get about three additional sets with the latter option (sets vary depending on the day), but I highly recommend getting the full experience and paying $200 to get the most sets. They also offer a sake pairing, but I didn't opt for it.

The ambience is perfect for a date night. It took about two hours to get through the whole meal, but it'll fly by as you stay entertained watching the chefs artfully prepare your omakase experience.
author: Garry S.

description: Omakase was good but fell short of expectations. It feels like in SF if you want quality sushi you have to go high end but when you go high end you don't always get what you paid for. I haven't tried all the top sushi bars in SF yet but it'll be interesting to see how they compare with this one.
author: Pat K.

description: Best Omakase! Great atmosphere! Great service! Parking is a little tough around the area. Love Chef Jackson! He is very friendly and attentive.
author: Michelle L.

description:
For a long time, I tried to resist coming here because right when they opened, their price point immediately started on the higher side.  As prices at other places have increased, the $150 the base omakase now no longer seems as outrageous. The other option is $200/person.

We did the Hideaki Omakase and the sake pairing ($80/person). 

Aside from the sake tasting, they started us with a complimentary sake.

To start: 
1. Ika - steamed firefly squid 
2. Grilled Japanese eggplant with micro greens salad baby anchovies - if you like eggplant (which I do), this is a great dish

Sashimi course:
Blue fin tuna 
Cold smoked amberjack 
Grated fresh wasabi, wakame, radish

Sushi:
1. Kawahagi (file fish) with fish liver 
2. Kohada with a salt and vinegar cure: the cure helped take away some of the brininess 
3. Kamasu Japanese barracuda: torched (I loved anything with a torch)
4. Sawada (Japanese Spanish mackerel): with garlic and ginger - the garlic on this was great

Intermission:
Uni chawanmushi: super light and smooth 

Sushi continued:
5. Seasonal wild cherry trout 
6. Aji with lemon and chopped chives - I didn't realize aji and shima aji were different, but aji is horse mackerel 
7. Kinmedai: golden eye snapper - torched - really liked this
8. Shima aji: stripe jack - quite fatty in a good way
9. Otoro: buttery, smooth 
10. Uni and house cured ikura on rice: loved the ikura; I wish there were a little more rice for this, though - I really liked their shari

To finish:
1. Tamago with lobster: light and airy
2. Red miso with clams and tofu 

Dessert: 
Panna cotta with mango and strawberries, yuzu granita

To take home: 
Chocolate with tea flavor in a cute box

The fish was all very fresh. Overall, I would have preferred a little more seasoning on the fish (a little under salted/flavored for me).  On the other hand, the shari was great, and the quantity of food was just right.

Service was very polite and on point. The sushi chefs seemed to be enjoying what they were doing, and they had a good sense of humor - the more experienced chefs were jokingly giving the younger sushi chef a hard time. It's nice that it was a relaxed and less formal atmosphere.

From the sake pairing, my favorites were the Black Dragon and also the final one we had, which was lighter and had a hint of apple. I loved the various sake cups they give you.  That said, there's not as much sake as we expected, and it left me wanting more.  It was great to try different sakes, but I might just go for bottles next time. 

Reservations are on Open Table.

I like that most of the seating is at the sushi bar - there are 2 small tables on the side for parties of 2.  The sushi bar was a bit of a squeeze last night, but the experience there being served piece by piece is definitely the way to go.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Have been here twice and the first time was awesome. The second was ok, as this place seems to have lost some of the specialness that it had when it was new.

The servers are still polite, the food is still fresh and amazing, but somehow the individual attention and focus has given way to a formulaic approach that gets you in and out with the precision of the Toyota production system.

The first time we went, the highlight was Masaki Sasaki cutting ankimo directly off the monkfish liver - dropping it gracefully on our plates. It felt organic and wonderful.

May try again, but at this price am disappointed with sameness.
author: Bob K.

description: Sushi were so fresh. Service was great. Owner was so friendly. I had Omakase with my family and we had awesome experience. It is a MUST GO spot when you travel to San Francisco.
author: Eric L.

description:
Understated and neutral interior, the service is friendly, attentive and fun, the chefs sushi bar table is the perfect size and height, full view of the creations made with masterful hands.  With a few rounds of sake down, the experience gets livelier and livelier.  Encourages a fun and energetic vibe rather than a quiet or contrived environment.

Jackson Yu is hilarious.  Humble, sweet, and incredibly skillful.  I would go again just to hang out with him  

Nothing about this meal was average, definitely worth the reservation.  The sequence of courses told a story through texture, mouth feel, oils/savory, it's hard to describe, you definitely need to try for yourself.
author: R B.

description: This place only loses 1 star for value but otherwise it's a good place. I got the more expensive version of their Omakase menu, which I'm not sure I can recommend, the $150 menu likely would have been better value. I will say the quality of the fish here is better than any US based sushi restaurant I've been too, their fish is impressive and the chefs are great. The sake paring with the meal was also very good, but when it comes to value it's expensive compared to other options. If you want the best quality fish outside of Japan then this is the place to go.
author: Mark H.

description:
When my partner and I do celebrations, we do them big. For our anniversary this year, we chose Omakase.

I pass Omakase every day on my way to work, and we've been to their sister restaurants (Live Sushi, Okane) and liked them. Little did we know that Omakase was going to be on a level of decadence that I haven't experienced at a sushi restaurant here in San Francisco before.

The sushi chefs dedicate serious attention to you. You can even let them know if you don't like a type of fish, and they'll do their best to tailor things to your taste. You'll get plenty of toro and uni, the best sellers. I don't care too much for uni, but months later, I'm still thinking about the steamed egg & uni combo that was the one of my favorite dishes we were served. Other memorable dishes were this ridiculous ice mountain piled with sashimi, the wagyu beef and duck, and the most tender toro I've ever had. Oh, and there was a clam broth dish that we adored.

I have a lot of good memories of our meal at Omakase. It's not a fast meal - you'll be there for a few hours, and you'll leave fuller than you've ever been from sushi. I'm not sure that my wallet can handle another Omakase meal any time soon, but I'll be thinking about it until I can go again.
author: Christina S.

description:
Omakase was truly a world class experience.
I went here with my S/O for his birthday since we both love sushi and wanted an intimate experience. 
The service was beyond helpful, and were very friendly and professional. 
Each dish paired so well together, and there was definitely a flow. I was so sad when they brought out the last dish. 
You will definitely leave satisfied, but not over stuffed which is good. 
The whole service lasted around 2 hours. 
My favorite part was the fresh nigiri, and the explanation of each fish was wonderful. 
This is definitely a splurge so I would recommend coming here on a special occasion. 
Overall, it was worth the splurge, and experience. 
I didn't take any photos because I wanted to enjoy the experience without any distractions. I recommend doing that for all - besides, it's a bit rude to leave your fish waiting there. 
The only critic I could give is, to treat everyone the same. We were a little disappointed when we saw a group at the sushi bar celebrating a birthday as well that got extra items. It was a little bummer because we were also celebrating my bfs birthday yet didn't get the same extra items. All in all it was a great experience. 

Ps; the music is very soothing, you feel so relaxed during / after your meal.
author: Janessa H.

description:
What a disappointment. After all the great reviews and the Michelin star earned again this year, this was well below my expectations. Let's go over why it such a letdown. I got the Yamato Omakase ($200) and spent close to 3 hours dining. Time that could have be cut down easily as they were preparing things during the dinner that could have been easily done beforehand like the bamboo leaves for the tokusen sashimi display.

When it comes to service, it was definitely Michelin star quality service. Servers were very attentive, friendly, asked if you wanted a complimentary sake shot, and made sure your table was clean after every dish. Chefs were pretty much the same, though the physical spacing of the restaurant is huge and creates a distance between you and them that makes it feel very impersonal. I will say what I liked the most was that they teach you the proper way to enjoy sushi. Hands only, in one bite, and with real wasabi - all things I appreciate as I always make my dining companion eat with me in a similar style.

It's ironic how the restaurant called Omakase is kaiseki rather than true omakase. Kaiseki refers to a full multi-course traditional Japanese dinner, which is what this was. I'd say less than half the meal was actually omakase a.k.a. chef's choice of nigiri (sashimi on a small square of rice). It was an array of appetizers and some subpar sashimi before we finally got the nigiri. I did like the surf clam out of all the sashimi, but besides that, they were all extremely fishy, not fresh, and no sushi ginger was provided. I've mentioned before that they used real wasabi, but it was so inconsistent in preparation that it took away from the meal. Sometimes you had a big glob of wasabi and it gave quite a kick in your nigiri, other times you could barely taste it at all like when I ate it with my sashimi. So like the meal order/pacing, we finally review the nigiri. It hit some high points with the flounder and torched horse mackerel, but everything else was only okay (refer to the nigiri in my photos). Nothing blew your mind, even the fish you've never heard of (knifejaw, alfonsio, wild adult yellowtail) were alright.

Meal Value (from 1-10, my measure of quantity/quality of the meal compared to price): 7
You may be thinking well if my meal was that bad, how come this was at an average meal value? I gave it this value as they use real wasabi and fish you'll most likely never eat anywhere else. It's hard to quantify value when it's a once in a life time experience. I discussed it with my dining companion, but rare fish doesn't change how bad the ingredients/preparation were for the sushi. In addition, I found it quite outrageous that they charged for standard green tea. 

At the end of the day, I would not recommend this experience to others (especially at this price point). If I were to summarize my experience in two words - inconsistent kaiseki.
author: Hung Yu C.

description:
For my boyfriend's birthday, I decided to surprise him with this place since it has been on our bookmarks. I was honestly a little disappointed and didn't think it was all that great.

I've been to other sushi places for their omakase and this place didn't live up to my expectations. Maybe I had too high hopes for this place? 

However, the service was amazing. I didn't have to ask for someone to refill my tea. There was a small card saying happy birthday and cute little drawings from the chefs on the back. 

Overall, I did enjoy my experience here. I just wouldn't come back, given the price it's at. Definitely something to try though!
author: Kristie L.

description:
When bae sends a link to the 2018 Michelin Guide and says "Wanna see if we can reserve at one of these places tomorrow night? Omakase has a table for 2 at 5:15pm.", the only correct answer to this is: YES???? No occasion, no reason, yes I'm a spoiled baby :3

We were running a bit late as we decided to walk to Omakase all the way from Lucky Strike, so we gave them a call to ensure we wouldn't lose our table. Finally arrived and we sat on a side table - my only gripe of the night. I'm a sucker for bar seating but I accepted my fate since we only made reservations the day before. Omakase offers two menus - $150 or $200. We opted for the $150 so we could order a la carte if we were still hungry after.

Everything was good but my favorites of the night were the uni chawanmushi, all the nigiri sets (heh), uni with ikura over rice, LOBSTER TAMAGO?! (this was really amazing), and A5 wagyu nigiri (ordered a la carte).

Verdict: whenever I do omakase, I'm always about the nigiri/sashimi, but this time I was thoroughly impressed with all the hot dishes at Omakase that were served. If we took the hot dishes at Omakase and combined it with the nigiri at Kusakabe, made a baby, bam - we got the perfect sushi joint.
author: Judith L.

description:
TL;DR top notch one of a kind omakase experience with Chef Taka

Words cannot describe how your taste buds will dance when you try the sushi at Omakase. The course started with some appetizers, followed by the sashimi. None of which blew me away. However, once we got to the nigiri, everything just kept going uphill. Each and every piece was unique and delicious, but they just just kept getting better and better. Everything was topped off with an a la carte item, nigiri chosen by our Chef Taka. It was smokey, fatty, melt in your mouth, deliciousness. Before I put it in my mouth, as it hovered over my tongue and my nose got a whiff, I could already taste the smoked goodness. Dessert was a simple dish, fruit, which were so buttery soft, so subtly sweet, and melt in your mouth. The freshness, quality, and skill that Omakse brings, is why they are Michelin rated. If you've ever watched Buzz Feed's "Worth It" series, you must've seen Steven and Andrew's reactions when they eat their top $$$ food. The love they have on their face is what you will be feeling when you come here.

I made a reservation to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday. We arrived promptly at 8:30 and we were seated at the bar as requested. Be sure to make a reservation at least a month in advance because they fill up quickly. The restaurant is quite small, so you might be a bit squished with your neighbors, so cuddle up with your dinner date. 

Chef Taka and the entire team made the experience delicious, memorable, and fun. Thank you, Omakase!
author: Sophia L.

description:
We came here on New Years Eve and I gotta say I really appreciate all the things they did to make this night special for us (as we were also celebrating our anniversary).

We had a seating at 8:45 at a table and the table was decorated with a small card saying happy anniversary, signed by all the chefs (and they drew cute sea animals)! Plus at the end of the meal, we got flowers! Again, went above and beyond our expectations!

So a bit of a bizarre thing happened to me and boyfriend as we were going through the set courses. Basically before the main course we were both literally busting because we were so full! Omakase staff were super accommodating and let us take the leftovers home (I think this was probably a special case as you know this kind of thing is meant to be eaten within moments of being prepared), given we still had 5 or so courses left.

All in all, I loved the service, ambiance, and food of Omakase. Thank you Omakase for such a memorable and delicious night!
author: Mimi T.

description:
Here again on a Monday night! Same amazing dinner! Thanks chef Jackson! We had a great time dining here with your superb hospitality.
 :-)
author: jc p.

description:
Came here to celebrate my birthday. I've been wanting to try this place for the longest time! This place is easy to pass on the streets unless you look up at the sign. Once you enter, you will be greeted by the waitresses. They are all very kind and helpful. We were seated in front of sushi chef Jackson. Was intrigued by the fact the he can speak Chinese which made it a tad bit easier for my mother to understand everything. Food was exquisite. You can either opt for the $150 or $200 Omakase. We opted for the $150 Omakase.

Highlight of the night:Akamatsu (ruby snapper)
According to the chef, this is the most expensive white fish you can get in the market. I can't even express how divine the flavor and texture were. I did not feel worthy of such a great tasting fish. 

Arctic char: they CHARred the top of the fish with a flame thrower. I'm lame okay but the charred taste you get compliments the fish ever so perfectly. It was a great combo and I could've ate 10 pieces of these alone. 

Wagyu A5:(had to do as an extra order since it doesn't come with the $150 Omakase) everywhere I go I always get wagyu A5 and I can never get enough. If you've never had A5 wagyu, I highly suggest you try it ASAP!

Hokkaido Uni: Another thing I always get when available. Uni is butter to the ocean. Very fresh here and super creamy.

Toro: also a must get. Toro is the belly part of the fish which contains high contents of fat and omega. Great for your hair, Skin and foodie soul. 

Lobster tamago: this is maybe the best tamago I've had in the Bay Area. Very light and fluffy with the hint of lobster flavor. Goes very well with the red miso soup.

All in all, everything was delicious. The only complaint I would have would be two pieces of sushi I had, the rice was falling apart when I picked it up. That's definitely not expected from a Michelin Omakase restaurant. One star down because of that. They definitely made me feel super special with the birthday card and flower. Very sweet of them indeed.
author: Ada H.

description:
Since dining here two years ago I was very curious to see how Omakase was 2 years later.

Still just as great, but just a few minor, simplified tweaks:

- They no longer do free 1/2 glass of Krug on the house for their guests; they seasonally rotate a complimentary welcome drink. For us this past weekend it was a glass of sake

- They no longer have 3 menu offerings; rather, there are 2 menus, one at $150 and one at $200. The $200 one includes a few more add-ons like a deluxe sashimi platter with o-toro as well as a wagyu course


Service is attentive, food is wonderful - I almost feel like the food is more authentic and less fusion than the first time I had it when it opened. They still grate their own wasabi but have simplified a lot of the nigiri - less frills/sauce.

Make a reservation! They have two small 2-person tables or you can dine at the bar.
author: Veronica S.

description:
This was a special treat night out for my boyfriend and I. Originally we were supposed to go to Outside Lands Music Festival, but instead decided to sell our tickets and use the money towards Omakase.

We met about 1 year ago, and this was in celebration of that time. We got there a little too early, so decided to go within 1 mile radius to a bar close by. 

The restaurant only seats about 18 people, usually people in pairs. And you can only dine here with a reservation. Majority of the people being seated, were celebrating their anniversaries or birthdays, which was noticeable, because of the nice placard in front of their seats.

There were two sets at different prices, from $150 to $200 per person. For a special, there was an additional $50 of an entree to share that was of local uni. We decided to go straight for the $200 set and with more deliberation, added the $50 for the special uni plate. There was complimentary sake, which was refreshing. 

I adore the hostess/ waitress, she was completely funny and is so nice. All the service was beyond amazing. It was a full house, and 3 chefs working on all our dishes. I think each chef had a certain amount of guests and was taking care of their sets. Ours was chef Ken, but he didn't speak much to my bf and I. I liked how they worked together and were playful, they were able to show a softer side, in which was nice for a change.

Our dishes were extremely delicious! Every dish, had small bites and were executed quite nicely. The last time we had omakase, was at another high-end restaurant in L.A., and that was also very delicious. In comparison, we preferred the one in L.A. more than our dining experience here at Omakase. I do highly recommend trying it out and splurging. 

Customer Service: 5 Stars
Food Quality: 5 Stars
Dining Experience: 3 Stars
author: Vivian V.

description:
This meal has ruined us for the very-good sushi we usually enjoy. Just at a different level. I'd never had omakase before but thought I could demonstrate a willingness to not be in control for my BF's birthday ;) 

Wonderful service and spectacular food. A bigger wine selection (we don't like sake) would have made it perfect. Now we just need to wait a few weeks before returning to everyday sushi.
author: Robin W.

description:
We came here to celebrate our anniversary, and was surprised with a nice card and a shot of sake to start our meal.

We didnt manage to get a seat at the bar, and I think that definitely dampened the experience a little. The food was good though, don't get me wrong, but it just isnt the full sensory experience enjoying it at the table. 

For a comparable experience, try Sushi Yoshizumi in San Mateo.
author: Christina N.

description: By far the best sushi spot in SF.  The rice...the rice was freaking awesome.  Enough said!  I also like the heavy beer cups.  It's not cheap but it's def. worth the $$$$.  Some of the in between small dishes were OK but the sushi was fantastic!
author: Nana K.

description:
Really fantastic meal to celebrate a new beginning of my career. I for once took a close friend of mine out as he often pays for meals and we've been discussing an opportunity for me to return favor. Plus of all the remaining and dwindling number of male friends, I was afraid that I won't be able to keep him for long: a man who I've known for nearly 20 years, who likes to eat sushi like I do, who knew me before I knew myself, they are as rare as good sushi places in the Bay Area. A meal for two would set you back half a grand but that's to be expected. I think good sushi is expected to be expensive as the fish has been flown in from Tokyo. Another place where I had this kind of uni was a Michelin 3 star place in New York. It's pretty hard to beat the quality. 

Allow yourself up to 2 hours. Also, expect to be fed like a dolphin, one piece of time, from mild to strong. There are two options to the patrons. The slightly more expensive version has a couple additional dishes, but I think for what I generally consume, it would be too much quantity. I think the lesser expensive version of omakase is portion appropriate.

This restaurant is adjacent to a more casual isakaya place which I'd gone before, but this was a much more intimate, quiet establishment. 

Service was both efficient and elaborate, yet not rushed or pretentious. The silver skinned fish were my favorite, though anything with Hokkaido uni should not be missed. The celebration was for me to join a multi national firm, the largest of its kind on the planet, pre IPO, with ample opportunity to travel to Asia. As I start the count down to my upcoming, first, but certainly not the last Asia bound trips, I wondered if I could replicate my eating expedition on a side trip to Tokyo in the near future.  And if time does not permit, then perhaps I'd simply return here instead after my trips. 

There is definitely something to be said about enjoying a perfect, exotic meal at the comfort of your own backyard.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Fine, it's exceptional but pretty damn expensive. We started early and sat at the sushi bar with chef Ken. Over time, he warmed up and told us about how he's from Osaka and he trained 20 hours a day for 3 years. It was interesting. 

The sake pairings were fun. The volume of sake was low in the beginning so we got more. But then the pairings got larger! Lesson is to just wait. 

Their otoro was amazing because they careful removed any stringy tendons and it was pure bliss. One of the pieces had a drizzle of truffle oil which was a great touch. I personally don't like clam and there were 1-2 stringy pieces that were harder to chew. Hate when that happens. Wagyu was awesome and the lamb, not so much. 

Overall it was great. I'd definitely go back if I didn't have to pay :)
author: Young Y.

description:
Very nice lil upscale sushi place. DH picked this as a surprise birthday dinner & overall, a wonderful experience. Restaurant is a small, intimate setting. Most seating is at the sushi bar. There are a few small tables seating 2. They have 2 omakase menus: $150 for the regular & $200 for an extra course of sushi & duck/wagyu beef.

All of the fish was super fresh & portion sizes were generous. The first dish was a soy braised monkfish liver, which was nice & earthy. Next was a veggie dish: daikon, lotus root, king oyster mushroom, and carrot. 

Sashimi started with bluefin tuna & house-smoked kanpachi, which was nice & complex. Gorgeously plated with some microgreens & a shiso leaf. Hokaido uni & chawan mushi was a little egg custard, very smooth, one of the best.

They had some more creative dishes, such as long neck clam & lobster tail sashimi, smoked ikura over a giant mound of shaved ice. Just amazing!

Steamed lobster claw with sunomono - good, but very mild flavors. Nothing exciting here, but it was likely a break before the nigiri started. The first flight of nigri included: mackerel (the best we've had), Japanese halibut (very firm with a bit of caviar on top), iwashi (fresh sardine), ocean trout, and bluefin chu toro. All delicious & not too weird.

Then a mini uni-don - tiny bit of rice covered with rich Hokkaido uni & garnished with smoked house-marinated ikura. I thought it was a little too salty. They were generous with the ikura...too much of a good thing!

The next flight of nigri included: live Hokkaido scallop, torched sawara (Spanish Mackeral from Nagasaki), torched Japanese Barracuda, torched snapper (which was the best). DH really liked the torched fish, which was lightly brushed on fire and blowtorched, giving it a smoky flavor. Shima aji (striped jack) and bluefin O Toro, which was super fatty, as expected.

After that, we were getting quite full. The duck breast with yuzu kosho was a tiny portion, not too exciting compared to the fish. The waygu beef was really good, rich and meaty tasting, alas, also one nigri sized bite. Waygu is pricey, but not sure if this was worth it. DH said next time he would go without it & order more seafood instead.

Finally, it was a piece of tamago with a torch caramelized top. It's supposed to have a whole lobster in each tray, but honestly, we couldn't taste it.

After the sushi was lobster agedashi miso soup with mushroom. It was pretty nice. Dessert was a ginger poached pear with kumquat candied yuzu. A fairy dessert that was light & relatively healthy.

Since it was my birthday, they gave me flowers & a nice signed card with cute doodles on it.

Our chef didn't talk much, but he did answer our questions. He was definitely passionate about the food and it was entertaining watching him work his magic. We definitely recommend sitting at the bar. Overall, a good choice for a special occasion dinner. Unique offerings, not expensive for the quality & quantity of food, flavors not too weird for an American palate.
author: Kari C.

description: The food was delicious and the waitress was attentive and knowledgeable. Only issue was the flies. Might've just been a bad day but the whole place was littered in fruit flies. I'm talking about dozens and dozens of mini flying fruit flies. Kinda killed the experience.
author: Wesley H.

description:
Omakase! More like Oh My Deliciousness!! 

The restaurant is located downstairs of an apartment complex and situated right next to another sushi restaurant. Make sure you go to the right one! The restaurant seats about 18 people, making it a more intimate experience with the chefs.  You'll most likely need to make a reservation before coming here. Great ambience and beautiful décor on the walls! 

My boyfriend took me here to celebrate my birthday and Omakase made sure to make it a special night for me! All the waitresses remembered my name by the end of the night and they gifted me a beautiful rose before I left. Wonderful service! 

There were two different fixed-price menus, and we decided to choose the Yamato Omakase menu. Definitely worth the price!! Our assigned chef prepared each of our meal in front of us and he took the time to perfect every single Nigiri. It was incredible how much detail and work were placed in each course. You can taste the freshness in the fish and the flavors flowed flawlessly together with each bite. The chef even told us where they imported their fish from, and most of it came straight from Tokyo!! Incredible! 

This was one of the best sushi experiences I've ever had. I would definitely recommend everyone to try this place!!
author: Shirley T.

description:
Good:
1. Everything - Amazing flavours on every...single...course.  Can't remember ever smiling so much while savouring my food!  Get the $200 menu for more sashimi and osetra caviar.

Neutral:
1. Pricey $$$$

Worth it?:
Despite the price, definitely worth it and a must try for special occasions. A well deserved Michelin star.
author: MJ L.

description: Hands down the BEST omakase experience. We ordered the sake pairing and do not regret getting it. We received excellent customer service from the minute we walked into the restaurant. The ambiance was serene. Our chef was very friendly. Food was top notch. Definitely worth checking out, especially if you're there for a celebration .
author: Teresa C.

description:
My fiancé proposed earlier that weekend and surprised me with dinner reservations at Omakase to celebrate. The whole experience was phenomenal beginning to end, and I couldn't have asked for a better place for my first official omakase experience in front of a chef, and to celebrate our engagement in the most amazing city! 

Décor was simple and traditional, and lighting dim and romantic. 

We dined in front of sushi chef Jackson Yu and every dish was so fresh and well balanced. You could really taste the quality of the ingredients and unique display of the food. There was so much variety - some include big-eyed snapper, egg custard pudding with sea urchin, and Japanese barracuda. We opted for the more expensive omakase ($200/pp vs $150/pp) and were stuffed by the end of the meal. The chef's choice that day was mostly protein, which we really enjoyed. 

If you were celebrating a special occasion, the staff also prepared a flower and personalized card that each sushi chef would sign - a really thoughtful touch to add to the meal. I was overwhelmed by the whole experience and dining with my fiancé to celebrate our engagement was so special! 

Would recommend for a special occasion or if you want the ultimate sushi experience! Michelin star rated too!
author: Syyu C.

description:
We ordered the Yamato Omakase-$200 meal and I was definitely super full after (of course I didn't come here starving though) I thought the price was decent as well.

Everyone from the waiters/waitress and chefs were all really polite and attentive. Water always filled, didn't really wait long for each course. Sitting at the bar was really fun. We got to see what the chef was making for us and he was really passionate about the food.

All the fish was AMAZING. Tasted so fresh and buttery. I tried a lot of things I've never had before and liked every single one. There is a good mixture of cooked foods as well as the nigri. They have a menu in front of you so that you can reference it (and order more if you wanted after the meal) but of course they explain what everything is to you.

I would definitely come back again! Definitely a happy customer.
author: Randy L.

description:
This place is overhyped. 

For $200+ person with no alcohol, I was not impressed. The food was good, don't get me wrong... but it did not blow me away. Dishes were not unique. I was full at the end, and extremely impressed with the service at the restaurant, but for the price point, I feel like there are better options in the city (like Ju-Ni).

I'd pass on Omakase -- you're not missing out on anything.
author: Stephanie B.

description: Best fresh sushi in town! Really great service ! Really enjoy coming to this restaurant with my family
author: Nadia Z.

description:
Another sitting with the Omakase SF group last night... another great experience.  Just coming home from a few months in the Asias, it's hard not to miss the simplicity of the Japanese culture.  While all these new restaurants and groups are trying to please the thirsty visual aspect of social media, very few are bringing it back to the roots of their dishes.  When it comes to Japanese food, it's very safe to say less is truly more with pride in the details of each ingredient used.  

Although I am fully aware that each spectator has their own preferences in tastes and flavors, I can't help but to notice the meticulous care the chefs put into each one of their nigiri pieces and dishes.  

I absolutely love that the Japanese chefs know their ingredients well... where it's from, why it's good at certain times of year, and can translate from Japanese to English for us to understand why certain ingredients are named the way they are.  I always want to know what I'm eating even if I might forget later... hehe.  It nice though you know when someone can take you on an adventure to a place you're not familiar with.  Let's be honest... all foodies out there think they know it all but in actuality we don't know that much.  So it's nice to have a local of that genre of food take us on a journey in their craft.
