That's what I appreciate most about this omakase experience compared to many others.

The head chef is actually Chinese.  In a place like San Francisco where the culture and understanding of food is ever evolving, it's nice to see someone like him respecting the craft and making sure we all leave happy.  I've eaten here on a few occasions and he recognizes me and the friends I send over.  Each and every single time, he would ask us if the food was great and how was our experience.  We'd always tell him it's amazing, but he always gets a little serious and asks again... "Really... serious question. How were the ingredients and be honest..." That's what he'd say each time.  He'd worry and tell us something like, "Well I got a 3 star the other day on yelp and they said it wasn't good so I need a real honest opinion..." He says I work so hard everyday and I just want to know my customers are getting the best of my team.  

Bescause of his studious attitude and the amazing food they put out, it's hard not to return with our friends each time!  

Thank you for dinner last night guys!  Love it!
author: Colin M.

description: Loved this place very much. Very intimate setting. Came here for my birthday dinner. At the end of the dinner, they even gave me a flower with a card. Wonderful experience!
author: Bonnie T.

description:
Why am I giving this place only 2 stars? Because...

1) I sat at the end of the table with Chef Tora. I tried making something conversation with him but he was very quiet/boring with one word answers so I gave up. He made zero effort in making any conversation. When he served us food, he mumbled everything super fast so it was difficult to understand anything. The other two chefs were having lots of fun interacting with their guests. I don't think it's required that the sushi chef need to be socially outgoing but, to me, omokase is all about getting to know your chef and how they mastered their culinary art. I mean, what am I paying $200+ for if not just the food? This said, I'd recommend sitting in front of Chef Jackson.

2) However, Chef Jackson, the younger looking guy who speaks Chinese, seemed like he only interacts with guests if they're young/beautiful. You're out of luck if you're old and/or not showing skin--very sleazy of him. The other chef (I don't know his name) looked like Krang from TMNT.

3) There was a long wait (like 20 minutes) between the first couple courses. This is unacceptable. Good omokase places adjust the tempo of your meal based on how you're doing, and if not, they don't let a long time pass where you're just confused about what's going on.

4) This last point might seem petty, but the lady who initially greeted us wasn't Japanese (or even Asian)--not that she had to be, but this is the first thing that detracted to the authenticity that you're at a fine omokase-serving establishment. I mean, white/Mexican people can make great sushi too, but there's something about being served something like borcsh from a Russian mother that just makes the experience better. This fact really doesn't matter, but it also didn't help that she was always wearing dirty-looking gym socks in her slippers (fashion faux pas) and she had this wrist brace on that probably was hosting colonies of germs falling onto your food. I mean, it just decreases the elegance--something I think is required for a Michelin star.

5) Overpriced--go to Kusakabe instead! The food is just as good for half the price.

Obviously, the food was delicious--there is no doubt about this but I do not understand why this place earned a Michelin star. Service is inconsistent/sloppy and that server looked the opposite of elegant. Other than the food, the only good thing is that there is a lot of parking.

Check out all the other great omokase places in SF before wasting your cash here.
author: Marlon T.

description:
Food -  food and chef skill is pretty much as good as it's going to get for sushi in the US.  IMHO there are a probably 2-3 other places in SF that offer similar quality.   Maybe a more discerning diner would be able to say that x or y place has better fish etc. but I think it mostly comes down to personal preference.  Kusakabe, for example, takes a less traditional approach relative to others (which some prefer or not prefer) but I wouldn't say that either is 'better'.  

The meal starts with some items that are more on the creative side (the uni in egg custard was particularly excellent), moves on to seasonal, traditional nigiri.  In August we had several  pieces - that I can remember, Aji (horse mackrel), sea bream, otoro.   The chef let us try baby ginger which was really good.  There was a nice red miso palate cleanser and we finished with a poached pear and kumquat dessert.  It was a nice, light end to the evening.

We did the smaller Hideaki set menu and added wagyu.  It was plenty of food.  

Ambiance - everything is nice but unpretentious and understated.  The chefs and staff have good camaraderie, so it's a more fun atmosphere relative to your typical fine dining establishment.  Many couples celebrating birthdays, anniversaries etc.   Overall meal took about 2 hours.

If you're in the mood for high-end sushi, it's a solid choice.
author: Holly P.

description:
"Omakase," or chef's selection of sushi, actually translates to "I'll leave it up to you."

They are always a full house with guests. Nice ambience and decortion.

Food was exquisite. You can either opt for the $150 or $200 Omakase with the $80 sake pairing

This is one of the best sushi experiences I've had in the US. Every single piece of sushi we had was as amazing as the next. The flavor and texture of each nigiri was exactly the way I like it, and I really enjoyed the rice which was very,very high quality. The ginger also tasted less sweet and more sour which I enjoyed as well.

What followed-- wow. I was not a dutiful in my record-keeping, but all of them stood out, see the pictures. Our experience felt more like an exploration of texture than of flavor; many of the pieces were out-of-this-world soft.

The most memorable part of our meal was watching and talking to the chefs Jackson!, he is extremely knowledgeable and fun to dine with

It was definitely worth the expense and I would come back every month in a heartbeat. Overall I found it a delightful experience.
author: Katie E.

description:
Incredibly delicious. Every piece of fish we had was amazing and I had the best lobster dish in my entire life. Sake tasting was great and more than I had bargained for ;) 

Service was outstanding and chef Sam was a highlight of the meal.  

Definitely pricey and not sure I would come back but still a great experience overall.
author: Laura D.

description:
I have to say, hands down the BEST omakase in town. Been to most of those hip and popular omakase places in town you name it, many fall short in terms of creativity, portion, taste or variety of the fish. You may walk out with a $550 bill for two at this place, but that's the money well spent. Service was superb! I like Yamakase (in LA) a lot for abundant variety of the toro, uni and truffle, but as satisfying as freshest sashimi any place could possibly be, Omakase beats all others. 

Our chef Sam-san was a hilarious guy and his section was full of laughters. We had a wonderful anniversary celebration again. 

Well done Kash! We will be back!
author: CY C.

description:
Omakase is quite possibly the best kept secret outside of Japan. I was shocked at how good the quality was and how close the tastes and flavors were to that of the food we had at Tsukiji market.The small chef's table bar is unassuming and next door to the more casual Okane.

There were 3 chefs throughout the evening, which kept us entertained and fed us well. Everything presented to us was super fresh and tasted amazing. Each dish was explained and the chefs gave us a little background about where it came from. I ate everything and LOVED everything! 

The menu changes based on what is available from the market, but we were lucky to try some delicious rarities. I couldn't be more happy with the way dinner turned out. The intimate setting meant getting to know some of the other diners and the food surpassed my wildest expectations. Lots of food, a little pricey, but worth it for the quality and a great experience.
author: johnson h.

description:
FIVE STARS OUT OF FIVE BECAUSE YES THIS PLACE IS BEYOND SUGOI. Forgive my language because the class of this restaurant clearly needs to be handled with more sophistication, but for a commoner such as myself who saved up enough money to splurge at this two time Michelin Star restaurant, I WILL SAY WHAT I WANT TO SAY ABOUT THIS PLACE IN HOWEVER I MAY AND THAT IS THAT THIS PLACE WAS ABSOLUTELY WONDERFUL. 
From service to presentation to taste, my gahd, I was impressed. The particular omakase served the day my friends and I attended was an unigasm. Tell me how you can serve uni in so many different types of ways where I could never get tired of it! My gosh, I still have dreams about that uni experience. 
First things first though, let me start with the beginning of our experience. Immediately upon entering, my friends and I felt intimidated by the serious atmosphere of the Michelin star restaurant. Upon seating, however, we could see that the servers and chefs cared deeply about our comfort and overall entire experience. They were not there to make us uncomfortable, but to provide us with service beyond what most humans are able to give each other. We felt cared for, appreciated, and educated throughout the entire experience. Our chairs were pulled for us to sit. Our sakes constantly refilled as we took a sip. The sushi chefs were more than delighted to share their knowledge on the food and culture they were indulging us in. As the night continued on, we felt more and more comfortable and found ourselves engaging with each and every individual around us in the restaurant. Everything was fascinating and we wanted more to be a part of the entire restaurant. That is how I felt upon eating here. I've never been catered to in such a gentle way in my life. The waitress in particular was so graceful and alert; I was truly impressed. She also showed excellent teamwork as she described the food items as well as assisted the sushi chefs in delivering the food to their customers. Every movement was graceful and that did not go unnoticed by me. 
Continuing on to the food -- this place is definitely fine dining and I believe it is so excruciatingly important to be mindful of each and every component put into each dish here. If you do not come in with an open mind and are solely coming in to devour for hunger purposes, then you will miss out on an enlightening experience. Unlike most omakase places that focus solely on the fish, this restaurant introduces special seaweeds, fruits and vegetables meant to be helpful for digestion, skin and more. Of course, the fish quality was beyond unbelievable here. Each and every piece held it's own texture -- it's own specialty -- it's own mouth drooling explosion. And the talent of the sushi chefs were amazing at preparing these rare, high quality ingredients. But if you do end up eating here, keep in mind every little detail put into the dishes. If you have any questions at all about anything, ask anyone, and they will be glad to elaborate and open your mind to what you thought was solely a plate with fish and seaweed. Take a bite of the beautiful fish, let it melt on your tongue, let it saturate your palette, think about what you're tasting, try to express it in words, and then, move on to the next piece.
GUHH. Such an educational dinner. So glad I decided to bring my boyfriend here for his birthday. We also received the cutest signed birthday card at our reservation spot and a complimentary birthday surprise. Thank you so much for the wonderful experience Omakase. I look forward to spending more special occasions with you in the future.
author: Kim N.

description:
My second time here...everything was good but not $200 pp good.

I don't know if it was the quality of food or experience but it definitely has gone downhill since my first visit.
author: Anna I.

description: Everything is prepared in the significant simple way. That also speaks of its flavor. Simple, clean and surprising. The Uni and salmon roe dish is one of my favorite.
author: kristofer l.

description:
Omakase is a delicious (REALLY delicious) Michelin-star Japanese restaurant. We did have reservations but due to our timing, we chose a day that we sat at a side table (definitely wish we got the chance to sit at the sushi bar though - try to do this!). Because we were on the side, the waitress explained every dish instead of the chef, but she was also really thorough and made sure we enjoyed our experience. 

The food is absolutely amazing and delicious. Yes, the price is steep, especially if you do the sake pairing, which we opted out of. But to be honest, the price is understandable after you try these delectable dishes. They're all small but packed with flavor, and I was surprised by dishes I thought would be on the plain side. One of the dishes was a tofu and tomato dish (which I was skeptical) but turned out to be delicious and refreshing! Opting for the $200 meal, we had scrumptious dishes with premium ingredients, such as lobster sushi (first time - turned out amazing!) and Wagyu beef nigiri. We also had an o-toro that was absolute tuna deliciousness! 

All in all, superb service with such an enjoyable dining experience (though I definitely recommend sitting at the sushi bar for the full experience - unless you're looking for a more private dinner). Come for the food and enjoy the sense of community as well (the other guests were kind and clearly loved the food as well, pouring everyone sake and having a good time)!
author: Mimi T.

description:
It's kind of nice when you always get to pick where you want to eat. The only problem is "picking a place" can be hard. With so many options, it can be tough to narrow it down. In this case, it was easy breezy as we love Japanese cuisine. 

We opted for the Hideaki Omakase ($150 per person): 
 
-Two Appetizers = crab appetizer and soup was spot on. 

- One Sashimi = great cut and fresh.

- Ten pieces Nigiri = different type of nigiris. I enjoyed some of the fishes. My favorite was definitely the sake and uni. 

- One Owan = dessert

- Kokuryu "Ryu" Sake = the smooth texture was absolutely tasty. 

It is very unlikely for any restaurant to be giving out orchid flowers, but Omakase restaurant did and I love it. I came back from the restroom and it was placed on my table with more desserts. Score!

I'm impressed with their service and their attentive staff. They take good care of you. I hope you give Omakase restaurant a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description:
Being born and raised in Japan, I always try to look for the best sushi in town. But nothing really reminds me of home in the city. 

Omakase on the other hand is the closest place to home that I have ever found in San Francisco. If you ever wonder how authentic Japanese sushi tastes, I definitely recommend Omakase. 

From the presentation to the service, what you get here, is what you would get in Japan. The attention to the smallest detail is what surprised me, I dropped a little bit of soy sauce  on my table and the next thing I know one of the servers was wiping it up for me. This is the kind of service you get in Japan. 

A lot of people who have never experienced the real thing tend to expect the "Americanized" version of Omakase. Omakase translated basically means "Up to the chef" and there is no specific manual as to what kind of food or sushi should be served in a certain order.

Anyways y'all should try here at least once, incomparable to other places in the city!
author: Ryo H.

description:
Most of the fish they serve are rare/exotic fishes, so if you haven't had much exposure to sashimi, I wouldn't recommend it as your first experience. If you're a food explorer and want to try what you normally will not be able to find this might be it. Keep in mind that there are around 16 seats and it was about a 3 hour dining time. They have one chef attend to every four people, and will serve the dishes at about the same time. The ambiance is a modern minimalistic sushi bar, and the staff is very attentive.

There were many many dishes (~19) out of which 12 were nigiri. I'll be honest that the nigiri was more of the highlight than the sashimi and other dishes. The first 6 dishes consisted of assorted sashimi, charimushi, duck liver, eggplant, and unagi. After many pieces of sashimi, it felt like a little too much to the point where it was hard to enjoy. These dishes weren't bad, but I came here to see their craftsmanship on nigiri. Some fish really blew my mind such as the ginger baby mackerel, buri (wild yellowtail), flounder over caviar, and even the gizzard shad. One thing I noticed was that the nigiri was relatively inconsistent. The wasabi would be overpowering for some. The soy sauce would be over drenched on a few. Additionally, I didn't really feel that the rice was made well. Most sushi rice should have a slight vinegar taste and kept at an optimal room temperature. It didn't seem like the rice was well-controlled during its making. This is surprising given how much attention is typically given to rice in upscale nigiri restaurants. 

Now you must be wondering, was this experience worth the hefty $200 per person? Really depends how you see it. There were so many fish I've never heard of despite having been to Japan many many times. Some of the fish I knew were labor intensive to prepare such as the gizzard shad. Also, many expensive ingredients were used (especially imported) such as grade A5 Miyazaki Wagyu, Hokkaido Uni, Caviar, and El Toro. Those are foods you wouldn't find cheap anywhere. So yes, I'd say the price is fair given their expensive ingredients, labor-intensive work, and few seats they are able to serve each night. However, as someone who enjoys primarily nigiri, I'd rather go to other places whose focus is nigiri.
author: Angus L.

description: The food is nice and very friendly environment.  We enjoy the fresh fish and of course the Uni^^
author: Kay F.

description:
Such delicious. Many sushi. 

The bf and I decided to do a treat yo self weekend over Halloween weekend because there didn't seem to be any plans. We holed ourselves up at the Fisherman's Wharf Hyatt and had a full-on tourist weekend. As part of it, he made us reservations at Omakase! The way to a woman's heart is undoubtedly through her stomach :P

We arrived at Omakase a bit early, and there were already others waiting inside. The waiting area is small, so it does the crowded. One of the staff will come up to you and ask your name to confirm against the list of guests they have. The first thing I noticed was the lovely, lovely atmosphere and ambiance of the restaurant. The surrounding lighting is dim, but there's perfect lighting at the bar. All the staff wear kimono, which I thought was neat. 

To start off the meal, they gave everyone a complimentary glass (shot glass sized glass) of sake. The customer service was amazing from start to finish (shout out to Lynn!). If you noted that it was your birthday or anniversary, the restaurant puts out a little card for you and at the end of the meal, they all sign it! How freaking sweet!! The chefs also take pictures with you at the end if you want :D

All the chefs were fun and friendly, and you could tell they were having a good time. The older Japanese chef was so goofy and cute! We had Chef Jackson, and he was super nice and explained stuff to us as well as gave us a demo of how they cut up daikon *mindblown*. I always thought they shredded the daikon, but it's all hand cut!!

The bf and I went for the Yamato Omakase (#YOLO) and also ordered their special, Hakkaku (Japanese Dragonfish, $50 for the whole fish), which came with 12 pieces of sashimi (dat presentation doe), soup and fried skin! We did not realize we got the entire fish, but it was delicioussssssssssss. I wasn't a big fan of the eggplant tempura-like appetizer, it was cold and bland IMO (But I also hate eggplant, so...). The Hakkaku soup was a bit on the saltier side and they may have been a bit heavy-handed with the pepper, but I still really enjoyed it. I also didn't care much for the strawberry mochi dessert...It tasted bitter to me?

Highlights for me:
- Hakkaku sashimi: The meat was...well meaty without being too tough. The texture was something between tai and tuna, if that makes sense. The fish itself had a very light, delicate flavor.
- Ikura: Their ikura is house-cured, and SO freaking good. It's sweet and salty, and paired perfectly with the Hakaku, lobster, giant clam, and uni dishes. 
- Umimasu: Yum! The acid balanced out creamy/fattiness of the fish.
- Aji and Shima Aji: Just can't go wrong with these!
- Anago: Didn't get to take a picture of this, but yum! I'm not a fan of any type of eel-y meats, but twas good!

Omakase is well-deserving of their Michelin star! If you're looking for an omakase experience that isn't too serious and buttoned-up, definitely give Omakase a try (:
author: Doris K.

description:
A very innovative Michelin star restaurant that really captures the essence of fine dining in Japan! When you enter the restaurant, you are greeted by a sushi bar with a limited number of seats. The place is decorated with very traditional Japanese wood work and art, so it really transports you to Japan.

I had the omakase set with sake pairings and everything was very fresh and unique. Some of my favorites were the Hokkaido uni rice and the tomato tartar. All of their fish is imported straight from Japan, so the restaurant really tries to bring Japan to its clientele. 

The first course was a soup and a small appetizer: we were served a seafood soup and the tomato tartar. The tomato tartar was interesting, and it was made so that it resembled an actual, non-vegetarian tartar. We were then served a sashimi course, which was beautifully presented atop a bed of ice and floral decor. After the beginning dishes, there was a ten-piece sushi nigiri course. Each nigiri was served fresh from the chef, who placed each piece on a ceramic sushi plate that each person gets. Each nigiri had a distinct taste, with some being meatier or more tender than others. To finish the meal, we were served kobe beef, which in my opinion, was the star of the show. The beef was tender and cooked perfectly to a medium rare. 
Dessert consisted of a homemade mochi. 

Overall, Omakase is an interesting experience in itself. The restaurant puts emphasis on giving the clientele an authentic taste of Japan, and all the cutlery, plates, and cups were very aesthetic.
author: Sandra S.

description: Beautiful restaurant that brings traditional Japan to the heart of the city. This restaurant is small and only offers seating around the sushi bar where you can see the experts at work. If you are not a person who warms up quickly to strangers then take note this place probably is not for you. There is no such thing as personal space or intimate dinners here. Rather, it is a dinner with the people who are elbow to elbow with you and the chef at the front. They have 2 options on the menu: the 6 or 8 course. We opted for the 6 and believe me it was plenty of food. The servers wear traditional kimonos, with their constant attention to clearing and replenishing your place at the table from behind. For us lady's you are handed a box to store your purse under the bar. The sake is delicious and comes in fun vessels. The food is a journey, with unique flavors and some turbulence- so hold on for a ride. Completely guided by the master minds of Japanese cuisine the roads primarily lead to bliss while others offer strange turns to not so great destinations; however, it is a journey so keep an open mind. The start was with the mountain yam. It was a slimy root which I particularly did not care for. The other courses included a pickled fish which was excellent, a 10 piece sushi journey where the chef would make each piece separately explain and you would pick it up from your board with fingers. All the fish is shipped from Japan, they even offered Japanese ginger - non processed like we like here- which was splended. Sashimi was excellent and the uni custard I could have done without. The soft on soft texture with the one note flavor was not doing it for me. It then ended with a ginger pear and orange dessert which was a perfect light note to end on. It was a fun journey and even though there were a few bumps in the road it is definitely something you should experience at least once.
author: Allie P.

description:
Received 1 Michelin Star in 2016. 

Closer to 2 stars for the food, but the service was great so rounding up to 3.

There are now so many omakase/kaiseki restaurants opening in SF, it's difficult to keep up! My friends and I came to celebrate a birthday at Omakase, and we made reservations a few weeks in advance for their first seating at 5:30pm. The space is quite small, with about 15 counter seats and two small tables. They started off with a complimentary pour of a nice sake, which was very nice. Although all the ingredients seemed fresh, we all left feeling underwhelmed with the meal, especially for the price. The combination of ingredients for some of the dishes was a bit strange, such as the pairing of slimy mountain yam with the ankimo for our appetizer. Also, the dishes were on the bland side, and/or were not elevated at all.

We weren't that impressed by the nigiri selection, and some of the pieces were chewy/stringy. My favorites out of the nigiri were the flounder & barracuda (very tender), uni w/ikura. Sadly, our favorite part of the meal was the add-on of premium sea perch, which was an additional cost. The dessert was too simple (just poached fruit?? not even a cake??), and it did not even taste good. Based on this experience, I will not be back.

SakiZuke Option ($200/person)
-Sashimi
-AiZakana
-TokuSen Sashimi
-Nigiri 12 Kan
-TomeZakana
-OWan

author: Amy D.

description:
I guess someone at Omakase decided to make more money this week, because three hours before our reservation Feb 13th we got this message:

"For this Valentine's week, we are only offering one menu. We usually offer two menus: $150 or $200. For this week, we are only offering our $200 option."

So Valentine's week felt like... a stretch, but why wait until three hours before the reservation to tell us (we made it a month ago)? They got this covered:

"This was a decision we have just made."

Classy.

Honestly, we didn't care so much about the money (it's a lot but we were already going to spend it) but we felt that the experience was more befitting of a budget rental car agency than a $$$$ Michelin restaurant. 

I figured three stars for the five stars it could have been (we canceled, fortunately Akiko's had last minute reservations) and the one star service that it was.
author: Vlad S.

description:
Love love love! Best place in town.
Came here twice in a month!!! 
Chefs are so nice and funny. We had a great nite. Lobster sashimi is so fresh they did it in front of us!!!
author: Wendy H.

description:
What better way to be sent off for your first trip to Japan?
Yes... omakase, with a capital O!

Yamato menu ($150.00 per person)

Mirugai amuse bouche (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=nMCgC_gDIJjSncP6YQ8OYA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), White and red tuna sashimi (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=ytlQWQKQNyCrSW5KY6oeiw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).
Tomato salad (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=HKUo-RXnGTERuY9aO9Iw7g&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), Uni chwan sushi (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fsltQtxMqx6NzIJGbo5SlQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).
Mirugai sashimi (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=EJqZZSxyE8kfi9JRHsLdnw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), lobster claw cucumber salad (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=zJhNAKMlkmdzhcsmaAtQzw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).

Nigiri sushi

Stripe jack (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=lcppiweJdmzhXOGSMf3dxA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), Horse mackerel (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=P2KNWG7usftHj2Rk6-Js1Q&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).
Golden big eye snapper (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=wqatSMMrNfhMH9s9lnPyAA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), Hokkaido sea scallop (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=iyuRfRdEsY2ufKrWoy5lRg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).

Hokkaido uni don (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=F7Yu6gvei7vr6Ze4eHnNiA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q)

Nigiri sushi
Otoro fatty (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=VfADsJdK68TCEszKf4XFtA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), Japanese barracuda (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=9snWK6rYQcQ8142qADN43A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).
Smoked amber jack (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=5K5yo44tK1LQhfQjFFklMQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), Sea eel (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=mTZFRNaNq30dqDk41ujjeA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).

Free range tamago cake (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=seAx0SuWU8SXc9CqMfJzhw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).
Wagyu beef (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=2zF6pdjPGQL-ZitW5abGSA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).
Miso soup with lobster (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=g9yNJEYadn4tEjgtFb-qpA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).

Birthday ice cream mochi (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=BlPVZ_jlUvmiBxtXPol1zA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).

My favorites were the Nigiri otoro and toro (no surprise) and, being a meat eater, the Wagyu beef.  There is nothing negative to say about any of the other offerings.
This was my first sushi counter omakase experience which proved enjoyable and extremely entertaining.  Our sushi chef Ingi (three working the L shaped counter) was informative and meticulous in crafting our meal; very soft spoken and low key, he was detailed in explaining how the seafood was prepared for eating.  We later learned that he worked for a renown Iron Chef who has restaurants in Honolulu and Napa before landing here.  Thanks for my very generous and kind host for arranging for this dinner and thanks to Omakase for a sendoff meal!
author: Mike C.

description: As good as it gets for a sushi and sashimi delight! It's a small 18-seater restaurant, so reservations are a must, especially weekends. The chef takes incredible amount of attention to creat every course. It's like a work of art with delicate tastes exploding on your palate. Chef Sam was serving us and he doted on every detail. The wagyu beef cut just melts in your mouth. You can see the minimalist kitchen as you are seated by the sushi bar. The tasting menu is 150-200/person and well worth the experience. I would not do a full sale pairing, a carafe (8oz) would do nicely for most of the meal.  Most seating are 2-2.5 hrs long. Great place for a special occasion! It's the epitome of an experience- restaurant.
author: Sridevi K.

description:
A mediocre experience. The food was plain and uninspired, starting with the lazily prepared mountain yam dish. Expect watered down flavorless food and boring presentation. Shredded chili, the same micro greens and/or salmon roe on most dishes, and yet somehow the result is the same : bland. We get it, the chef knows how to cut carrots and cucumber into scrolls and ribbons. But why do these same elements need to come up again and again in the same Omakase? It feels like I ate the same flavorless, soulless dishes twice or even 3 times. Aside from the very basic and under seasoned sushi, the Omakase seems preprepared, standing around and cold, nothing aside from the sushi seems freshly made.

Sadly, we walked out after the 6th course, we didn't finish the Omakase. Unfortunate, as it was my wonderful girlfriends birthday. As we left, our Chef was condescending and quite frankly, I have never seen my fish handled so unappetizingly and vigorously as by this 'chef'.  'Gross' comes to mind. Birthday ruined.

Spent over $700.- for a few pieces of sushi, a carafe of sake and a flavorless eggplant and an ugly condescending chef. Save yourself the money.
author: Richard L.

description:
Perhaps I should preface that not dining at the bar may have affected the meal. When dining sushi, I prefer being at the sushi bar because part of the experience is watching the chefs prepare the fish and the interaction. But for last minute reservations, I can't complain. 
I've had my shares of Omakase in my life and know to expect that it's just not possible for a business to give you all the great things without balancing it out with some lesser things. Because of this I usually tend to not go Omakase but always open to exotic fish that I may not know of. I thought they were pretty reasonable w the sushi overall, but I was highly disappointed w the closing, their dessert.. (which I'm big on) was three small pieces of warmed pear with edible flowers for aesthetics. Another thing I was disappointed with was their uni sushi. I love love uni, but this had an interesting unusual flavor I just wasn't too used to. It felt overly fatty but flavorless. 
I opted for the $150 Omakase and I was already getting full w 4 more sushis left (this was a
good thing). So if you've got a small appetite like I do, I suggest the smaller Omakase. 
I thought the staff was attentive and nice, and enjoyed the waitresss Emi, she was funny. But unfortunately a couple of things I had wanted wasn't on the menu. But overall great staff, intimate small restaurant, good sushi. Will I go back? I'm not sure bc for what was the total bill, I can't say the fish was worth that price tag. Or maybe I'm just sad mirugai wasn't a part of the Omakase!
author: Sandy P.

description: I came here for my birthday this year. I love sushi, but sometimes when I go to the more expensive locations in San Francisco, I feel like I am not "getting my money's worth". Even though this place is definitely pricey, I think it is worth it if you enjoy omakase style dining. I would definitely splurge and get the more expensive menu option. It came with an extra, huge sashimi course and a duck course. This is definitely my favorite omakase place I've tried outside of Japan! All of the fish was amazing, and service was top-notch. Over half of the restaurant was celebrating our birthdays, and the staff personalized and did a drawing for each of us! If you have a special occasion coming up or just feel liek splurging a bit, definitely consider coming here!
author: Cynthia M.

description:
I died and went to sushi heaven ~ so yeah its only okay. 
Food is mind blowing delicious, that's not limited to their sake and even their house tea. First thing I did when I went home is order the barley tea on Amazon and its coming from Japan just like everything else at Omakase. Chef Jackson is very serious about his craft but he doesn't forget to interact with his clients. He explained where he sourced and what makes their sashimi so special. The whole experience is just perfect. Can't wait to go back!
author: Jo C.

description:
Recommendation of the day: Not to try it unless you have $200 to waste.

Pros:
- Our host and the waitress was friendly and explained every entree to us. 
- It was easy to find street parking. Tons of spots in front the restaurant especially if you go in the evening or the weekend.

Cons:
- Nothing was memorable after dropping four bills for two people. 
- A couple of their sashimi/nigiri didn't taste fresh. Maybe because I went the day after Christmas.
- Couple of their course was ridiculous. Are you really going to stack two thin slices of Japanese potatoes on top of slice carrot in some weird sauce and count it as one of my course....Another "course" was just lobster broth but no lobster piece..

P.S. I can here on my birthday and was very disappointed with the food especially since it's been on my list of sushi places I want to try for awhile now. 

In the month of December, I also tried Wako in SF and Warikuya in San Mateo. Both were much better and cheaper! These two places deserve their Michelin star..idk about Omasake..still disappointed thinking about the place right now. -.-
author: Linda L.

description: Have to give my boyfriend a shoutout for taking me here for my birthday because he knows how much I love sushi :) Omakase had been on my to-try list but I couldn't justify going to this place without a special occasion because of the price tag. Omakase has two tasting menu options - the Hideaki with 10 pcs nigiri, appetizers and dessert for $150 and the extended Yamato with 2 sashimi, 12 pcs nigiri, appetizers and dessert for $200. We decided to go big or go home and both got the extended omakase which was a decision we didn't regret. Honestly, I have mixed feelings with Omakase. I really enjoyed the fact that I got to try so many new and different fish types I had never tried before and I did think the fish tasted good. Service was also really good. Our chef was pretty friendly and entertaining and volunteered to take a photo of us. They also do this thing where the chefs sign your birthday/anniversary card which is quite possibly one of the cutest handwritten/drawn cards I've ever received (see photo). However, that being said, I thought for the price and the type/quantity of food we received, I would rather revisit a less expensive but still good quality sushi place (ie. Ju-ni or even Wakuriya). It was a good experience and I don't regret having tried Omakase but I probably wouldn't go back any time soon.
author: June Y.

description:
I believe omakase is the number one sushi restaurant in the city. 

Our chef Jason was amazing as well as the rest of staff. 

If you love sushi, you must try this place. If you love sushi you've probably already been here. 

If your scared of sushi but want to try it. Omakase will definitely get you addicted to sushi. 

Attention to detail is key. 

Just take a look at all the photos I took. You'll probably be drooling

Thank you to the team at omakase for an enjoyable evening.
author: Lyman C.

description:
I was pretty excited to try this place out after hearing all the rave reviews. Some friends have told me that it was the best omakase experience of their life! I must have went on an off day or something but I surely felt the opposite. For $300 a pop I felt that Kusakabe and Wako was better. 

We had a reservation at 7.30 on a weekday and when we got there the place was pretty empty. For some reason it took them 20 minutes to seat us, when there was clearly space for us to sit and no one in front of us. Now onto the experience......

The good:
- Everything was beautifully plated. They definitely win big on presentation. It will be hard to resist snapchatting all the dishes.
- Lots and lots of uni. There were maybe 3 dishes with uni.

The bad
- I realized 30 minutes into the meal that only one chef was Japanese (the adorable looking old man) and the other 2 were not. We were served by the youngest looking guy. Not to discriminate but I was hoping, for such a hefty price tag, that my chef would be Japanese. 
- Said chef didn't try to interact with us at all, sometimes he did not even specify what kind of fish we were getting. I thought it was absurd. Normally it wouldn't be too bad but the restaurant was so quiet and it became such an awkward meal. 
- If you can tell from my photos below the uni they served was not fresh. I was really disappointed by this.

With that said, I would recommend Kusakabe or even Wako for a more authentic omakase experience.
author: Caitlin B.

description:
2016 Michelin stars: 1

The service was absolutely fantastic, and felt like a 2 or 3 star Michelin restaurant from that perspective. Every dish was made and presented with care and precision. We went with the larger of the two omakase (Yamamoto?) and then had an additional 5 pieces -- 4 repeats of our favorites from the omakase and one additional that wasn't included in the omakase. Quite a unique experience!
author: Leo I.

description: This restaurant is an absolute must in SF.  I've been here 4-5 times and the quality of food and the service is always unparalleled.  The chef that we have had every time we go is Chef Jackson, and honestly he is the one that makes the dining experience truly enjoyable and fun!  He explains each dish that he prepares and it always amazes me at how intricately he handles his knife.  The waitresses are super attentive and never let your water, tea or sake cup go empty.  Even after going to Japan last month, this restaurant can absolutely compete with the best in Japan.  The bottom line is that the service is excellent, the food is extremely fresh and the chefs know how to give you an amazing dining experience.  Definitely check it out!!  Your taste buds will thank you later!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
For me this place is awesome! I almost go every week 3-4times, chef Jackson yu, Ken, Tora, Sam and Taka are really nice to us, and their staff also take care everytime. In addition they take care customer's food
allergy, and ask everytime. To be honest, when i eat here i felt really comfortable, like home. They brought everyday fresh fish and new menu up to season change. For these reasons, i recommend that this place is the best sushi place in SF.
author: Sung K.

description:
I can summarize this experience in one sentence. We haven't had sushi this good since we visited Japan last year! Quality quality quality. 

We came here yesterday 1/12 to celebrate our anniversary. The service, food, and sake were incomparable. 

We met this server named Char with a C NOT an S who was hilarious and made our experience even more meaningful. If you're reading this Char, we meant to get your contact to hang out! YELP me back! :) 

Best. Sushi. In SF
author: Nathaniel C.

description:
SAY LESS. Omakase definitely ruined all of my future sushi experience. I don't think any place can top this one. The experience as a whole i.e. EVERY dish, chiefs, staff, timing, service, ambiance and price was nothing less than perfect. 
Most memorable dish were the Ankimo, uni chawanmushi, mackerel, toro, A5 wagyu, and Hokkaido uni & ikura... just EVERYTHING. 
You know that feeling where you enjoyed something so much you want to others to enjoy it as well?! That's exactly what me and my boyfriend felt. We watched others who started their courses later than us take bite of every perfection and let me tell you WE CRIED WITH THEM! With every bite, you'll first be in love, then be in awe cause this is the best thing you've ever put in your mouth, then cry cause God's tongue is short lived at that moment. 
So if you want to eat like a goddess, please try Omasake and relish it all in. I walked out feeling like a million bucks: mind, body and soul.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Welcome to "Westerners try to do sushi." I did not enjoy pretty much every aspect of this meal except for the food, which was of good quality (except for the forthcoming bones story). Here are the lowlights:

- The minute we sat down we were offered champagne and shown the price on the menu - very tacky.
- We ordered a few extras like dragonfish, which were presented in an interesting way, but at $50 not worth it and not very tasty of a fish. I also liked how they offered uni as a special add-on, but three of the courses in the regular omakase had uni in it.
- There were bones in my eel that were scratching at my throat as I swallowed. I'm not a stranger to eating whole fish, bones included, but this was unpleasant. I alerted the wait staff and they offered to bring a different cut of the eel, but I was pretty turned off by then. The chef overheard and informed me that "in Japan, they eat the bones." Thaaaaanks. I actually just came back from Japan, and no, they really don't.
- One of the courses was a soup that was just broth. They warned me it may have eel bones in it and gave me a bowl, which was nice of them, but my question is - why don't they run the broth through a sieve? This is a fancy place, not the type of establishment where you might be expected to be spitting out bones.
- We were charged for a beer we ordered but never received.
- All the add-ons are super pricey (eg, $8 green tea).
- Our sushi chef was kind of awkward and not really friendly. At the end of the meal, he didn't ask us how our meal was.
- When we got up to leave, no one came over, so we just grabbed our own coats from the closet. 

Not the best customer service, not a luxury (one-star Michelin) experience, and not a pleasant meal overall. There are plenty of sushi/omakase places in SF that are more authentic and nice.
author: Christina G.

description:
Chef Jackson delivered us an INCREDIBLE meal! I made reservations 2 weeks in advance for a Sunday night 8:30pm reservation and got sat at the bar. We went for the $150 omakase set and we all left impressed and full.

They source their fish from various parts of Japan and do a fantastic job at preserving the freshness. I've been to Tokyo and have eaten quality sushi straight from Tsukiji Market; Omakase paralleled in quality, taste, and presentation. You can tell Chef Jackson and the other chefs care about what they do.

My favorite, was of course, the Toro (tuna belly). So rich and decadent! Chef prepared it 3 ways: sashimi and twice sushi. It was absolutely amazing.

If you want to splurge on a true omakese experience, look no further!
author: Tiff T.

description:
After having tried Kusakabe (which was very good in it's own style), I was excited to try a local Edomae style sushi. My family and I came to Omakase to dine and we were unfortunately very underwhelmed with the whole experience. The servers were great and very knowledgeable, they greeted us and were friendly. Our sushi chef however barely spoke to us, only giving us the name of the each piece with no detail in between. There was a point where we sat around for 10-15 minutes unsure whether the omakase was over or not/what was going on. The main chef seemed to be much more friendly as he excitedly talked to other patrons in Chinese and displayed some cool ways he prepared the food. 

I tend to gauge restaurants by how my mother (a tiny opinionated japanese woman) reacts to them. She absolutely loved Kusakabe, but was very whatever about Omakase. Everything included the soups and her hot tea came out luke warm, and she was appalled that the tea was $8!

I first had Edomae style sushi in Los Angeles at Q with Chef Hiro. Before eating at Q I wasn't much of a sushi person other than Tuna, but that experience completely changed my palate and I was amazed as to how delicious and unique each type of fish was. While the fish at Omakase was fresh and of high quality I'm sure, nothing stood out or was mind blowing.
author: Saya Y.

description:
What more can I say that hasn't already been noted here.
Service was amazing and the fish was definitely on point!

From the time we were greeted at the door, walked to our seats and introduced to our chef we oddly felt at home. 
Everything was amazing! The Hokkaido uni melted in my mouth. I had fish that I normally thought were fishy (iwashi japanese sardines etc) tasted like it jumped out of the ocean and onto my plate.
Dinner was a splurge but worth every penny ;)
author: Liz N.

description:
Great omakase experience with artistically prepared food and a fun staff who didn't take themselves too seriously. We had Chef Sam who was so funny and a little bit goofy. You can tell that the staff is like a little family with a lot of good-hearted teasing. With that said, the staff was very professional and introduced each dish to us beforehand and provided tips for eating, if needed.

Omakase offers two preset menus:
1. Hideaki Omakase for $150 (excluding drinks, tax, and tip)
Two Appetizers
One Sashimi
Ten pieces Nigiri
One Owan
 
2. Yamato Omakase for $200 (excluding drinks, tax, and tip)
Two Appetizers
Two Sashimi
One Yakimono
Twelve pieces Nigiri
One Owan

We did the Hideaki Omakase and found that it was more than enough food. The couple next to us got Yamato Omakase and had some pretty nice additional dishes (more nigiri including wagyu, a sashimi plate, lobster). Either way, this is not one of those omakase places where you'll leave needing to eat another meal.

What we had:
- Monkfish liver- so tender, it reminded me of uni
- Japanese eggplant with baby anchovies
- Steamed lobster with cucumber
- Bluefin tuna and slapjack sashimi
- Japanese cooked fish with ponzu sauce

Nigiri Course
- Goldeneye snapper
- Striped jack fish
- Mackerel
- Toro
- Japanese flounder
- Barracuda
- Amberjack
- Uni
- Torched toro
- Unagi

- Egg cake with lobster and mountain yam, sugared and bruleed on top
- Lobster agedashi with miso soup
- Matcha green tea jelly with condensed milk, brown sugar, and sesame powder

Of course, the nigiri course was the highlight. Each piece was prepared differently (both from each other and from other restaurants). Depending on the item, each piece was specifically enhanced (truffle salt, seared with a blow torch, scored across the fish) and then lightly brushed with soy sauce. This allowed for a perfectly balanced and portioned bite for you to take with your hand and put in your mouth. The blow torched pieces had a really nice and unique smoky component. My personal favorite was the goldeneye snapper, but the most visually indulgent was the torched toro where the chef separated some of the fat off of the toro, put the fat back on top of the toro and then torched it, resulting in toro torched in its own fat. O_O

It's amazing to watch chefs prep and prepare right before your eyes. You get to see the precision and delicacy that goes into making each piece of nigiri. Plus, most if not all of their fish gets flown in from the Tsukiji fish market. Omakase is also very generous with extra surprises, like the dessert and a complimentary taster of sake. Chef Sam also hooked us up with the leftover egg cake.

There are two seatings each evening: 5:30pm and 8:30pm with about 16+ seats each. All of the seats are along the bar, except for the 2 tables on the side. If possible, it's probably best to see if you can request the seats at the bar so you can watch the chefs and talk to them. Reservations available online, but beware of the $100 cancellation fee. Location is in the design district in SOMA. Plenty of street parking on weekend nights, since the area is pretty dead around that time.
author: Alice T.

description:
This was the best sushi eating experience of my life...I'm not exaggerating...seriously. 

I went here on a Monday for a friends birthday and we went all out.  We got the $200 Omakase with the $80 sake pairing (yes, that's per person). It's the most I've ever spent on a single meal in my life and probably won't do it again for a long time but it was absolutely amazing. 

The service was impeccable from the hostess to the servers to the sushi chef himself. We basically had our own sushi chef making us course after course after course. We didn't take any picture to preserve the moment and I would encourage you to do the same. The menu changes based on seasonality and freshness of the day so I won't go into great detail about the courses as I assume they will change fairly often. 

The sake pairing was six amazing pours. All of them delicious and different in flavor profiles that matched well with the courses being eaten. I'm not a sake expert by any means but these made me want to be. 

The one dish I have to mention was the cold smoked yellowtail. I've eaten a Shamu worth of it in my life but nothing as wonderful as this. The smokey flavor permeated the fish in the most delicate and wonderful way. Absolutely mind blowing. 

I would give this place a thousand stars if Yelp would let me.
author: Scott M.

description:
We have been here a couple of times.  It's truly an enjoyment of food and art.  Chef/Owner Jackson Yu is highly trained and skillful.  Come at the nights when he's working!  He's also very entertaining.  I was laughing the whole time. 

They are very generous with their top quality fish.  My mouth is watering as I'm thinking about what we ate last night.
author: Danielle W.

description: What a fantastic, amazing, words can't describe meal! Chef Jackson Yu and his team make you feel like you've been transported back to Japan. Every course is expertly executed.  Thank you, and we'll be back again.
author: Richard K.

description:
I was here for dinner with a friend on a weeknight during their 2nd seating at 8:30pm. I had heard a lot about this restaurant, especially with their one Michelin star rating. Afterwards though, I felt it was overhyped and did not live up to expectations.

The entire restaurant only seats 18 people, but not all seating is at the sushi bar, which is definitely a better experience. Service was exceptional.

My friend and I did the $150 option with $80 sake pairing. All the fish and ingredients were extremely fresh and of the highest quality - the chefs were happy to talk about how they source their ingredients from Japan if you ask. However, the courses were largely unimaginative (-1 star). Two of the slightly more interesting ones were lobster tamago and mango sorbet in sake. 

As there are so many other great sushi options in SF, I would definitely pick Kusakabe or Akiko's, both exceptional and more exciting, over Omakase in the future.
author: Tiffany P.

description: Great place, decent food. Only thing is cannot order food, can only chose set menus.
author: Cathy C.

description: Loved every moment while we were here! Made a reservation through open table at the beginning of the month. There were only two option which is 6pm or 8:30pm because the meal last 2 hours long. Parking was super easy here because its in Townsend and there were loads of street meter. But you don't have to pay after 6pm. Customer service was excellent here they made us feel very comfortable since it was our first time. From the uni to the wagyu. We went out big and chose the $200 price fix meal since it was my boyfriends birthday. Our chef Sam was very friendly and bubbly his personality. Bill Total was $450 for two people without tips included. Would love to come back again. P.s the place was really small. There were only 18 seats and two small table. Prepare for the amazing dinner and food!!! Thank you omakase for making this night so memorable for me and my boyfriend.
author: Tina C.

description:
Not even sure where to begin, but if you want to eat some of the freshest and high quality fish sourced directly from Tsukiji fish market in Japan, then definitely come here. The chefs are super friendly and have a great sense of humor. 

My sister and I went with the $150 set meal, which was so worth it. We got so much fish & seafood! There was lobster, salmon, yellowtail, grouper, halibut, scallop, shrimp, tuna (different cuts), mackerel, uni and more types of fish I can't remember. Bottom line is you won't be disappointed with the generous amount of seafood they serve. The menu changes weekly based on the best quality fish they can source.

Service was incredible and very attentive. I'm not surprised at all that they received a Michelin star so quickly. I selfishly hope that the bookings don't get too crazy as they've gained a lot more popularity since earning the award. :) definitely looking forward to coming back soon!
author: Sophia H.

description: This is where you go to ball out and get guaranteed, excellent quality service and high end sushi
author: Ingrid R.

description:
As a new Michelin star Japanese Restaurant, I would like to say Omakase has a faith of Japanese traditional food  style, Edomae‑style. They provide fish from Tokyo's Tsukiji Fish Market. The chefs are knowledge of tons of fish, and if luck, will see how they cut the cucumber and have a change to see many different fish.
Not as other restaurant, Omakase's chef will love to speak with you and share details of each dishes, so the environment not really quiet but friendly.
author: Faye L.

description:
My bf and I are huge sushi enthusiasts and we been making our way through all the omakase restaurants in sf. This one actually ranks somewhere in our top 5, not the best but not the worse. Actually there isn't anything bad with this place, it's just with the new places such as ijji and ju-ni out there , they are giving omakase a run for its money!

We went with the $99 option and ordered a few a la carte at the end. It came with about 10 pieces of nigiri and each one was delicious... Love the cherry salmon! I think that every place we go they have had it on their menu as a seasonal item, so tasty! The uni, chu toro, mackerel, Saba and other dishes were delicious as well. I would say the best a la carte pieces were the wagyu and o-toro! Love me some quality fish!

Overall, there isn't much else to say about this place. They definitely do deserve that Michelin star, it lives up to the reputation of fresh fish. I also liked that they used minimal sauces and you could really taste the flavors! 

Definitely would come back here again in the future for a special occasion! 

Total for 2: $ 400
author: Stella J.

description: No need to say a lot. I'm not for omakase only because if there's something I don't like I got no choice and with that being said I've ate at many great sushi bars from here to japan. This is one of them. From the uni to chu-toro to A5 Wagyu. Everything was excellent. Beware: this is a very expensive place to eat. The premium is $200 a person. This is NOT the place for a person who orders philidelphia rolls.
author: Ben B.

description: Omakase was a truly life-altering treat. I ent with a friend and had the big meal with sake pairings -- everything was immaculate, service was impeccable, and every single bite was a magical journey to deliciousness. I honestly can't tell you my favorite item, as everything was spectacular. I will say the first 3 sakes were definitely at the top of my list, and I can't wait to return again.
author: SisterMable S.

description: Not the best omakase I've had but definitely the most expensive one. For the person who asked if it was $150 per person the answer is yes. They only offer 2 set omakase. A $150 one and a $200 one. The difference is in two additional courses. The service is exquisite tho. Excellent service provided by the entire staff. The restaurant is small and can seat about 20 people. Make reservations ahead of time and ensure you can attend as they charge $100 cancellation fee if less than 48hrs. It's very casual so no need to dress up.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Been meaning to write an update review but been traveling the past last month. I had the opportunity to try Omakase again and I'm glad I did. I actually came here 2 consecutive nights here! Service was great and Chef Jackson was serving us. I asked for less wasabi and he was able to accommodate. Appreciate that he remembered the next night to put less! It was actually his birthday the 2nd night I came here and helped him celebrate, unfortunately he had to work. lol Very personable and easy to talk to. 

There's an option of $150 or $200 Omakase. We both ordered the $150 Hideaki Omakase (2 appetizer, 1 sashimi, 10 pcs Nigiri and 1 owan). They offer complimentary champagne/sake when you first arrive. Sake tasting was well worth as they served a good amount of different kind of sake. Fish was very fresh and enjoyed it! Dessert was surpringsly good combo! It was a fruit sorbet with sake at the bottom of the cup. 

Highly recommend to ask for bar seating because you get the full experience. You're able to talk to Chefs and watch them at work! Give this place a try! It's also a 1 Michelin star! They also have a sister restaurant next door as well as another option. Make your reservations early!

One thing I would appreciate is to have a list of what is being served. The Chef will tell you what fish it is and where it's from but always nice to see it so you can always refer back to it! :)
author: Sherry Y.

description:
Amazing Omakase experience.  Fish is so fresh it melts in your mouth.  Huge variety of unique Japanese fish, Chefs are fun and creative.  Overall and amazing experience.

Definitely worth checking out!
author: Christina Z.

description:
We went through over 22 dishes in our Yamato Omakase and every dish was just amazing. There was only one nigiri that didn't amaze me but also didn't underwhelm me. Therefore, this place is a hands down delicious meal. One of the best sushi places I've been to in the Bay Area. 

You arrive with coat check and a complementary glass of champagne. The omakase options are very simple. Theres not too much worry about here. Just pick one and enjoy the ride. 

Make sure you make reservations as this place really does fill up. I would not try going in as a walk in.
author: Marlene T.

description: After my trip in Japan, I've been on this sushi eating spree with my boyfriend. We've been looking for some quality grade sushi and decided to book a reservation for Omakase. It's expensive especially for not having any alcohol pairing for over $200 per person. We did get this cup of palate opening sake they presented to us, but it wasn't anything remarkable. The most spectacular course was the uni special that we ordered. It was huge and beautifully presented, and it tasted as good as it looked. Overall, I felt that the food was good, but the presentation was what really captured my attention. That, and watching the head chef skillfully create the dishes. I just couldn't justify the amount we paid. To be honest, I've been to Kusakabe and I felt that the two were comparable despite their different approaches. Definitely a fun experience though.
author: Trang T.

description: My favorite Michelin star restaurant in San Francisco, Jackson was very friendly and hilarious!    I went there twice a week with my friends and we absolutely love it!!
author: Riley Z.

description:
Omakase was a memorable experience and everything after dinner was a blur after 2 big bottles of sake that went down too smooth. 

We order the premium menu for $200 a person which came with wagyu and lobster which the $150 menu lacked. I wish I took notes on how each dish tasted but everything was extremely refined, fresh, well executed/presented, and the flavors were on point. I appreciated the variety that was offer and my favorites were the truffle flavored fish, uni, and the wagyu. 

We also added the dragon fish which came in the most remarkable presentation. It was fresh and delicious and I loved how they used the bones and extra parts from the fish to make a broth which we enjoyed later. 

By the end of the meal I was stuffed and extremely buzzed. The customer service was impeccable. My only complaint is I wish we sat at the chef's counter for the full experience but we lucked out on last minutes reservations.
author: Jeanne L.

description: Flavor pairing of the sauces and garnishes for the nigiris were quite good. Quality was very fresh. The uni nigiri, however, was a bit too heavy on the sauce which drowned out the natural flavor of the uni.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Chef Jackson!!! 
So their menu changes about every week, but these guys will always give you a good meal. 
They freaking grate their wasabi here fresh right infront of you. 
The seared chutoro melted in my mouth and the yaki black cod at the end of the meal omg these guys know how to serve you fish. 
The white shrimp is pretty bomb too. They make each nigiri fresh for you and you eat it right then and there while they're slicing the next one. 
And what a surprise with my miso soup when i found a nugget of lobster waiting for me at the bottom. 
Complementary sake. 
Very nice for a date night or if you want to have some high quality sushi.
author: Tatiana T.

description:
The most touching dinner I've had! During the reservation, the staff will inquire whether you are celebrating something--if you are, they will give you some mementos to celebrate with you. Really, really thoughtful.

Chefs and staff were amazing from beginning to end.

Perfect escalation of dishes. Light flavors to start and then a amazing set of fresh fish nigiri. There are two omakase options, and we had opted for the larger ensemble for $200 :) There are also a la carte options at the end, but the Yamato omakase was definitely enough for me. I did order one Akamutsu afterwards since it was seasonal and rare. That, along with the giant clam &a lobster sashimi, jackfish, ocean trout, and uni were my highlights although the entire meal was ABSOLUTELY delicious! The fish were so fresh and even a light garnish accentuated their natural flavors.

Finished with two sweets, a lobster tamago cake and a sweet savory mochi burst. Amazing! I was so happy.

100% would go again for any occassion.
author: Kathy Z.

description:
Wow wow wow! Omakase - the way it is done. I have had omakase before but never like this. Expensive, sure but worth it after your visit. First - check out their web site. That will whet your appetite. Then find a great companion and go!!

I was treated to dinner here by a good friend and the experience I had can only be summed up as sensational. Freshest seafood I have ever tasted. Everything they described on their web site is accurate.  The settings, ambience, colors, taste! All true. 

We ordered the supreme set and dishes kept coming and coming. Nigiri was served two at a time.  Each pair was  described by the server who patiently waited till we finished our conversation. Every bite was fresh, delicious and well balanced. From the start to the end (sorbet over sake!) 

If you can save enough for an unforgettable meal, this is it!
author: Khiang S.

description:
i don't know

i love taka

good luck to him

the food was "very good"

my favorite was the smoked blue fin, something like that 

that's it
author: Stephen C.

description:
Complimentary pour of Krug to go with my sake? Why not?

As the restaurant name suggests, this is an omakase only establishment. If you don't know what that is, then I suggest you go elsewhere for your stupid rainbow and caterpillar rolls.

Veronica S. and I both chose the $150 omakase menu. Pricey, but the fish was high quality, as were the cooked dishes. Two appetizers, a sashimi and yakimono course, 12 pieces of nigiri and an owan dish later, I have to admit that I wasn't as full as I would have liked to be (maybe I am pregnant?). I also wasn't a big fan of the tamago, which was extremely eggy instead of the sweet sponge cake-like preparation that I prefer.  

There is ample street parking in this neighborhood, which is a huge plus. Just roll up, walk in and stuff your fat face.
author: Suany W.

description:
My first omakase experience and one of my favorite meals ever! 

My boyfriend brought me here for my birthday and from the moment we walked in the doors, I felt so welcome and cared for. As the restaurant knew we were celebrating a birthday, they had left a welcome card with a personalized birthday greeting, which the chef's ended up leaving a note on towards the end of the meal as a keepsake. The chef we were seated with, Ingi, had a pleasant and calm demeanor and suited our dining style very well. The other sushi chef Jackson, serving the girls next to us, was definitely more silly and outgoing. Together, they were a very entertaining pair. If you are making a reservation, I would recommend requesting bar seating.

Since it was our first omakase experience, we decided to go all out for the Yamato Omakase, which came with 2 appetizers, 2 sashimi, 1 grilled dish, 12 pieces of nigiri, and 1 dessert. Compared to the other $150 menu option, this one came with 1 extra sashimi dish, 1 grilled dish, and 2 extra pieces of nigiri. Absolutely no regrets - we loved every moment! 

One of our favorite dishes was the clam and lobster tail sashimi (beautifully presented too!) at the start of the meal. Among the nigiri, our favorites were the toro (plain and also seared), the ocean trout, hokkaido sea scallop, and the hokkaido unni with ikura. It was such a treat watching Ingi prepare each piece with such care and precision; from the sushi rice to the sauces and the garnishes, everything was done to perfection. The wagyu beef dish with the various dipping spices and truffle sauce was melt-in-your-mouth delicious and I only wish we had more! At the end of the meal, they had added a candle with dessert and also provided a beautiful small orchid bundle. Throughout the meal, the wait staff was cleaning the table surfaces between courses, re-folding our napkins when we would get up, and always refilling our beverages. They even offered to take our picture behind the sushi bar before preparing for their next service. The combination of hospitality and delicious food made for an awesome birthday meal! Will definitely be coming back to celebrate more occasions!
author: Sarah N.

description:
If you ever have the opportunity to go here, I highly urge you to take it. 

The staff takes such good care of you- the service is absolutely incredible. This was hands down my best dining experience. 

Seating is comfortable and intimate.

But the food... the food... I might've died briefly, not sure. I think I died and went to heaven for a few hours. 

I recommend the uni- they have it live and prepare it in front of you. It's beautiful, really. They make it so gorgeous that you don't want to eat it, but when you do... wow. I've always ordered uni, but I've never tasted it like this. I felt like I was in the ocean. This may sound exaggerated, but I assure you it is not.

Along with the omakase, we added the sake pairing, which made the experience even more enjoyable. They explain where the sake is from, what type, what year, and pour it for you. It truly added to the dishes. 

Omakase- home to the best meal of my life.

I will never have a meal as good as the one I had here
author: Yve N.

description: Wow wow wow!!!!!! This is by far the best Omakase ever!!! The quality of the service and food exceeded my expectation! Everything is beautiful and tasty. Definitely is 5-star without a doubt !!!
author: Ruby C.

description:
Omakase has changed the way I see and experience sushi, in all the best ways. The experience was so much more than just eating, it was a show. I appreciated the thought that was put into each presentation right down to the tableware. It was all so beautiful. 

As soon as I entered Omakase with my boyfriend, I felt as if I had left SF behind and was transported to Japan. I love the decor. Although we were seated at a table and not at the bar, I did not feel that I missed the experience of watching each piece being prepared. The restaurant is small (18 people total) so I was able to see and hear the chefs. I found each staff member quite personable; it was easy to talk and joke with them. 

I had the Hideaki Omakase with a carafe of Akitabare Suirakuten while my boyfriend had the Yamato Omakase ($200) with the sake pairing. We began our meal with uni, which I highly recommend. Each slice of uni melted in my mouth. From the appetizer to dessert, I found the entire meal to be quite enjoyable and amazing.
author: Katie C.

description: This was one of the best meals I've ever had. I came with my husband and two friends for a friend's bday.  We had Chef Jackson as our chef. He was so friendly, informative, and most of all fun! The food was delicious, my favorite being the 4 types of toro that he served. Everything was amazing from the presentation, to the service, to the food. I mean the type of meal where when you try eat a bite, you have to close your eyes because it's THAT unbelievably good. It's on the pricier side at $200/pp omakase and about $100/bottle of sake but honestly I felt like the quality and service lived up to the hype. Everyone we ate with agreed it was one of the best dinners we've ever had...and I've dined at 3 Michelin star Benu and thought this was better.  Definitely a fun dinner to be remembered, can't wait to go back! Thanks again Chef Jackson!
author: Diana L.

description:
I'm all about omakase! (Or any tasting menu in general. I love trying a little bit of everything!) When a girlfriend told me there was a new restaurant called Omakase, I decided we had to go. We had dinner on Tuesday, June 23 at 6:30pm. I made a reservation for two a couple days prior as they only have bar seating. I believe there are about 14 seats?

The meal started off with a glass of complimentary krug which was a nice way to start off the evening. I wasn't sure which sake I wanted, so I asked the sushi chef for his recommendation. I told him I loved dry crisp sakes. The Dewazakura "Izumi judan" was perfect! Definitely recommend for anyone who likes their sake dry.

Their menu consists of three omakase options: $100, $150, $200. We were debating between all the three options, but eventually decided on the $150 option as it came with sashimi. It came with: 2 appetizers, 1 sashimi (3 kinds), 12 pieces nigiri, 1 maki, 1 owan.

*Appetizers: Lobster and snow crab with sea grapes & Saba with fresh ginger, Uni fish cake
*Sashimi: Live octopus, Copper river king salmon, Black sea bream
*Nigiri: Blue fin tuna, Spanish mackerel, Shimaaji, Isaki, Saba - Japanese mackerel, Butterfish, Hamo - sea eel, Sea robin, Copper river salmon with gold leaf and osetra caviar, Kohada, Mirugai, Kinmedai, Toro, Anago
*Yakomono: Sea bass with English pea puree
*Ankimo
*Uni from Hokkaido, Japan
*Tamago
*Maki: Negitoro
*Owan: Asari akadashi

Omg, yum! Everything was delicious and perfectly paced. I especially loved the appetizers, ankimo and uni from Hokkaido. Each piece of nigiri was super fresh and wonderfully executed. I was seriously in sushi heaven! My favorite of course being the toro. Just melted in my mouth.

By the end of the meal I was stuffed! You really get your money's worth with their menus. There was so much food! I rarely go to restaurants numerous times, but I'm such a fan of Omakase, I'm already planning another meal. After dinner, my girlfriend said they definitely lived up to their name. Can't think of a better way to describe our experience!
author: Elena N.

description:
Definitely a great experience - every course was delicately prepared.  I suggest getting the Wagu at the end - delicious.  

The service was spot on - there are only 10 seats at the bar (which makes up most of the restaurant) so it is a very intimate affair.  Pulling the pocket door to get in reminded me of being in Tokyo.
author: Frank G.

description:
Best sushi spot in the city! The food, ambience, service, and most importantly the experience is everything I want and would expect from a Michelin star restaurant.  We had Chef Jackson who is a true professional and master at what he does. From his knife work, to him explaining to us what we were eating, he always made sure everyone was having a great time.  I have been here a couple of times and it continues to get better each time.  The courses are very well thought out and delivered. They have some of the freshest fish you can find in SF and your palate is in for an awesome ride. The toro and seared wagyu is simply AMAZING.  You will not be disappointed eating here.  

Some additional comments for those visiting:

Parking here is a breeze. Tons of free metered parking (after 6pm) making it hassle free. Always get a spot right in front!

My glass (water, tea, sake) would never go empty. The waitresses are super attentive and very helpful. 

The green tea is to die for. Compliments the meal very nicely and doesn't have that bitter finish.

Not necessarily your typical uptight omakase style restaurant.  They want you to enjoy the full experience and have a great time (sake always helps with that)
author: Matthew C.

description:
Its an experience!  You are paying for the experience and the story of eating here.  
We had an amazing time.   But we are reviewing food.  Now that omakase is a household word (although completely misused!) EVERYONE is doing it.  And it seems the model right now is to create an elevated "authentic" experience (Ijji, Hinata, Ju-ni, etc).

Here's why you come here.  

- Important business dinner with the requisite expense account
- You want to impress a hot (gold digging) date
- You want an experience where you are treated like the most important people to the chef and restaurant at that moment (i.e. special occasion).
- You just got your tax refund and you want an experience!
- You won the lottery 


So why 3 stars?  I've had better "omakase" for less in the city.  The service, overall experience, and atmosphere were not nearly as detailed or intimate but I came for the food.

Don't let the three stars stop you from coming here especially if you want to impress and delight.  But if you are looking for Jiro level sushi (cause this is getting close to his price point) maybe look around.
author: Spanky M.

description:
Not the most original name.  But it's a great addition to the edomae sushi scene in SF.  

LOVE:
*Chef asks after the first piece of nigiri if he can adjust the wasabi, soy and rice.  WOW.  No ego here.  So individualized.  Yes thanks for recognizing customers have personal preferences.  We opted for a tad more wasabi.  
*glass of KRUG for all levels of omakase.  Nice touch.
*perfect rice
*complimentary sea cucumber, so chewy, but oddly good, perfectly marinated
*GREAT appetizers, the salad, squid ink tofu, anago foie, amazing! 
*lots of torching action here, but very light handed
*first time having fresh, hydrated uni, just melts!
*best of the night: shimaaji, toro, kohada, ebodai
*best tamago to date, super moist and not too sweet
*thanks for introducing me to housemade, preservative free ginger, very savory, as in salty, still prefer the vinegar variety
*a box is provided for handbags, rare in SF

Chefs are from Maruya and owner/chef heads Live Sushi's in SF.

Still some room to grow, not many pieces made me squeal in delight.  But a very clean meal.  My mouth still tasted like the ocean hours later. Wonderful warm staff and the 3rd tier omakase is a very generous amount of food.  Next time I would request for less shellfish and more fish.  About 1/4 of the meal consisted of shrimp, clam and scallop.  Honestly I prefer fish.  Not sure if dessert is available but it's not part of the omakase. Plenty of parking on the block, love eating in SOMA.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I'm a huge fan of omakase-style sushi. You never have to worry about ordering because you know you're getting the best the chef has to offer.

First off, at Omakase, you're paying for not only the fish but also the ambiance. Each reservation-only seating seats about 10 people in all. The overall style reminded me of an authentic, upscale sushi bar in Tokyo. For a fixed price of $100 (which is the basic omakase), you get a complimentary pour of brut, an appetizer (lobster salad), a soup (miso lobster), and ten pieces of sushi.

On to the fish! Every piece was good to great. A couple standouts were the ahi horse mackerel and toro fatty tuna. My only critique is that the wasabi in my pieces were too generous. I normally do enjoy my sushi with wasabi but there were a couple times where the kick hit me a little too hard.

A couple unique pointers for first timers:
1) You're served each course one at a time
2) You eat with your hands
