3) The last course is the tamago omelette (aka sit around and revel in your omakase experience for a bit but know that it's time to go home)

Overall, it was a very good meal and the high price point was appropriate. Both the food and service were exceptional.
author: Charles L.

description: I've been extremely fortunate and blessed by the sushi gods for this $200 omakase course and I was stuffed stuffed to the brim. Spectacular service, Chef Sam was amazing and such a sweetheart. The fish was definitely high-quality and extremely fresh. A few nigiri pieces were served with truffle oil, which is pretty amazing. Can one be overwhelmed by too many nigiri pieces coated with truffle oil? Me thinks not! The cooked dishes were decent and one of my nigiri pieces crumbled in my hands which made for a nanosecond of sad Denise, but hey, it happens..right? I think the best part is that the chefs are equipped to serve whenever each party gets seated. The overall experience was great but I'm not sure if I would ever splurge on the $200 menu on my own dime. A girl has got to learn to budget sometime in her life!
author: Denise L.

description:
I promised a new review after we were provided the opportunity to retry Omakase and the difference was night and day. The food was delicious as was all of the different sake that we tried but what truly made the experience was the service we received. From the beginning each and every person we interacted with went out of their way to make the experience incredible.  Char/Charmaine (apologize if I spelled it wrong) was a joy to have as a server and she balanced the perfect level of interaction without being overbearing at all. Chef Jackson is not only a talented chef but was also incredibly thoughtful remembering the specific dishes that we did not like from last time and adapting them in a way that we might enjoy. 

The atmosphere was lively and fun! The one recommendation I would make when booking is that if you can request to be in the long section of the sushi bar it seems like the experience is the best there. We did the entire $200 tasting menu and had no trouble getting through the entire thing and enjoying every last bit. It was such a fun experience that we ended up hanging out and drinking through half of the second seating. Jean from the Omakase restaurant group was also present and went out of her way to provide a hand made flower arrangement for my wife. 

Thank you to everybody who made this experience special and we will definitely be coming back!
author: Howard C.

description:
If you're going to splurge, this is the place to do it. Outstandingly fresh, delicious fish. Go for the Yamato Omakase menu. It's a good amount of dishes not overwhelming. 

One note, they don't have a wine pairing and wine by the bottle start around $75.
author: James Y.

description: Anybody writing a 5 stars review of this place doesn't know real omakase. This place is D- and i would not recommend it to anybody serious about Japanese food.
author: Sylvio D.

description: Overall a wonderful omakase experience. The seafood is super fresh, but I'd say the non-sushi dishes are more interesting. The nigiri are fine, but they seem to use the same yuzu/soy sauce, and after 10 or so, all the fish start tasting the same! I'm comparing this to an omakase place in NYC where they had slightly different sauces for different nigiri; The total was more than the sum of its parts and I still think of it from time to time! Anyway, I still give this place 5 stars because the food was very good and service attentive. I'm just nit-picking because I feel like this place can be so much more!
author: Puay K.

description:
This is the first time I've ever seen pre-cut fish for my nigiri. Is this normal? The pieces were all cut and placed in a box. The only other time I've seen it is when Safeway/Whole Foods are building their togo sushi boxes. I've been to Yume, Sushi Dai, Kusakabe, Wako and I've never seen such a thing.

The food was enjoyable and some pieces were delicious/memorable. The wagyu nigiri was not as good as Kusakabe's. One nigiri piece was a little chewy (from the tendons). There was one cooked fish dish that didn't have much flavor. Overall, I was full from the $200 option, but having experienced other omakases, I would simply say that my money can go further elsewhere. 

Is it a $200 meal? No, maybe $140. It was a good meal, but not $200 good. I hope they adjust their pricing to better compete or up their game at this price. Service was excellent.
author: Shaun B.

description:
A new place that opened in recent weeks and a place that will blow your mind. The setting from top to bottom that includes everything from the special Japanese made tin that's used to serve their extensive sake list, to the wooden cups and wooden cup chiller, to the artful porcelain plate that's used to place your sushi on...is all from Japan. 

Sushi Chef Jackson is one person you'll want to have standing there behind the bar  when you make your dinner reservations. His skill level, knowledge and personality separates him from many chefs. He will delight your palate and you will walk away feeling that you just walked out of a very special place in Tokyo. 

I highly recommend this place but you'll need to make reservations well in advance. There's only 14 seats and they have 2 seatings per night. 

Yes it's that kind of place.
author: Ivan H.

description:
WOW!

I have had Omakase bookmarked for the longest time but could never get seats since I am so last minute when planning events. This restaurant definitely deserves that Michelin Star and is probably why they are always booked. 

Right when I stepped foot inside I was amazed at the beautiful decor and soft lighting. I sat down and was pleasantly surprised to see a personalized Happy Birthday card from Omakase. This personal touch is a plus. 

Now lets get to the food. We ordered the $200 Omakase selection and it was definitely worth every penny. We usually need to order extra a la carte after the omakase is over and the bill will run you $500 or so per person. Each dish not only tasted so fresh and delicious but looked like beautiful intricate art work. We were so lucky to have the famous Jackson as our sushi chef. He was very entertaining and highly knowledgeable in all of the fish selections - his humor added to the already perfect dinner. This is the ultimate dining experience in all aspects! I love how all of the fish is fresh and flown in from Japan's famous Tsukiji fish market. Each piece just melts in your mouth and is perfectly seasoned, even the sushi rice is perfect. People may not notice but something as simple as the sushi rice can greatly impact your sushi experience. 

I am a serious sushi snob and not easy to please. I started my review with "WOW" and that says a lot. 
I will be returning again very soon! What a great birthday dinner!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
As an annual tradition, I like to spoil my girlfriend to a nice pre-fixe for her birthday each year. We both started getting into eating sashimi and nigiri the past couple months so I wanted to surprise her with an omakase. Three weeks before memorial weekend, I scrambled looking for an omakase that would still take reservations. Akiko and Kusakabe were unsurprisingly booked so I went with Omakase thinking hey it couldn't be that bad, and it has a michelin star. 

Chef Jackson, the owner, gave us the best experience we had with fine dining. At many other fine dining, the meal is generally quite intimate and you're given all these exotic ingredients prepared in certain ways that require me to constantly google half the words! Dining at Omakase was definitely still intimate, but was a lot less laborious. In the 14 seat bar plus a couple tables, we luckily sat in front of Chef Jackson(make sure to request the same!). Whenever we had any questions about the food, he patiently taught us about the fish we were eating and why it was different from others. I even felt comfortable asking him if it was okay for me to eat the nigiri in two bits- it's not. 

The highlights of the meal were definitely the striped jack fish and the jack mackerel. The former was wonderfully fatty and flavorful, moreso than high end yellowtail hence the higher premium you pay. The jack mackerel had an interesting softness to it while still retaining a slight chew and buttery flavor. I didn't care as much for the wild king salmon which had a slightly sticky texture to it. Some of the nigiri were overwhelmed by the fresh wasabi or else maybe it's my palate unable to understand why there needed to be that much wasabi. I should have asked Chef Jackson, that's how easy it is to talk to him.

If you would like to learn more about the food you pay big bucks for, enjoy a delicious meal, as well as have a great time, make a reservation at Omakase.
author: joda l.

description:
The boyfriend and I decided to celebrate his birthday here after trying Shiro's in Seattle. 

We both got the Hideaki Omakase ($150/person. This comes with 2 appetizers, 1 sashimi, 10 nigiris, and 1 owan. It doesn't sound like a lot, but we were both stuffed at the end of dinner. BTW, you can order extras at the end in case you're still hungry.

The ambiance of the restaurant is very peaceful and romantic. You won't find people having loud conversations. Plus most guests are couples (at least that's what it seemed like when we dined there). The restaurant is very dimly lit and decorated simply. There are 16 seats around the bar and 2 side tables for 2 people each. Honestly, I originally wanted to sit at one of the tables as I felt that it would be more private. My boyfriend convinced me to sit at the bar and I was glad. Watching the chefs prepare the meals was mesmerizing. How do they cut those fish so smoothly and evenly?! And the fire!! Well, torch. If you dine here, I definitely recommend sitting at the bar and holding a conversation with the chefs. They're pretty funny!

Now to the meal. Eating the sashimis and nigiris here has spoiled my taste buds. I don't think I can order those at regular Japanese restaurants. Specialty rolls here I come! The fish looked and tasted super fresh. They're flown in from Japan! O.O Each of your meal will be delicious and served beautifully. Definitely a must try if you haven't been. 

The customer service is amazing. The servers refilled my tea and always asked my boyfriend if he wanted more beer before I even realized that my cup was empty. They seemed very knowledgeable of everything served at the restaurant and were very friendly. No complaints from me & im a stickler for good customer service! 

Also, if you're celebrating an event and you let them know, you get a card wishing you a happy birthday or anniversary, which is signed by all 3 of the chefs at the end of your meal.
author: Trina V.

description:
Amazing experience, very thing was perfect. Food is amazing! Fresh and delicious.
Chefs are also nice and take care about you to make you feel special.
To try!
author: Olivier H.

description:
Why 2 star? This is based on their communication and customer service. I reserved 1 week prior and requested for a seat at the bar. At first, I received a text message 2 days prior for confirmation on table seating. The staff did their best to accomodate but it was for a day that I would be returning home. I responded and requested to cancel as it was still more than 48hrs until I can cancel without penalty charge of $100 per person (you have 48hrs to cancel without penalty charge). I have not heard back regarding cancellation confirmation despite my text asking if the cancellation is confirmed. It's as if they don't care as long as they themselves are aware. I just don't want to be charged penalty without being notified, despite cancelling more than 48hrs prior to my reservation

Will make an update with my dining experience in the future.
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
Omakase opened up in 2015 or so, as a new Sushi only, prix fixe type tasting menu restaurant. 

Interestingly enough, 2015 was the year that this concept really took hold in the San Francisco area, because 3 other similar restaurants opened roughly that year, with the same concept: Wako on 2nd and Clement, Kusakabe on Washington near the Transamerica Building, and in San Mateo on 3rd street, Sushi Yoshizumi. Later in October 2015, when the Michelin guide came out with their Michelin Stars, all 3 received 1 Michelin Star. And as a result, I believe they have all raised their prices, and are harder to get reservations. The latest restaurant in the genre is Ju-Ni, opened in 2016. (Ju-Ni means 12, for the number of seats at the sushi bar.) Let's wait till October to see if Michelin adds them to the guide. 

Omakase started out with 3 set meals, at $100, $150 and $200. They have since dispensed with the low end, and when I went months ago, they offered expensive Krug Champagne with the $150 and $200, which they have since jettisoned as well. Michelin Stars can help the bottomline! 

The same owners of Omakase have opened up next door in early 2016 a more casual (but still higher end) Izakaya (small plates) type restaurant, called Okane. ("Money" in Japanese.) It does have a more casual, small, 4 seat sushi bar, and sushi at tables. 

My international dining partner and I couldn't get the sushi bar at Omakase, which I always prefer, so we sat at one of the tables and was served by the waitresses, who were polite, attentive, and well trained, but not necessarily Japanese. Jackson Yu, the head Sushi Chef isn't either, but he is very well trained and has a lot of experience he brings to the menu, offerings, and sushi. His assistants are mostly Japanese. The General Manager of Okane is Justin Goo (From Alexander's Steakhouse) and I believe he is GM for Omakase now, too. So trust that you are in good hands. 

We went for the $150/person Omakase, and had a lovely meal with great dishes and very good service. You will have to look at the pictures to see each dish, as I ate there longer ago than my memory can remember the multi-course menu. 

"Omakase" is Japanese for "Chef's Choice" for sushi. Similar in concept to a Chef's tasting menu at higher end western restaurants. However, in the traditional sense, in a small Ma and Pa Sushi-ya in Japan, "Omakase" would mean that you trust the Sushi Chef with preparing things. But you would interact with him on what is fresh, and he would observe your tastes for his offerings and adjust accordingly with each next offering, through careful observations. But these restaurants like Omakase and others mentioned, are larger and more formal, and more similar to a Chef's Prix Fixe tasting menu of seasonal delights that Michelin likes to give stars. 

By the way, "Omakase" is more a noun, but the verb or very similar wording is also a general term in the language for "leave it up to me" or "count on me" if you are telling someone to rely on you for handling things. It is an opportunity for the promisor to prove their value and savvy, but a heavy responsibility as well in a culture of interdependence, like most Asian cultures are. Here at Omakase, I think with Jackson and Staff, and Justin and staff, you can trust to leave your dinng pleasure up to them.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
Omakase does not do just sushi -- it offers a "kaiseki-style" meal, where you get both nigiri and small Japanese dishes. For Bay Area sushi, I usually only compare the sushi to the quality I expect from other sushi meals I have had in the area. Obviously, you are not going to walk out of a kaiseki meal in SoMa with the same experience as you had in Tokyo. For some reason, Kusukabe seems to be the gold standard in the Bay, so to give my own opinion on how Omakase compares to Kusukabe: nigiri is better at Kusukabe, non-sushi dishes better at Omakase.

Omakase offers to types of kaiseki meals: a $150 one and a $200 one. We decided to go with the $150 meal.

The $150 meal comes with 2 appetizer dishes, 1 sashimi dish, 10 pieces of nigiri, and 1 owan dish. I actually am pretty sure we got more than that because I remember looking over to my dining partner halfway through the meal and saying, "Wait...I thought we already had 2 appetizer dishes??" 

You definitely want to sit at the bar (not just for Omakase, but for any omakase sushi restaurant). Being at the bar gave us the opportunity to interact with our chef and talk about the food and the SF sushi restaurant industry. It was fascinating being able to talk about how they got their fish every day, and the close community within the Bay Area. Even more awesome, at one point our chef was telling us about how to know what is "good" wasabi, and ground up some fresh wasabi for us from the root and let us try a small taste! It was pretty cool!

The overall meal was very very satisfying. I am a HUGE uni fan, and so, as no surprise, I loved the uni chawanmushi (sea urchin in a steamed egg dish) and the uni donburi (uni with salmon roe and rice). The fish was good, but honestly, I kind of felt like each piece was prepared the same way without much difference in the sauces used. Regardless, I still really enjoyed my meal. 

They start the meal with sake and end the meal with a sorbet in a glass filled with sake. I don't drink, and informed the server at the beginning that I had an allergy. They remembered and gave me sake-less sorbet for my dessert at the end of the meal, which I really appreciated.

4 stars for great food and service. Definitely a stellar restaurant to celebrate a special occasion!
author: Hannah J.

description: A perfect experience well worth the price tag. I don't know what else I can say. The sushi is incredible. The detail they put into each piece is beautiful. We also tried the sake pairing and thought it was worth it. A perfect experience from start to finish.
author: Kina L.

description:
We had an amazing night last night. Thank you Chef Jackson. The sashimi was amazing. I will never look at sushi the same. Thank you for making my daughters birthday a memorable one! Great conversations, amazing food and making new friends. #21BirthdayGraduation#DivorceParty
#RenownedProfessorUCSF
author: Russell T.

description: In a moment of spazticity and relative weakness, I initially posted a 1 Star review of Omakase. How could that be possible with a place that is Michelin starred you ask? Well, after initially being told I would have bar seating for my reservation I made last week, I was told today, the day of the reservation, that I in fact had a table seat as I was last to request this and the establishment is first come first serve. This, at an omokase restaurant would have been a travesty. However, after explaining what I was told and what my expectations were thereafter, the manager and chef/owner worked it out beautifully to where I could move my time up by an hour to get bar seating with Jackson himself! On top of that there were free booze, a seemingly endless supply of extra pieces full of toro of all varieties to make up for the inconvenience. And make it up they did! This may very well be the best omokase experience I have ever had! Every piece was expertly crafted with utmost precision. The appetizers were excellent. The dessert fantastic and the ambience perfect. I felt a bit terrible the entire time that I had even thought about leaving a bad review, let alone actually doing it. Shame on me. Well done Omakase, well done! Maintaining a Michelin Star one guest at a time, as it should be. Take note all. :: slow clap ::
author: Harjit m.

description:
Favorite sushi restaurant in SF :) $150 for 15 or $200 for 20 courses/pieces. $80 pairing. Small bar, so make early reservations. Dress: smart casual.

Tip: tea is free and included ;)
author: Frannie C.

description: Ingi is an amazing chef, and the restaurant is able to accommodate dietary restrictions. The ingredients are very fresh and the sake selections aren't bad either. The only downside is that everyone in the same time slot gets seated at the same time, creating a crowd in the tiny entrance/waiting area.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Eating at Omakase reminded me that it's more than just good food that makes a great meal.  A lot of little things came together that evening, starting from a friendly greeting upon arrival.  Once our seats were ready, another warm greeting from the chef followed by an explanation of what we needed to decide on the menu.  In the mean time an appetizer is served along with sake to welcome you.  Service during the meal was perfectly timed, the waitress was knowledgeable about the sake pairing, broke it down so that we could get a sense of what we are drinking and how it pairs with the particular course.  Always warm and friendly, we felt comfortable, even though it's was a new experience.  The other customers around you are just as relaxed, conversation flows, like everyone is at home.  

This is a special sushi experience, for us reserved for special occasions.  Everything we had was as fresh as you can get from Japan.  Each nigiri sushi made one by one, just before eating, amazing.  It's like being pampered, like at a spa, relaxing and exciting at the same time.

A lot of times when going out for sushi, we end up scrutinizing how well the rice is cooked and seasoned, or is the nori (seaweed) fresh or stale.  Is the fish fresh and portioned cut nicely, etc.  Omakase is so far beyond that, it's really down to the details of the food, what flavor profiles the chef prefers and the service.  I'm not an expert at omakase sushi (yet), but I do know we came away all smiles, more than satisfied with the meal, had fun chatting with our neighbors and even took pictures with the chefs....how fun is that to end a meal with such enthusiasm.
author: Tom S.

description:
I don't get the hype. Service was good. The food was okay but me and my table didn't experience the amazing flavors everyone else supposedly has in all these reviews. The flavors were on par with a basic $40-60 omakase elsewhere in the city. Dinner at Kazan is way better in terms of flavor than this place. I don't mind the price tag since I do fine dining from time ot time but this place missed the mark.

Maybe I'm a sushi snob? I've had sushi at Tsukiji Fish Market in tokyo (Sushi Dai) and it was just okay- it was just....affordable but not mind blowing?I've had better at more expensive places in Tokyo and stateside. I don't get all the omg so fresh comments here either because a lot of sushi is or can be preserved and what not for flavor.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
tl;dr
Hands down the best quality of fish I have ever had.  You also pay a pretty price for it though so if willing to splurge and indulge it is definitely worth trying.

---------

Setup/Atmosphere/Authenticity: Two fixed menu's for $150 and $200/per (see menu pictures).  Sake pairing available for additional cost or separate drink selection available for 8oz or bottle.  We went w/ the $200 option, no sake pairing, and ordered our own selection of sake off the menu.  Each dish is brought out individually at your own pace.  Depending on how fast you eat this can lead to a lengthy meal. Reservations VERY HIGHLY recommended.  The entire space can probably seat approx. 20 - 25 people total at a time.   There is a sushi bar that fits majority of the guests w/ 2 or 3 small tables in the front that seat 2 people each.  There are 3 chefs at a time and it is meant to be entertainment/dining.  If sitting at the bar it is recommended to engage w/ the chefs.  It seems to be reservations based, and fixed in waves to keep the menu along the same pace so the chefs aren't all over the place.  No jacket required, but would not come in jeans and a t-shirt.  Everyone fits the theme of a Japanese restaurant, sushi chefs (self explanatory and waitresses in kimonos)

Service: Waitresses are very attentive.  As soon as you finish one dish they collect the dish and wait till the table is ready for the next course.  They also explain what each dish is when brought out which was very helpful as I wouldn't be able to pronounce or even know what some of the items were.  I also asked for a breakdown of the sashimi section and they hand-wrote each dish (w/ the English definition) on a fancy paper!  They had the chefs even sign it!  They also provided a card w/ the chef's signatures (and little drawings) for someone's graduation.  Very thoughtful and cool from the chefs!  The hostess also came by to talk to us and she was extremely friendly and offered several recommendations.  You could ask them anything about the food and they were more than happy to answer and be of service!

Quality of Food:  Wow, just wow!  Most of the items I would probably not order at any other restaurant because I usually don't eat or just not a favorite.  Decided to go out of my comfort zone and I was very happy I did.  Everything was absolutely delicious!  A perfect example was the Uni.  Not a fan of uni - mainly for the texture but when I tried it here it was so smooth!  Same w/ the sashimi - very fresh fish and as you would say "not fishy" is actually good!  They serve the best parts of the fish and each dish was very flavorable.  My only issue is the amount of wasabi they put on the sashimi.  Since that part of the experience is meant to be enjoyed w/ your hands, they actually put a little bit of wasabi and soy sauce in between the fish and rice.  This is cool - never experienced it that way but I am also very sensitive to wasabi.  So when I stuck the pieces in my mouth unknowingly I was in for a little shock.  It really wasn't much but I use very little wasabi on my sushi so I would've liked less and/or more spread out instead of it more as a glue for the fish and rice.  They offered us a complimentary sake in the beginning and it was fruity which I really enjoyed (picture w/ the bottle and metal cups)!  The one we ordered w/ our meal was recommended by the host.  It was very good as well!  Not as fruity, more dry, but very smooth.  It was easy to drink.

Overall:  I definitely enjoyed the overall experience.  Given that I'm usually pretty easy to please I don't go out to nice restaurants.  I was definitely glad I went a little out of my comfort zone both w/ the price and the food.  I would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for a good, authentic, Japanese sushi bar.  I would not recommend coming here though if you're just looking for rolls.  This place is mainly a highlight to more authentic sashimi dishes.  As mentioned I also recommend making reservations and engaging w/ the staff (both the chefs and the waitress).  Realistically I probably won't be going back on my own any time too soon for a casual dinner or quick bite.  After the full meal we were there for almost 2 1/2 hrs and it didnt even feel that long till after I looked back at the time.  However if someone wanted to go for a special occasion I would not hesitate!
author: Patricia L.

description: Rather tired and uninspired. Sushi strictly by the book.  Overpriced. Not particularly friendly. Seats jammed together like iwashi in a can. Very limited sake by the glass (carafe, actually).
author: H S.

description:
This place is amazing and unforgettable. I almost came back to eat the day after. That's how good it was. 

Two options of omakase depending on how hungry you are. 

Each piece of nigiri here literally melted in my mouth. 

Service is TOP NOTCH. Water/tea always filled, napkin always folded. Not overbearing at all. 

The food/experience was so good I didn't care this time about taking pictures except for one. I wanted to savor the moment. I was so full at the end. 

Atmosphere is casual, not pretentious at all. Chefs are SUPER NICE, don't mind you taking pics. 

tip: reserve for the bar
author: Anthony V.

description: Came here with our friends for hubby's birthday and had a GREAT time. The sashimi was very fresh, we got to order the live uni on the side as an add on but it was not as good as we expected. The chef was very friendly to us and drew a birthday card for my husband. Definitely wanna come back again.
author: J C.

description: Always enjoy sushi here service is good!! I would definitely recommend this to friends and family
author: Samcasino B.

description:
Summary: This is the best sushi in the Bay Area. Went here and Kusakabe on consecutive nights and can definitively say that this was better (both were good). 

As a self-proclaimed omakase snob, I think I have a pretty good idea of what's good and what's not. This place is very good. Everything was very well prepared, but I'll walk you through some of my favorites:

Pros:
Very creative dishes that taste as good as they look
Fresh wasabi root being turned into paste right in front of you
Excellent view where you can see the sushi chefs doing their thing
Small, intimate environment
Great service
Toro
Golden eye snapper
Horse Mackerel
Uni + Fatty Tuna combo was absurdly good

Cons:
The conch wasn't as delicious as it looked (it looked ridiculously awesome!) Maybe it's the crunchy texture and it's possible that it was well prepared and that I just don't like conch.
The whole crab, while delicious, was rather difficult to eat

Overall, I would go back without hesitation when I'm in the Bay Area. High quality omakase and great service.
author: Alex W.

description:
********************** 1490 *********************

  Omakase is one of those Japanese restaurants recently got 1 Michelin Star in October 2015, and then you can't get a reservation on Thur, Fri or Sat anymore, or at least 1-2 months out. With that said, there's a reason why for this hot spot in the Design District.

  Omakase is a cute and quaint little tiny place. You can't even see anything because their windows are covered with drapes. Good thing is you can find plenty of parking spaces here after 6 PM.

  Chef Jackson Yu, with 18 years of experience from all over the world, surely knows what he's doing here with 2 menu only now $150 Hideaki Omakase (2 appetizer, 1 sashimi, 10 nigiri, 1 owan) and $200 Yamato Omakase (2 appetizer, 2 sashimi, 12 nigiri, 1 owan) , of a place with about 20 seats, and fresh fish that is flown in three times a week from Tsukiji Market in Japan, as fresh and as nice as it gets.Everything was delicious and fresh and it's a bargain for the quality you get here. Chefs are very attentive to you and make you feel very welcome. 

  Now if you are that type that want happy hour $5 California Roll, or if you like Dragon Roll Dynamite Roll, Spicy Roll, or Victoria's Secret Roll, this is definitely NOT your style. 

  Don't forget to check out their premium Sake list, quite delicious. Another reason why I enjoy coming here, because their new General Manager Justin Goo (former Bar Manager at Alexander's Steakhouse and Gary Danko). Under his management, Omakase will only get better. 

  I left here fat and happy, so my BFF, we can't wait to come back. One my favorite newest Michelin Star in San Francisco.
author: Manda Bear B.

description: This place is not just a Michelle star restaurant providing great food, you'll feel like home and Jackson treats every customer like a friend. Go and try it！
author: Luna X.

description:
Omakase is pretty small restaurant in SoMa with maximum capacity of 14 people at one time. Despite that, we were still able to get a seating on Sunday at 5:30pm with a week's notice.

Right when we were seated, we were served complimentary sake. They had an extensive list of sakes and wines that you could order on the side, but it's $80 for the pairing. We came here for our 6 year anniversary and decided to spend the extra $50 on their Yamato Omakase over the Hideaki Omakase, but passed on the pairing. The Yamato Omakase comes with an additional sashimi, two additional pieces of nigiri, and a meat dish. 

The additional sashimi that night was live lobster tail and the meat dish was Grade A5 Wagyu. The fish is flown straight from Tsukiji market in Tokyo and the nigiri selection includes less commonly found seafood, such as the coveted Hokkaido uni, Hokkaido mackerel (much less fishy and vinegary than you'd find elsewhere), and golden eye snapper. 

I'd recommend sitting at the bar because you can watch them in action and ask questions. The chefs' preparation of the nigiri deviated from the traditional in that they sometimes added small amounts of sea salt or truffle salt, a squeeze of lemon juice, and light sauces. Most of the pieces had wasabi underneath the fish, but since they use real wasabi, it wasn't as biting or pungent. The chefs also lightly brushed the soy sauce onto the fish before serving it so you didn't have to dip it yourself and get the rice soaked. There were a few fish that they seared with a blowtorch, which brought out a different flavor than when completely raw. 

I was surprised at how delicious some of the fish were with these small additions - truly amazing! It was interesting that they could transform something I've had so many times into something so different. It was also apparent that the quality of their seafood was superb. For example, when the ikura popped in my mouth, it was a light, briny taste reminiscent of the sea rather than a flood of harsh saltiness.

The Wagyu at the end, though small, was worth it. It was lightly seared and sliced into very thin pieces and served with sides of green tea salt, wasabi, truffle soy sauce, and pepper. 

Another thing worth mentioning is that the restaurant pairs the food with beautiful traditional Japanese ceramic and pottery. The pieces are subtle, so it's easy to overlook, but it definitely added to the ambience.

If you're coming here for a special occasion, be sure to let them know. Almost every single party that night had something going on. You could tell because they had cards displayed on a stand for those individuals. At the end of our meal, all of the chefs signed our card and drew silly pictures of a sea creature and handed us a small arrangement of orchids.
author: Tracy V.

description:
Updated- 4/17/2016.

After dinning at other places- Wako, Kusakabe, Ijji, Yume, Ju-Ni.  I have to take Omakase down another star to two.  

Dinner at Omakase_

Another new addition to 2016 Michelin one star.

Lets start with the good

Sashimi-
Mirugai- Japanese claim is the best i have in a long while.  Crisp and sweet.  Excellent.
Kampanchi- fresh and flavorful.  
Tuna- so so- but acceptable
Lobster- little sweet and perfect texture.

Sashimi is good.  Definitely one star quality.

Hot dishes-

chawanmushi- this is just bad.  The broth were a little salty.  But the egg portion is flavorless.  The Hamachi inside was not prepared properly and i can taste the stink of hamachi.  Overall, this was really really bad.

Trout with dashi and tomato- bland and nothing goes with each other.  Forgettable dish.

Misoyaki Blackcod with snow crab dashi-  this is just bad.  Reminds me of Maresa.  Blackcod misoyaki is very salty and sweet. So i can understand the need to balance the taste.  But to have a dahi of snow crab with absolutely no flavor at all.  Its just ridiculous.  You can't balance the flavor at all. Its just salty fish with water.  Overall bad.

All the hot dishes was total mess.  

Nigiri-

Lets start with rice-  the biggest problem with Omakase is its rice.  I prefer slightly under cooked rice with red vinegar that gives it texture and sourness that would bring out the flavor of the fish.  Omakase rice is over cooked and lacks texture.  Its also lack sourness that would bring out the flavor of fish.

Out 11 pieces of nigiri, only couple dishes that i would want to eat again.  The white shrimp with uni was creative.  The hirame with hirame liver on top was good.  The toro was great- just enough fat and very rich in flavor.

One thing that really pissed me off was the Aji.  Aji is my favorite fish.  Omakase Aji was probably the best i had in the bay area.  Except the chef butchered it by putting way too much ginger on top.  Really really pissed me off.  It could have been out of this world.

Nigiri- I gave it 3 out of 5 star.  They have very good fish and probably one of the best in bay area.  But the rice and some fundamental mistakes really ruined the fish.  Its a pity, because it can be so much better. 

Lastly-  the tamako at the end was also really really poorly done.  Omakase tried to duplicate Jiro's style of tamako.  Jiro's version is full of flavor and texture is like sweet honey cake- moist.  In US, Nakazawa is probably the only place that is authentic as compare to Jiro.  Yoshizumi in San Mateo comes close.  But Omakase really screwed up.  The flavor is there.  But its over cooked and tasted very dry.  The texture is like dried out sponge cake.  

Service- 
Yes.  Compare to other $$$$ sushi place in the bay area.  There are more servers at Omakase.  But the service was not as good as it can be.  My wife's tea ran out twice and tea got cold on several occasions.  Sushi will lower the patron temperature.  Hence keep constant hot tea is a must.  

Our chef (not Chef Yu) was slow in wiping the plate clean.  Also, my wife's white shrimp with uni fell apart on the dish.  

Conclusion-

Nirigi- 3/5

Sashimi- 5/5

Service- 3/5

Hot items- 1/5

I had to revise my comment after visiting Ijji.  Ijji's fish quality and creativity is heads and above Omakase.  Omakase is over priced and no where as good as other authentic Japanese restaurant.  

This place caters to Chinese much better.  Its just not authentic Omakase.
author: Jerry W.

description: I had a great experience last night eating here for my anniversary, the waitresses and chef Sam were amazing! It was a set menu so I was ready for whatever the chefs had planned for me. Everything was so fresh and the courses had great flavors. I am normally not an uni eater but the way it was served makes me want to come back for more. The only other place I've had that is comparable is sugar fish in SoCal, but damn that was some good sushi!!!
author: Jennifer T.

description: Originally I wanted to give 4 stars but unfortunately the last plate had one big faux pas I cannot forgive especially for a meal of this caliber. My friend and I arrived @ 9-910pm for our reservation so we were literally the last guest to start and finish. The dinner takes about 3 hours which is fine with us especially considering if it was any less I would feel cheated considering it was a little over $600 for dinner for two. The toro, Uni, wagyu and duck breast definitely stood out. The clam broth was a tad bit salty for my taste. The rest were good but not exceptional. Sadly at price point I was expecting more. The presentation is nothing short of gorgeous. It was dinner and a show since you are watching the chef makes the dishes before your eyes. Okay, I don't want to keep you in suspense about the faux pas. It was the omelette that had Caramelized sugar on it. We watch the chef make it for other patrons and watched the other patrons eat it. The looks on their face only heighten the anticipation for us as not only did it looked amazing but the looks on the face said it all. Our chef had pre-made ours along with another groups that were like 30 minutes ahead of us in terms of dinner service. So sadly when it was our turn to eat the omelette to say disappointed is an understatement of the year. Since he had torched it ahead of time, the omelette was cold and the Caramelized sugar had turn a bit bitter. I understand we are the last patrons in establishment but if you didn't want to stay open past a certain time then you shouldn't take our reservation. With the numbers of omakase restaurants opening in the city there are just better options and can't say I would return to dine here a second time.
author: Gina H.

description:
Was it delicious? Absolutely.

But was it a $200 dining experience? Questionable.

Was it worth flying to San Francisco from Thailand for one night just to eat here like the man and his teenage son who sat next to us at the bar? Nah, Tokyo is much closer. ;)

Omakase only has two pricing options now after the $100 option got taken off the menu: $150 and $200. For half the price ($95), you can eat at Kusakabe (which also has one michelin star) and get a comparable dining experience. I would say that Omakase is more traditional, and Kusakabe adds a few more modern/fusion twists to their dishes.

Anyways, pricing aside, I had a lot of fun joking around with my friends and the chefs. By the way, any omakase experience is incomplete if you don't sit at the bar, so make sure to request bar seating when you make your reservation.

Almost all of the fish are flown fresh from Tsuiji market with the exception being the Maine lobster, which I consider one of the highlights of the meal. Some of my favorites include:

- the grilled eggplant appetizer
- the Maine Lobster tail sashimi - I've never had lobster raw before. It tastes like ebi (sweet shrimp)!
- the horse mackerel nigiri with ginger and chives - this is a new twist for me. I've never had chives on sushi before.
- uni ikura on rice - I wish I could have a giant bowl of this stuff!!!
- O-toro (the fattiest cut of tuna you can get) nigiri - I call it the orgasm-toro. It never disappoints.

The just OK:
- Scallop nigiri with lemon zest - the lemon zest overpowered the natural flavors of the scallop. I wish I could have had it straight up!
- Satsuma beef - I'm just being picky here, but they served it to us on the lukewarm side. The slices were also disappointingly thin. Needs more meat!!!! Loved the marbling on it though.
author: Catherine C.

description:
This was such an amazing experience with amazing chefs! 

I was in a group of three, seated at the bar. We ordered the $200 Omakase and tasted a few different sakes. Chef Andy was our main craftsman that night and Chef Jackson made a couple of dishes for us as well. The service was excellent. Chef Andy was very attuned with us and definitely willing to listen and change according to our needs. 

I think a huge part of the experience is also what you bring to the table. We started off fairly quiet but we really pursued our chefs and started conversations. Yes we talked about the fish, the origin, his training, and his expertise; but we also took the time to get to know him. The chefs give back what you put in because they're reading your level of comfort. It was such an amazing experience. 

Some highlights for the food: 
- lean tuna sashimi: this was so wow! Extremely tender but still firm in texture. The flavors definitely lingered on my tongue! 
- uni: straight from Japan !! shipped within 24 hours, perfectly briney with such sweetness (I think this could have been my favorite of the night.) 
- monkfish liver: creamy richness that I'm still drooling over! 
- clam and live lobster: first of all, the plating was beautiful (thanks Chef Jackson). Secondly, the juxtaposition of the two were so well thought out! Flavors were simple and subtle, the textures really took me on a trip. 
- otoro: not much to be said here really. Melt in your mouth, taste bud-exciting otoro 


I could go on, but it's seriously worth a try! I had an amazing experience. (literally the third time I've written this sentence in this review) This is a serious business and I can't wait to find my way back here again!
author: Tina Y.

description: If you're in the mood to splurge on sushi, sake and service then Omakase is the place to go.  Our chef, Jackson was top notch and kept us engaged the entire time.  As for the sushi, the photos speak for themselves!
author: Brandon M.

description:
Guess we missed the initial opening phase of michelin-standard sushi. The 4.5 star rating is baffling regarding the quality of the dishes we received. Host girl was awesome, attentive and professional. Waitresses did their job of introducing each dish well. 

This 2 star rating is a direct grading of the sushi we received. Checked in with the waitress towards the end and asked if it was a combination of different chefs creating different dishes for each party throughout the night, but turns out a single chef will be assigned to your omakase experience - our Chef's name was Jackson ("Jackson-san"), and as a caveat, it might have been a unique disappointment with his lack of experience or selective sloppiness in preparing our courses since we chose to sit at the tables instead of at the bar.

Incredibly disappointing and I'm no hyper-cynical food critic by any means. but the sushi presentation, the rice, etc was no better than something Ryoko's in the TL would serve (or maybe slightly lesser than)- in itself a decent restaurant but to be purportedly on the level of Kusakabe and Maruya in terms of quality and price, it was a huge fail and an extremely painful bill to justify.
author: virna d.

description:
One of the best omakase experiences ever! A friend and I opted for the 200$ set meal and we were not disappointed. Everything was so fresh and delicious. The restaurant has only bar seating that fits less than 20, with 2 seatings per night. 
Definitely a once in a long while treat.

Reservations are needed as they are booked out usually a month or so in advance.
author: M W.

description: If you have the mean$ to go, this is a must try! Fresh, delicious fish flown in from Japan. The service is impeccable and the staff is fun. Also, it's not at all pretentious so definitely have some sake/champagne and enjoy yourself!
author: Nene N.

description: I have to qualify this 3 star review.  If it were just based off the food, it's decent, so maybe it would be closer to a 4 star.  However then you add in the price and it's just WAY too expensive to get past 3 stars.  I absolutely knew the place was pricey going in, but what I expected from this dinner was just amazing dishes, or at least a few of out of the course that stand out.  Unfortunately, not a single dish should out as even above average.  Just nothing to write home about.  For what dinner and some wine costs here, you could go to 3 times to other sushi restaurants and have some more excellent sushi.
author: Prabal D.

description: Favorite omakase in SF so far. Reservation required. The chef is really funny and made the experience even better.
author: Cate L.

description:
It's so good, it drew me out of lurker-status to write my first review.

I came here with a friend for the second seating of the night. We got the $200 omakase and boy, was it worth it. Absolutely incredible experience start to finish from the very friendly, knowledgeable chefs to the creative and delicious food. 

Standouts from the night were the ocean trout, satsuma wagyu beef, sweet Japanese white shrimp, uni/grouper/ikura bowl, and toro. Everything was SO YUMMY.

The chefs didn't mind us hanging around (i.e. basking in food coma) and chatted with us afterwards. Very nice guys who are passionate about what they do. Shoutouts to Jackson and Andy :)

I'll definitely be back!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Came on a Sunday for early dinner, it wasn't very crowded, that gave us good time to watch and talk with the chef.  The chefs were friendly and considerate.  Service was attentive and professional.

We took our kid there and the chef made a mini sushi set for her, very fun to watch in the making and super cute to eat!  It was a nice surprise to see the chef came up with this idea!  We were very touched!  

We had a number of sushi and they were all very yummy.  We also saw how fresh wasabi was made, eye-opening!  The chef also explained the fish quality they got from Japan that they have a contract to make sure they got the best part of the fish.  It was reassuring to hear that.  

Overall we had a good time and enjoyed our stay.  There was only one dessert course but we had a good taste of sushi.
author: LeeLee C.

description:
The restaurant itself is tiny, with only a very small number of seats at the sushi bar. While the dinner was extremely intimate, I did feel a bit uncomfortable and cramped sitting so close to the next party. Amongst Maruya and Kusakabe, i'd have to say Omakase's space was my least favorite.

However, the sushi is exquisite. I would have liked if the chef was a bit chattier, but he did let us try all the different types of uni they had so I was more than happy at the end.
author: Cheri K.

description:
I am not a subtle eater... My manner of consuming food is more like a possessed vacuum cleaner in an 80's horror movie.... 

This is exactly why omakase have come to be, for me, like yoga, meditation, or sunday services is for others... 

At its best It is a slow, subtle, and deceptively complex way of experiencing food that helps me to explore the and expansive breadth of my human ability to feel and sense...it helps me connect to something very real and transcend any hint of carelessness or clutter. 

I do not pretend to be  an authority - and of course there are HUGE  exceptions - but for me, very very very personally and intimately... I like a chef that can, like in church, act as a priest (or in sad rarity priestess).

We are gathered together here to experience the fish... and not the ego of priest or priestess...  his or her art is in crafting an essence of flavor that lets us experience the perfection that God touched in that piece of submarine flesh - and through that our own perfection in Gods image. 

Omakase Did that -  I never tasted 'the chef' but felt always focused on the fish. He did not drown the fish in fermented sauces - But for most of the meal... and it PAINS me to say this... I was bored. 

The service here though... was immaculate... breathtaking I dare say. 

The only 3 courses (that were not subtle) but that really helped me leave my body and touch something more important than my phone the courses on the more expensive menu - something did not sit right with me there... most of the rest of the time I caught myself texting... which I eat omakase to forget... I had been spoiled by such good fish in this fair city - that demanded true perfection. 

I give it 5 stars 'against'  most 'sushi' you will find - but for the price, and compared with the other omakase in town, it fell flat for me at 3. 

I hung a lot of hope on this place... and it was beautiful... just not transcendent.
author: Eric T.

description:
Thank you for a wonderful bday experience!
Restaurant is on a quieter part on Townsend, exterior is subtle and clean. Walk in and a hostess in traditional kimono greets you with an approachable smile. Offer to take you jacket, if you choose. We had the 8:30pm seating at the sushi bar and within 5mins of arrival, the place is full (@ 18 seats total) I like small and intimate setting tho because it gives you a chance to chat with the chef, it's like watching an art student at his best. 

I am not big on rice so we both opt for $200 sashimi selections. Glad I did because it was an endless amount of scrumptious delight. Each bite and taste had different sensations! We had a huge bottle of semi sweet sake so obviously I don't remember the names of each piece of fish but NONE of which I didn't went "oooohhhh yum". Two of my all time fav were Uni and Mirugai and no doubt...perfect. The yummy bday cake was the perfect taste to end this journey. 

I'll be back soon!
author: Vee V.

description:
Amazing!

Great food, awesome service, a perfect evening. Every bite was a little piece of heaven made perfect by the sake pairings.
author: Per K.

description:
Soooo...maybe my tastebuds are bad...maybe this Chef that everyone raves about was abducted by machines from the future and replaced with a cyborg intent on terminating humanity with bad cuts of fish...or maybe I just caught this spot on a bad day.

Whatever the case, I really really really wanted to like this place. Not because it was really really really expensive ($500+ omakase for two). But because I really really really wanted to have another good omakase experience close to home. Shiro in Seattle was amaze-balls...Wako near Geary was orgasmic...Omakase on Townsend was (insert negative expletive).

Am I being too harsh? Maybe.

But let me explain.

I overhear the chef talking about how much he paid for his knives. $3000 for one even. I'm thinking to myself, damn his knife skills must be on fleek! I start getting excited! Then the first sashimi dish comes out...

I look down at two pieces. And look over at my girlfriend's two pieces. I know there's always going to be size discrepancy, but one of my slices was like 70% thinner than hers. I pick it up, she notices it too, and kindly switches pieces with me because you know I'm a grown man! Whatevs no big deal but I note it.

The courses start slowly trickling through and on the most part everything was ok. Nothing to write home about and not very creative. I think 4-5 of the sushi had the same dressing so I couldn't really distinguish the fish. You could've cut up a goldfish, blowtorched it, dressed it, and it would have probably tasted the same.

But then something happens that has never ever happened to me at any high end Japanese restaurant...actually not even at a sushi boat place!

A sushi piece comes out and I put it in my mouth, start chewing, and chewing, and chew some more. I realize I have fish grizzle in my mouth...you know like when you bite into a badly cut piece of steak and get tendon. Mother...of...God! I need to spit it out but umm there's no trash, or napkins, or a place to hide it...it's an omakase dinner so the chef is looking right at me, the waitress is at my back, and other customers are to the left and right of me! So I tuck the grizzled piece under my tongue and excuse myself to find the bathroom where I promptly spit it out.

What the what!? How does that happen with a $3000 dollar knife? And at $500, I just spit out like $40 bucks!

My girlfriend is laughing at me until two dishes later, it happens to her too! Her gag reflexes are faster so she spits it out onto her lap and wraps it in her cloth napkin. But it's one of those restaurants where when you leave for the bathroom, they pick up your napkin and fold it for you! Yeah, who's laughing now?

This should never happen and it actually happend twice to me like watching a movie from M. Knight Shamalan that you know is gonna be bad but you give it a chance and then after the movie, you want to find where he lives and kill him. But I digress...

The service here was quality. The ambience was nice and cozy and inviting. But the omakase was mediocre at best. I don't mind paying for exquisite food experiences. But leaving this place, I felt like I was robbed, like I went to Vegas and lost all my money on the first night of a week long vacation, like I read all these good reviews on a restaurant on Yelp just to find out that wow, peeps give out stars way too easy peasy, lies I tell you!

Aww I hate writing bad reviews but this is just a detour sign on the road to omakase nirvana. With great power comes great responsibility.
author: Christopher C.

description:
Always a great meal with awesome service!
Harder to get into now with their michelin rating. 
Get the $200 onakase and a nice bottle of sake, your good to go. Hard to give a description of the menu because its always changing.
author: Dub C.

description:
Obviously the ambiance leaves a lot to be desired. Terrible waiting area and elbow to elbow sushi bar, neither of which match the quality of experience they are trying to give. 

That said the service is excellent, and personalized. 

I will say that I thought the fish was inconsistent, although there were certainly some awesome pieces. This was definitely not the level of culinary experience I was expecting, but it was good. 

The sake pairing was a little frustrating as they would pair multiple courses with a very small glass of sake. 

All in all, we enjoyed the meal. But honestly I probably will not be back as there are much better high end experiences in sf.  I just don't think it is fair to give 3 stars even if the price would imply a better experience.
author: Amjad S.

description:
Came here for our anniversary and was surprised to see that almost everyone dining there was celebrating a special occasion. 

Main highlights:
- Sake pairing was delightful. Paired perfectly - bravo!
- Sushi was solid.. a little steep in pricing but it was for the most part worth it. The Hokkaido scallop was delish!
- For special occasions, all the sushi chefs sign a card for you which is cute. They also give you a single orchid upon departure which is a very nice touch. 

I personally prefer ju-ni and Kusakabe over Omakase but it was a great night nonetheless.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
What an experience , amazing quality and variation of fishes. I felt like I was in Japan. The omakase story through the dishes was delightful.
All 3 chefs are  A+
I had barracuda , Aji, mackerel, trumpet fish, oh toro, lean tuna, Hokkaido scallop, Lobster, baby kingfish and too many more to mention 
I will come back here again! Thank you chef Jackson!
author: Alejandro S.

description:
I'm a sushi snob. I've been to countless number of traditional sushi restaurants, in fact I travel long distances for good sushi. I only sit at sushi bars, and order omakase at every sushi joint. 

Unfortunately this place is just average, not good!
I've done so much research before making the reservation. Their fish come from Japan but they are not the best cuts.  Nice and friendly staff, however no value proposition. I'm ok with paying high prices for high quality fish, but Omakase disappointed me. :(
author: sirin a.

description:
Oh, dear.. I don't even know where to begin...

I've had this placed bookedmarked since it opened and finally decided to make reservations. They only do 4 seating's a night so I highly recommend booking in advance. They also take credit card information at the time of booking and charge a $75 fee for bookings cancelled within 48 hours of the reservation. Not quite sure how strict they are on this though.

My entire group opted for the $150 set. It was A LOT of food for me and my girlfriend, but the boys seemed satisfied with the amount. I'll definitely go for the $100 set next time around (yes there will be a next time). Everything was PERFECT! I can't get over how good the fish is here. I don't even like uni and it was AMAZING!!!!!! My favorite was the monkfish liver, which I normally do not like... 

Chef Andy was incredible. He made the experience 100x better. I could really tell he puts his heart and soul into what he does. Not only was he extremely informative, but also funny as hell! I would highly recommend requesting him for your next visit :) Chef Jackson came by a few times to chit chat (drink), and have fun as well. These guys are the real deal.

There's absolutely nothing bad I can say about this place, the food or the service. Perfection I tell ya! 10/10 would recommend.
author: Anna M.

description:
Omakase is a great Omakase experience.  Convenient, since this is all they offer: a Hideaki Omakase for $150 and a Yamato Omakase for $200 with a few extra courses).  It's really a 4.5 star experience -- the quality of fish was excellent, and the chef was both friendly and skilled.  However, it's $25-100 more than similar dining experiences elsewhere -- half of that might be a San Francisco thing, but it's a bit expensive for what it is even in SF.

I'd strongly encourage making sure you get seats at the bar.  There are two 2-seat tables in front; you do not want those.  It's also a relatively small restaurant, and if you have loud people showing off eating at the same seating as you, you're probably not going to have the immersive dining experience you seek.

Dinner starts out on a high note: complimentary glasses of Krug.  It's like first class on Singapore Airlines!

The menu changes from day to day based on availability and seasonality, but there was excellent sashimi of several types, 12 nigiri (although a bit heavy on flame-seared whitefish of various varieties for my taste), an amazing piece of A5 beef, some of the best uni I've had (matched by Morimoto's in Philadelphia), and a really amazing lobster miso soup (made with the shells of the lobster served as sashimi salad in the first course.)

I'd definitely go back, but at the price, not frequently. A superb dining experience, and totally worth going at least once.
author: Ryan L.

description:
The fastest I've ever spent $$$ on sushi but well worth it.

It started with a craving for really good fish. I came across Omakase while perusing yelp to satisfy my craving. It's relatively new compared to the sushi restaurants of similar caliber but I knew immediately I wanted to try this place. Simply because I was craving omakase and this place has stellar reviews and only serves omakase. Perfect!

Not that hard to choose which set you want, just ask yourself how much you want to spend for good sushi? For me... TAKE ALL MY MONEY.. just kidding but really I don't play games with good fish. 

The restaurant is very intimate. There is only bar seating and you are elbow to elbow to the person next to you. I didn't mind this too much since my neighbors were great people to talk to. You get to see the chef at work which I love. I'm fascinated at how they prepare the food. My boyfriend and I of course chose to go all the way with our sushi experience and did not regret it.

All the fish served were fresh and seasoned/dressed to perfection. The nigiri sushi needed no extra soy sauce or wasabi... it was perfect. The fish to rice temperature was superb. The fish was slightly cold and the rice a little warm to provide the perfect contrast in your mouth. The sashimi was melt in your mouth. We had a beef dish as well and that was excellent. The beef was tender, juicy, and so full of flavor. One of the best I've had. Even the ginger they provided in between each sushi piece was delicious.

From eating here I've learned:

1. Monkfish is the foie gras of the sea. I've never had monkfish this good, ever in my life. I thought I hated it from trying it in other places but Omakase has shown me the light and now I can't go back.

2. I didn't even know Uni could do something other than melt in your mouth. The uni I had here was juicy, firm but delicately soft at the same time. It was a whole new experience.

3. Fish prepared correctly is one of the most rewarding things you can taste. Every single piece of fish served to me was 10/10.

My boyfriend and I got lucky and picked a night to eat when Chef Masa was preparing. He used to co-own Maruya in SF but left and know he's consulting for various restaurants, Omakase being one of them. He is an expert at what he does and we were both glad we could enjoy it. 

Definitely can't look at normal sushi the same way again and I wouldn't trade if for anything. Omakase was wonderful and I would definitely come back again!

***TIP: come hungry if you're planning on going all out because it is a lot of food.
author: Jennifer H.

description: I tried Omakase when it first opened last year. I was impressed and raved about it to my sushi loving friends. Much has changed since then. The immediate difference you notice is the seating. They now pack way too many chairs at the sushi bar taking away from the dining experience. Now to the actual food - the sushi rice was over done and didn't hold well. The pieces of fish offered were also underwhelming. Worst of all was the chef that was taking care of our section. He was very rude and even aggressively chopped my piece of sushi before handing it to me when he misunderstood something I said. With all the $$$$ sushi options in the Bay Area, and even in the city, this restaurant is easily a skip. I will not be returning.
author: Amy C.

description:
Getting straight to the point, the sushi here was absolutely stellar and easily set a new benchmark for the cuisine.  The freshest sashimi from Tsukiji Fish Market flown in 3 times a week and exquisitely-made sushi rice served at the proper temperature, the grains dispersed on the tongue with the greatest of ease.  Favorites included barracuda as well as several others whose Japanese names I unfortunately cannot remember.

The experience was good, but not particularly memorable.  Our sushi chef turned out to be the most seasoned of the group (Chef Gen?) and he did an excellent job from start to finish.  I do wish that it was more interactive though as the language barrier made things a bit difficult.  By the end, my brother and I were kindly asked by the waitress if we were still hungry...actually, we were a bit.  We decided to wrap things up though and we were both surprised and honestly, disappointed when all we received thereafter was a check.  No finishing sweet bite or any dessert items to speak of, just a feeling of being left totally hanging after some red miso soup of all things...

Don't get me wrong, the sushi was wonderful.  But at this price point, I was expecting a fair deal more out of the experience.  Perhaps this is just the way sushi restaurants of this caliber operate with the focus almost entirely on the food.  If that's the case, I'd rather spend my money for a far more involving and encompassing experience at a two Michelin star establishment or similar.
author: Eric F.

description: So good. San Francisco doesn't have that many outstanding regular sushi spots, but we finally do have a few outlier ultra high end spots. Omakase hits the mark and is right up there with Kusakabe and Maruya. It's not an inexpensive meal... you pick a price point of either $100, $150, or $200 and they take care of the rest. There is also an $80 sake pairing. The flawless service, fish quality, and artistry make it worth trying at least once. Can't wait to have an excuse to go again.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Best Omakase!  Chef Jackson and their team are experts in their field.  Every dish was well thought out and courses came at the perfect pace.  Chef and team are so friendly that u feel at home.  A must try gem in San Francisco and highly recommended by some of the best veterans in the industry!  Well worth the price, truly memorable experience.
author: Wasabi P.

description: Omakase was one of the best dinners my girlfriend and I have ever had. I truly appreciate the experience we had. Thank you to everyone who made her birthday so great!
author: Andy R.

description:
What an incredible dinner!

Make sure you sit at the bar and watch the masters slice the fresh fish flown in from Japan and mold them into beautiful pieces of art.  The fish just melts in your mouth!!  I especially loved the uni, otoro, chutoro, fresh lobster with caviar, the sugar torched Saba, the fish braid (literally), and the wagyu yakimono. 

Chef Andy kept us entertained and we plan on taking up his offer of having VIP seats right next to him when we come back! :)
author: Tanya P.

description: Pleasantly surprised and delighted at how much I enjoyed Omakase. Best of the Michelin starred sushi restaurants in San Francisco. I was able to get a reservation just a few days before going. Of course the freshest of ingredients and also some of the hardest to get. On top of that, extremely well-prepared dishes with exquisitely subtle nuances which I appreciated very much. I'm making myself hungry again just remembering what I had there! The Yamato course is no joke in terms of the amount of food, so if you go for that, be sure to bring your appetite. Looking forward to my next visit!
author: James P.

description:
Omakase serves one of my favorite omakase dinners in SF!

If you come here on a weeknight for the 8:30pm seating, you won't have any trouble finding parking.

I have had the opportunity to dine at Omakase twice. On the latest occasion, I got the $200 set while my food companion got the $150 set. Both sets were very delicious and filling. I believe that the more expensive set included Kobe Beef, two additional nigiris and another small plate. To be honest, I wish that I just stuck with the less expensive set as I was quite stuffed by the end of the meal.

My personal favorites are the Saba Nigiri, Chawan Mushi, and Miso Soup. 

The Saba has a great balance where it was not over-marinated; meat was tender, not overly fishy and had just the right amount of the vinegar pickled taste.

We split the sake pairing between two people and I thought that the pourings were generous, but I don't drink much on a regular basis.

Would definitely come again!
author: Jeff M.

description:
Booked last minute on the same day as my dining experience. 

Location: 
I'm very familiar with this location since it's literally a block away from where I work. I usually park my car around the area and go next door for starbucks. So, the opening of Omakase wasn't new to me. I've actually bookmarked this place for the longest time and waited a long time for the occasion to book a reservation. 

Atmosphere: 
The place is small. They only have 18 seats total. The sushi bar sits 14 people. There's 2 small tables near the window that seats 2 each. I wished the lighting was a little brighter, this would have been perfect for all my instagram worthy photos. Interior design was along the lines of minimalist appeal with an added touch of some Japanese decor. 

Service: 
We were literally greeted immediately at the door by a staff who was dressed in a kimono. She asked us to take a seat at the waiting area while she prepare our seating. She also offered to hang our jackets if we needed. Moments later, another gal guided us to our seats. The one thing that I liked was the offering of a small basket to put the girls purse. It's rare that a restaurant here in the USA offer such service, but this is very common overseas, especially in Asia. 

Food: 
We had a party of 5. Three of us went with the Yamato Omakase $200 set and two went with the Hideaki Omakase $150 set. They originally has a $100 option, which is no longer an option. The difference between the two that we order was two additional pieces of nigiri, one plate of "live sushi" and one osusume. The word "live" made me do a last minute switch. I wanted to see if they would serve something that was really live and still jumping and moving on the plate, but I was disappointed to find that this wasn't the case. The "live" sushi plate was lobster and mirugai. None of those were actually live or moving. =/ They did not have chawanmushi the day we went, it was replaced with steamed butterfish. I didn't have a problem with that since the butterfish was soft and well prepared. Nigiri was well prepared. The rice was seasoned properly and the fishes were garnished. Chef were able to properly enhance the taste of each piece of fish. Our expensive option also came with a small cut of a5 Wagyu. Lastly, I forgot to mention the complementary pour of sake (loved it). 

Nitpicking: 
There was a small fly (perhaps fruit fly) that was buzzing around and did end up resting on the sushi bar. Nigiri rice was on the softer side. One of the spoons used for the uni & ikura rice bowl had some splinters on it, almost cut myself but I asked the sushi chef to change it. Head chef; Jackson was not in today, so I'm not sure if there's a improvement if he was our chef.
author: Eric Y.

description: Omakase when it opened has some of the best quality and preparations I've had in San Francisco perhaps the entire West Coast. Other places offering omakase have opened and the quality has gone down here. Now the people giving it one star because the meal is too long or expensive are ridiculous. Go to Japan and order omakase at a higher end place and it can be just as long and far more expensive. Yes some of them take under 1 hour and are no frills but that's not the style of this place and some places in Japan. This place is styled as a special occasion place and that's what you get. It's an excellent place for people that like Japanese food but aren't super knowledgeable. for people more knowledgeable it may be a bit of a disappointment with the way they have simplified a lot of the nigiri and the rigidity of the menu. Also it tends to be more traditional than a place like Ju-Ni but I think it also will appeal to more people. The small intimate setting makes for a tranquil dinner.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: Loveeee this place, our chef ‍ Jackson is super friendly and easy to talk to. We came here for one of our friend's birthday and all the chefs sign the birthday sign and take pictures with us. You got around 20 items for the $200 and oh the toro so yummy. The service is perfect and super friendly. It makes the omakase experience the best of all the place that we ever go to.
author: L D.

description:
Omakase is the new kid on the block and I cannot say enough good things about this place. If you're a true sushi lover and can appreciate the art of Japanese cuisine + all the tiny details that go into every cut of fish, then this place is for you. Make your ressies ASAP while they are still new, otherwise reservations might be hard to get within a few months.

Oh, did I also forget to mention that every meal here begins with a glass of champagne?? For only being a few weeks old, you can tell that A LOT of work was put into making this dining experience one-of-a-kind. Given the talent behind Omakase, this is a restaurant worth visiting and watching.

PS: this place is perfect for date night!! Sit back, enjoy some sake, and watch the Chefs prepare you a meal you won't forget.
Now THIS is a place that seeks perfection and I was immediately impressed by the passion and voice given to the art of food.

Sitting at the sushi bar, it doesn't take long to realize that Omakase is special - there are only 14 seats a night, every single piece of pottery is imported from Japan, the service is on point, and our sake was served in hand-made crystal glasses-!!

GUYS. Even the sushi rice is timed/cooked depending on the time of your reservation AKA arrival. I mean... how cool is that??

They take the extra step to ensure that each guest enjoys the optimal temperature for sushi rice.  Not too cold, and not too hot. Just perfection.

Every single item we had was phenomenal, there were even pieces of fish that I've never had before! Head Chef Jackson (who goes to Tokyo every year to practice his art) explained that since some fishes on their menu are so expensive and rare, 99% of sushi restaurants in the U.S do not carry them.

For more deets and pics, visit http://cyneats.com/omakase/
author: Cynthia L.

description: It was our first time dining in a Michelin star restaurant and we find the experience to be enjoyable overall. Everyone sit at sushi bar with 1 chef assigned to 2-4 people at max and make food right in front of your eyes. We had Chef Sam San who prepared for for just my wife and I. You get to learn more about the food while enjoying them. We also did the sake pairing and it was quite enjoyable as well. The service was great! The overall bill was quite big though, but then we kind of expected that going to a Michelin star restaurant.
author: Kevin C.

description:
After hearing so many people rave about this, I finally got the chance to try Omakase. And I am so happy that I did! The chef's complimentary dish, the sashimi, the nigiri - all of it made the meal perfect.

Before you even get settled the chef gives you a kanpachi rice ball with a special sauce which was one of the many highlights. It was SO good. My boyfriend and I were joking about them doing this on purpose to hook you in so you'll order the $200 omakase option afterwards. They also provide a complimentary glass of champagne. 
 
My favorites:
- Sashimi appetizer (it came with mirugai clam too!) 
- Sardine nigiri
- Aji nigiri
- Barracuda nigiri
- Toro nigiri
- Uni, caviar, ikura, shrimp serving
- Scallop appetizer

It was hard to remember all the nigiris we ate but they were all SO fresh. The seasoning on each of the nigiri topped it off even more! I was talking to someone next to me about how that toro was probably the best toro I've ever had. Same with that uni/shrimp/ikura. I really hope I'm not overhyping this for anyone. If you really want uni, you might need to get the second omakase option. It seemed like those who got the $100 option didn't get the uni. But who knows? The omakase selection probably changes every day. 

The experience and the food makes this place worth five stars and the money. I had so much fun watching the chefs prepare and present everything. It's been a full 24 hours since my meal but moments of dinner are still replaying in my head and I can't stop thinking about it!
author: Ingrid C.

description:
Omakase has some fierce competition all over town, with the omakase concept becoming wildly popular among foodies everywhere. I'll preface my review by saying that Wako and Kusakabe are still my top two spots for omakase, but Omakase is a close third due purely to the quality of their fish. 

I went with the more expensive omakase option, which includes two extra courses. I was relatively unimpressed with the beginning courses. The tomato tartare seemed too basic and the amuse bouche didn't seem to fit with the meal. I loved the freshness of the cucumber and crab salad, which was the one dish that really started the meal for me. The following 12 pieces of nigiri were all incredible. They don't try to stuff you with rice, layering on a generous piece of fish on top of just the right amount of rice to balance it out. The hot wagyu beef course was a good shift from the fish courses, but relative to the other hot dishes at other omakase restaurants, I wasn't blown away. We finished the meal with a mochi that had both sweet and savory elements, which was surprisingly good. The overall experience was good, but I would suggest going to their sister restaurant Okane next door and just ordering off the sushi menu. You get the same fish in a less stiff atmosphere, and it allows you to pick and choose your favorites.
author: Ashley T.

description:
OH em ghee!  What an experience!  The food was absolutely delicious.  The fish was SO fresh and each dish was better than the last.  I didn't want it to end.  We were fortunate to have the owner as our chef and he was such a pleasure to watch and he was so sociable and entertaining.  

Aaaaah, if I could, I would eat here a couple of times a week.
author: Delilah B.

description: Jackson is an absolutely amazing chef!  I had an amazing time - the service, food, mood and sake were all incredible.  Definitely recommend!
author: Thomas Y.

description:
We had the middle tier omakase option with the beverage pairing (which you have to ask for).    The Uni dish was by far my favorite, but I am an Uni junkie, but the Toro was outstanding too.  The coolest thing for me was being served fish that I had not been offered before as sushi like Trumpet, Barracuda (yes the song plays in my head), Sea Robin and Butterfish.

The setting is small and intimate, very sparse design-wise, which is nice so you can hear the sushi chef and your server tell you a bit about what you are eating and drinking.  It I had one desire it would be around the beverage pairing; the pairings were all saki but since beer and wine is also available they could have mixed it up a bit.

Great job and I bet I see this place in next years top 100 restaurants in the Bay Area.
author: Heather D.

description:
This place is a gem!

I am so impressed with the quality and flavor. Each piece of fish is given its own delicious treatment.

Aside from the devine fish, my experience here was exceptional! Chef Jackson is a friendly character who is phenomenal at keeping his customers entertained, while maintaining a comfortable environment. I also really enjoyed watching his craftsmanship.
