His attention to detail is striking. Even the dinnerware is something to be appreciated. Highly recommend this place!
author: Nancy F.

description: had a very pleasant experience here for birthday and we enjoyed every minute of it, full of good food, creativity and laughter. I highly recommend this place if you value high quality Japanese food
author: Sweet R.

description: at first, the chef seems distant and hostile, but as the night progressed and everyone got some alcohol in their system, he lightened up. The food was absolutely on point, it was artfully prepared, the quality was fresh, the service was friendly/prompt, and the parking in this area is easier than other places. Do yourself a favor, you will want the extended menu.
author: Long C.

description:
Quality of the ingredients no doubt was one of the freshest I had in the Bay Area aside from Saru.  We had the $200 omakase since we wanted to had the full experience but there was just some inconsistency that mars the experience a bit.  

For example, for the Uni rice bowl, we didn't have caviar on top.  We weren't ask if we would like more wasabi or less after the first nigiri tasting.  I could do with a little bit more wasabi since I couldn't really taste it in the nigiris.  Guess I could have asked the chef but since I entrusted the chef, I'd think he knows the best how much wasabi to put on the nigiris without overpowering the fish so I didn't want to be rude.  The owan was a shrimp red miso and not lobster miso.  Guess I was expecting by ordering the $200 top of the line omakase, we would have been given the best of what the restaurant can offer but that's not so.

I'd recommend going with the $150 set and that would be just as satisfy.  

Also, I know it won't be fair to compare what I had at Mori in LA because of the location difference (rent maybe higher in SF) but for $50 more I paid eating at Omakase, I was more or less expecting the equivalent of what I had at Mori for $150.
author: Shirley H.

description:
Best sushi in SF 100% ! 
Fish are fresh and of good variety. 
Great sake selection. 
Will definitely go back :)
author: Danny W.

description:
Fantastic experience.  I'm not usually one for creativity in sushi, but this was so subtle, so smart, and with such great fish, I would venture to say it's the best sushi in SF.

I believe the only reason the restaurant is limited to one Michelin star is that there is no bar.  You wait for your table in a small foyer by the door to the street, and they don't offer a cocktail.  In fact, though they have sake and wine, they haven't any liquor, and that's just... but I digress.

We had the large menu, which at $200 per was an absolute steal (the truncated menu was $150, and diners seemed split in which they ordered; either would have been great).  We were stuffed by the end.  Giant clam was to die for.  Also the tuna jowl was of tremendous note.

The service was pitch-perfect; friendly but not obsequious.  There were three staff on the floor to assist ~14 customers; good ratio.

Next time you want to treat yourself, seriously consider this place.

One more thought - I'd pass on the sake pairing.  Unless you are an enthusiast, it adds a lot more expense, and, at least for my unsophisticated palate, it didn't expand the flavors that much.
author: Toby P.

description:
Overall a wonderful experience - the food was lovely but was a tad disappoint by two dishes that I can't recall. Their uni is touted as phenomenal and it's certainly true! Service was extremely attentive and one chef cracked jokes for the entirety of my dinner, to my delight.

Opted for the $150 Hideaki offering but will absolutely try the Yamato if I return.
author: Nicole C.

description:
A bit of a hidden gem, this restaurant is located next to Adobe and Zynga and the first thing I noticed was how many parking spots were available during dinnertime. Score!
I am greeted by beautiful geisha's who quickly pour me a glass of delicious champagne. Each plate of fish is decorated with organic ingredients and I immediately notice how well thought out each plate ware is. A few dishes had gold flakes on them which I loved b/c I felt so rich :)
I actually could not finish the entire Omakase but next time I come, I will surely bring a bigger appetite. I like how you can choose which price point you would spend it on, but I assure you that you truly pay for what you get.
author: Betty H.

description:
Some of the best sushi I've had! The quality of the fish is extremely fresh -- they showed us their authentic Hokkaido uni flown in with Hokkaido sea water in the packaging. All of it was incredibly delicious, fresh, and well presented. 

There was an atmosphere of elegance and refinement without any pretentiousness. The servers were extremely hospitable and watchful to make sure that our sake wasn't running too low or to tend to any need. The timing of the $100 omakase dinner was about 1.5 hours and timed perfectly. The restaurant had very limited seating which made it a peaceful and intimate environment to chat with your sushi chef.

Overall loved everything and will definitely come back next time we are in San Francisco!
author: Joanne K.

description: For the price, you can do a lot better in SF. I personally prefer Wako, Ijji and Juni to Omakase and they're all either cheaper or the same price range.
author: June W.

description:
Hands down, the BEST sushi/nigiri ever.  We sat at the bar with the main chef, who was soft spoken, kind and entertaining without being intrusive.  We enjoyed sitting at the bar and watching the prep, but with a family of four it was hard to converse along a stretch of bar.  

All the kitchen items and each nigiri item was delicious; we savored every morsel.   The rice was perfect, and for the nigiri the balance of soy sauce and acid was just right.  The wasabi is fresh and the ginger not too acidic.  

We look forward to returning.
author: Gina T.

description:
It takes some humility to admit when you're wrong and I will say that I was wrong about Omakase. I decided to give this place another try after seeing consistently positive reviews from fellow yelpers. 

To have things come full circle, I again sat in front of Chef Jackson. He remembered me from last time but did not begrudge me for my less than stellar review :P 

The complimentary pour of Krug has been replaced by sake (daiginjo). The omakase itself was drastically different. We had a wide variety of dishes and nigiris -- more than any of the other omakases I've tried in the city (Kusakabe, Ju-Ni, etc). Given that the lack of variety and innovation was my primary complaint last time, I really appreciate the change. It also speaks to the fact that the fish is routinely changed according to what is in season. 

Some of my favorites: 

-- Seared toro to start and raw toro to end 
-- Blue fin tuna and Halibut sashimi marinated in kelp 
-- Chawanmushi with uni 
I love egg custard and I love uni so it's unsurprising that I enjoyed this. The egg custard itself was not very flavorful but I actually liked how it didn't distract from the the uni. 
-- Torigai heart clam
I haven't found this in many restaurants in the states so I was pleasantly surprised! 
-- Line caught Aji (Japanese Horse Mackerel)
While Aji is a common fish on most sushi menus year-round, it is mostly farmed. I highly recommend line caught Aji when it's in season and Omakase's is easily one of the best I've had. 
-- Seared kinmedai goldeneye with himalayan salt 
Deep sea fish. Slightly sweet and so tender. 
-- King salmon with cherry blossom leaf (?)
-- Uni with ikura 
Obviously. 
-- Ankimo
I wish I had gotten this last time. In fact, I wish I could get this everytime. I highly suggest adding this if it doesn't come in your omakase for whatever reason. It is so different than any ankimo I've tried. The texture is much smoother and softer. There is a deep "liver" taste that is not overwhelmed by an excess of ponzu or soy. 
 
The last thing that makes Omakase one of the top sushi restaurants in the city is how attentive and impeccable the service is. My sake cup was always filled. My napkin was always folded when I returned to my seat. Most importantly, even though my girl friend can be picky, Jackson accommodated her very generously! When she didn't want saba (mackerel), he gave her *live clam*. When she didn't want a large portion of uni, he gave her *amebi (sweet shrimp)* topped with a small piece of uni. Needless to say, I was a bit jealous!
author: Xinxin W.

description:
I WANT right now!
This has to be the best fish i have had! It literally melted in my mouth. When you come here you get a set menu but you can order off the menu and add more if you want, which most pre fixe menus you can't add more of the things you want 
My hubby and I added extra waygu and it was totally worth it! 
The seating for us was at the bar which in my opinion was perfect! we were able to interact with our server/cook one on one. 
I would love to make it back to Omakase one of these days!
author: Natasha I.

description: This is the restaurant which I have eaten the best sushi in the San Francisco. The chief is good and friendly. He made some amazing sushi for us. I really want to recommend this restaurant to my friends, it's pretty good and delicious.
author: Lanqing X.

description:
Omakase is worth every bit of hype there is about it. I knew I wanted to take my boyfriend for his birthday, so booked a reservation as soon as I could (3 months out on OpenTable). If you are particular about what time you want to eat, then book early since there are two main sessions for dinner - 6pm and 8pm. You definitely want to budget out time for a 2-2.5 hour amazing dining experience.

Ambiance is quiet, traditional Japanese (think Jiro Dreams of Sushi, but not as intense). Lighting is dim and romantic. Not the best for picture taking, but you're also not really supposed to take photos. Just let yourself taste the incredibly fresh fish (the big-eyed snapper was my favorite), uni, and sake. You can add a sake pairing with your selection of one-out-of-two Omakase menus. We went with the Yamato Omakase for $200/person with a bottle of sake to share. Don't let the sticker-shock scare you too much because it is worth every penny with the quality, presentation, and service of the food/drink.

I don't normally give out 5-stars, however, Omakase is more than worthy of this rating. I highly recommend Omakase to anyone searching for a new kind of eating experience. But warning, sushi will never be the same afterwards! Happy eating!
author: Paige M.

description: Excellent food and service. I made reservation 2 months in advance for a Sunday dinner, and it was a full house.  It was for my husband's birthday celebration, and they put a signed birthday card at the table. We felt very welcoming with exquisite Japanese gourmet.
author: Mirana Y.

description: I really wish I could give this place five stars but from my experience it was just short of that. On that particular night the service lasted what seems to be almost three hours. I understand it's fine dining but it almost felt like a boring movie that would never end. It was to the point where I wasn't even hungry anymore because I just wanted to go home. I'm sure on a regular basis it wouldnt have last that long as they usually have two batches per night (around 2 hours) I'm sure they just over booked that night, but timing and pacing is extremely important for this type of dining at this type of establishment. In terms of the quality of the food, it was good but I can honestly say I've had better in at least two other similar establishments in the same city. In the end, this place did live up to its reputation but their price is higher then others and competition is stiff.
author: Herb L.

description: Honestly, I was expecting a lot more from Omakase since we were paying about $200/pp plus they have one Michelin star. The whole experience was okay but I was hoping that the chef would interact with us more than he was offering that night. I looked around that night and noticed that the chefs that were working didn't really interact with their customers. The food overall was decent but it wasn't any rare or special kind of fishes that I was hoping for. The waitress was very nice and made sure our tea was filled every time. The atmosphere of the restaurant was nice and cozy with dim light. I don't think I would be back again for that price and quality. I rather try other omakase place that opened up in the city.
author: Wing C.

description:
I have been here twice within the past 3 weeks. I ordered the Yamato Omakase each time. I went with the default nigiri the 1st time, but decided to change it up by going sashimi style on the latest visit. The food is super FRESH and delicious. Among the highlights:

mirugai - FRESH, sweet and the right texture (just the right amount of chewyness)

otoro - FRESH, just buttery. melts in your mouth. sooooooo good

king salmon - FRESH, so soft and smooth. you will no longer want to eat regular salmon!

hokkaido uni - FRESH, soft and perfectly runny.

a5 waygu - FRESH, so tender. perfectly seared. you will no longer want to eat the sirloins, filets, etc.

The restaurant has a capacity of 18 people (14 person sushi bar and (2) 2 person table). With omakase, sitting at the sushi bar is definitely the way to go. I will definitely have Andy San serve me again.
author: Steven L.

description: Made a reservation to celebrate the boyfriends birthday and it was a great experience. The service was great, food was excellent, and the chefs are friendly. Make sure you let them know if you're going for a birthday, they'll prepare for it!
author: Connie M.

description:
Very intimate setting with only 13 seats. The space looks pretty minimalist but doesn't lack any attention to detail. Along the wall are fully functional pottery rice cookers. Jackson Yu was our sushi chef for the evening and explained a lot of the decor and its origins to us. He trained to become a sushi chef in Japan with strict 80 hour work weeks for months at a time. Real dedication to his craft and it shows.

I opted for the $150 omakase option. This included two appetizers, one sashimi (3 kinds), 12 pieces of nigiri, one maki, and one owan. I'm glad I went with this option because it was just the right amount of food. I wasn't overly stuffed that I had to shovel food into my mouth but left very satisfied.

Almost everything from the fishes, dishes, and the decorations are flown in from Japan. The details of this restaurant truly make it an authentic experience outside of Japan. Because they only fly in the freshest fish from the Tsukiji Fish Market in Japan, every meal here will vary. This is the main reason why I'll be back again.
author: Eric L.

description:
I normally don't write reviews but I purposely created an account on Yelp to express my dissatisfaction towards Omakase. It ruined my Christmas mood as I was here with my fiance on Christmas eve. It was such a disappointment. The food was mediocre, definitely not worth $200. The service was poor and unacceptable for a Michelin star restaurant. What a waste of 3 hours and money...

First off, we were not greeted as we walked in. The waitresses and chefs saw me waiting but ignored me; not even a "Hello/Welcome". I waited for at least 10 mins before the hostess came to ask me for my name. 

We were finally seated and the hostess told me the bar was full when I requested for the bar at the time I made the reservation. The people that sat at the tables (only had two tables) did not receive the same attention as the people who sat at the bar. We were totally neglected! Everytime our tea kettle was empty and I had to wave down the server to give us a refill. I even lifted up the kettle cover to show them it was empty. Of course they were too busy serving the guests at the bar. 

Food wise, the guests at the bar got to eat each nigiri (12 total) as the chef finished making it. But because we sat at the table, we had to wait until the chef finished making the 3rd nigiri before we were served. So basically, we had to wait till the guests at the bar finished their 3rd nigiri before we can eat our 1st. The part that pissed me off the most was the chef gave bigger portions to the people at the bar! Even the head chef Jackson was questioning why the portions were so big. I mean, we are all paying the same price right? 

The hostess handed us the bill along with the last course. I guess they wanted us to leave asap. I still ended up giving a 15% tip at the end, which I will always regret as I should not have even given a dime. As we walked out, no one said "Bye/Thank You", like we never existed. 

Tip for future customers: Make sure you get a seat at the bar or else you will be neglected. Or you will need to know Jackson at a personal level. That night he had some high school friends there along with his first customers. Of course they got all the attention that night.
author: Sheldon K.

description:
A well deserved Michelin star for Omakase! The food was great and the service was impeccable. 

Once my friend and I were seated, we were first offered a complementary cup of sake. I personally have not developed a taste for sake yet but whatever they served there was absolutely delicious! It was light, slightly sweet, and paired very well with the meal. I really need to find out the name of the bottle. This could very well be the start of my sake fandom. 

We opted for the Hideaki Omakase option for $150. We sat at the bar and were served by the chef owner Jackson. Each set came out perfectly timed. Everything was perfectly seasoned. My favorites of the night were definitely the two sea bream nigiris (the baby and the uncle as Jackson put it). They were rich, full of flavor, and just melted in your mouth. The only thing I wasn't a fan of and didn't finish was the lobster agedashi. The shrimp-uni-caviar-gold leaf bite was also to die for. Did you know that there are actual gold in those edible gold leaves? 

We had a nice conversation with Jackson too as well as the couple who was sitting next to us. I must also give a shout out here to our host Justin who opened our eyes to the real world of the wagyu beef and explained the misnomer between kobe and wagyu. After this evening's food and this evening's conversations, I am really inspired to finally take that travel-alone trip to Japan this year.

I understand they rotate the offerings within the omakase options. I will definitely be back to try it again!

Tip: Definitely sit at the bar and definitely engage with your chef. It makes the whole experience that much better. :)
author: Nancy Y.

description: All I can say is WOW took the wife here for her birthday. It's worth every $100s of dollar I spent here. Who cares about price when the quality of food is amazing
author: Tim C.

description: I had a great time here. They were so accommodating. We came in late after a delayed flight and they still let us do our tasting and almost caught us up to the other people at our sitting time. We did the Yamato (I think 18 courses) and the sake pairing and ordered a carafe of another sake. We did not need that carafe, the sake pairing would have been more than enough. The food and sake were great. I love the chef and owner, Jackson, who was serving us.
author: Mandy T.

description:
Hot dish was really really really disappointed. Nothing that we like. Not even meet the standard.  The fish was blend and the soup was not tasty.

The sushi was great, but not enough. I guess only 10 pieces.  $200/person is overpriced for sure. Not full after all the dishes.
author: Che K.

description:
No doubt the fish was fresh. But the warm dishes were a disappointment. And the big problem was for the 200 dollar omakase, I was expecting a5 or something comparable, but we got miso marinated cod. I mean maybe it's cool if you are at nobu in 2000, but for 50 dollars more, I want something better than that. 

Basically for 200 dollars, going to benu, lazy bear, or crenn is much more worth it.
author: Brian Y.

description: I brought 3 clients to dinner here in July and here are my thoughts...  We sat at the bar where you can watch everything that is happening, I enjoyed that, though the smells from cooking also wafted out.  We all ordered the Yamato Omakase, the 18 course chef's choice menu, for $200.  The food was beautifully presented and well-prepared.  I absolutely loved the beer and the way it was served in a mug.  What I thought was less than 5 star was the service, I had to call the waitress over more than once for beer and water, and the variety of the food.  Of the 18 courses, 3 of them were uni (sea urchin), which is my least favorite fish. In addition the dishes were almost all protein and I would have liked to have seen some more vegetables and fruit.  I think some chefs believe giving meat, poultry or fish in every course is giving the patron their "money's worth" but I disagree.
author: Virginia T.

description:
If I hadn't gone to Kusakabe, I could have given Omakase more stars. 

Pros
- Server are attentive, and will fill your tea glass with hot tea.  :) 
- easy street parking, because of their location 

Cons
- $150 menu...you can get a better experience at Kusakabe
- One of the sushi chefs isn't Japanese, and it bothers me that his friends decided to stop by and yell "hello" and "we're waiting for you upstairs" from the foyer in Cantonese.  Oh my, I went to a Hong Kong flea market, not a 1-Michelin star restaurant.
- Sushi chef doesn't know flavors and didn't respect my wishes to minimize soy/nikiri sauce and Example: house-cured ikura is already salty, so drenching in nikiri/soy sauce is unnecessary.  Pairing the ikura with uni, the saltiness would be offset by uni's sweet and creaminess.
author: Bo W.

description: Pretty good , little pricy , still love it ! Should go try , every week sushi muni is different !
author: Kaiya X.

description:
My colleagues and I have been looking forward to trying this place since we were growing so curious of how this place was, plus it became a bit taunting with it being so close by to our office. When we had arrived, the interior was had a beautiful simplistic quality to it. I loved it. Once we got seated, we were offered a complimentary glass of champagne. Also, if you're carrying a backpack or purse, the waitress offers you this crate to use since it's tradition.

We had all opted for the $150 omakase since we all felt like it wasn't too little nor too much. Turns out all we got pretty full from the meal. There were 12 pieces of fresh nigiri and all sorts of delicious dishes. It was interesting when certain dishes came out we were instructed to eat from right to left. It was a great way to build up the intensity in your palate. Their sake selection was great too. I forget which bottle we had ordered, but it was very refreshing and had a subtle sweetness to it.

The whole experience was great and I'd definitely come for a special occasion since this is pricey, but if you're a sushi lover like myself then price does not matter. This was as close as to a 'Jiro Dreams of Sushi' experience that you can get in the US, so why not? It was really interesting to watch the chefs prepare each dish and how graceful they would treat each dish. Everything from the food, service and ambiance was great. Chef Jackson Yu was extremely generous to us as well. We chatted with him for a bit and he was just so friendly. Overall, it was an awesome dining experience and I would definitely come back again.
author: Connie C.

description:
Every step of this meal felt like perfection. We ordered the Yamato Omakase, aka the more expensive option, and the entire meal was a flavor-balanced dream.

Favorites included the tamago egg sushi and the steamed egg seafood cup as well as the nigiri. The quality of the fish is unparalleled, and even in a city like San Francisco with a lot of sushi competition, Omakase stands above the rest!

Come here for special occasions or just because. The service is impeccable, the chefs are skilled and friendly, and the experience is one you will not forget :)
author: Irene C.

description:
Two stars for the only decent and nothing amazing, overpriced meal.  

Came here for Valentine's Day dinner and even got their "special" $50 live uni.  Got about a total four pieces of a dead uni, 12 pieces of food (all pieces of fish were questionably small and taste was mediocre; I can't remember anything spectacular) and one bottle of sake.  The bill came out to over $500.  I guess I wanted a little more "wow" given all the hype here on Yelp. 

Any number of better establishments in SF, including Kusakabe and Wako can beat this place in taste, decor, and price.  Oh, and forgot to mention, nothing special about the decor, just like any regular sushi joint that serves California rolls and their "authentic" Japanese dishes that they serve my food on were chipped at the rim.  Only reason why this review gave two stars is because they delivered as expected service.
author: Lilian T.

description: I don't usually write reviews, but Omakase is one of the best sushi restaurants on the west coast. I prefer Omakase over Kusakabe any day of the week. Chef Jackson is an amazing chef and the quality of fish is comparable to Japan. Definitely my go to spot if I am craving legit sushi.
author: Jerry K.

description:
More and more of these establishments are opening up in San Francisco and it's really changing the Japanese food scene here in the city. No more fake Japanese rolls! 

Omakase has a skilled sushi chef who worked at a two-Michelin star restaurant in Ginza, so I know we were in good hands. Sure enough, the meal did not disappoint. Everything was well executed, using the freshest ingredients possible. The fish were flown in from Japan's famous Tsukiji fish market. 

What really blew me away was that although I've been to some of the best sushi restaurants in the world (Jiro's, Sushi Sawada, etc), I had something that I've never had before at Omakase. I had shiro ebi for the first time.. And boy, have I been missing out. It was in season and Chef Yu was kind enough to bring it out for us even though it was not a part of the pre fixe menu. I gotta say, I was wowed by the shiro ebi. Of course it didn't hurt that he topped it off with some mouthwatering uni and caviar. 

Very impressed with Chef Yu and Omakase. I'll probably go back and just order five orders of the shiro ebi and call it a day.
author: Lynn C.

description: Sushi should be served to start with the lightest then to gradual richer taste of fish, but here, one blander sushi after another bland one. And the waitress also recommended to us some uni from northern part of somewhere (did not understand the waitress),  being uni lovers,  we ordered it anyway along side with Hokkaido uni which is on the omakase menu. Turned out again it was blobs of watery bland taste uni, especially compared to Hokkaido uni which is always good, rich n aromatic. Big disappointment ! The fact that the premises purchased such low quality of product , sold it to customers for $50 an order, and served it along side with Hokkaido uni ? Omakase , supposedly the best choices from the chef, served at the right sequence !!  No, this restaurant has totally lost my respect.
author: Claire C.

description:
This place was alright... not worth the hype. The sushi chef's weren't all that friendly. The ambiance was alright. $8 for tea!!!!! What the...!!!! It's just tea!! The dinner took a total of 3.5 hours wayyy took freaking long.. everything took wayy tooo long. I would understand if a dish took 15 mins max to come out but a whole wohooping 30
Mins per a plate.... i am too inpatient for this. Oh i also had a bit of fish scale in my mouth! Not worth $600......take your money and spend it at the sister restaurant next door!
author: Eva L.

description: One word: overhyped. I've had way better sushi in San Francisco. I mean you pay for the environment right? You get free champagne when you walk in, very intimate setting and the decor reminds you of an authentic Japanese sushi place. The food doesn't speak for itself tho, I couldn't remember one single item that stood out. If you want to spend the same amount and get better sushi in SF, try Akkikos, Saru and Kusakabe. Good luck!
author: Sandy L.

description:
A 7-month old star. The place is somewhat hidden because it blends in with the shops on the street. They are next to starbucks and another sister sushi spot.

Since their menu changes daily or weekly. I can only review what I had that day. 

Upon entering this 14-seat establishment, we were warmly greeted with a complimentary sake. There are only 2 tables by the window, try to request a seat at the bar though. 

2 dinner menus are available- a $150 and $200 set. The difference between the 2 is that you get 4 more dishes- 2 pieces of fish (scallop and shrimp from japan), a large app dish and a soup dish with fish.

I had the $200 set with 2 bottles of Krug Brut Champagne. They only sell 1/2 bottles FYI and a glass is $55. The champagne went really well with all the fish. 

-White raw fish with turnip in a soy-ish sauce: the white fish was really fresh and had a slimy texture that I appreciated 
-Salad with a pepper and sauce- very very fresh veggies. Tasted like it was picked out of the garden out back. 
- Blue Tuna and white fish sashimi- This was like BUTEER! 2 pieces of each. I wish I got more of this.
- Uni Flan- Interesting texture and flavor combo. 
- 2 white fishes (not sure of the name but it comes with the $200 set only)- one was buttery and the other was crunchy. Interesting mix, loved this dish as well.
- Crab and cucumber- Plate cleanser. Very refreshing and a high quality piece of meat.
- Tuna with a sauce- 1st sashimi sushi piece. This is to die for! I wanted many many more of this. 
- white fish with ginger- very fresh and mild. a bit chewy 
- another white fish with sauce on top- great mixture of sauce and fish combo
- snapper with candied ginger- ohhh this was so good!
- mackerel with sauce- served warm and not fishy at all.
- red snapper- love the texture and mildness again.
- salmon- yummy! Smooth and like butter
- scallop- from japan.
- shrimp- from japan. 
- red fish-  mild, simple and fresh
-  tuna with green topping- just like the 1st piece, cannot get enough.
- Uni with rice and eggs- a good portion size where you will be satisfied.
- egg- I could have passed on this one. I prefer the egg from Pabu.
- Fish in soup- I could have passed on this one as well.

Dessert- Sorbet 

I wish there was more then 1 desert dish.

Over all 5 for service and food. The price is very reasonable for the quality of fish your getting.

Will be back.
author: Carrie Y.

description: Such an incredible experience. From the hostess and servers, to the extremely talented chef we had, it was by far one of the best omakase dinners I've had! I recommend the 20 course. The sashimi pieces will change your life!!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Pros: everything was perfectly executed. Came out very full and satisfied. 
Cons: none

Only the best ingredients are used, and the attention to detail was just amazing. The food itself is just delicious. Everyone at the sushi bar agreed that it would simply be impossible to go back to conventional sushi after this experience. Chef Jackson is super entertaining as well. He is clearly well versed in all the ingredients, where they come from, how the fish are raised or caught. Example, certain fish are flown in within 40 hours of it being caught and arrives to the restaurant and served fresh. 

The dragon fish also made an appearance, and apparently comes from a part of Japan where they have the deepest and coldest waters. (This attributes to the flavor of the fish). To boot, it is very difficult to catch. Because of its rarity, it is an a la carte item, and does not guarantee that it will be in stock regularly. 

Overall, it is by far, the best dining experience in my life and worth the price. I doubt I could afford to go there regularly, but if you enjoy sushi, this is a must try.
author: Juliana L.

description:
I recently went to Omakase and i can say that it's up there with Zushi Puzzle as the best sushi in San Francisco. 

A bit pricey but worth it.
author: Jesse F.

description:
This place is delicious but their sushi are hit and miss. I do feel like this place is an imitation of Kusakabe bit they haven't quite hit on the head. I'm tempted to give 3 stars but since I've only been here once, I'm giving the benefit of the doubt. I do wish this place creates an identity of their own. 
 Here's my break-down

FOOD: fish is fresh. Definitely delicious pieces but some were a miss. I think the menu can use some tweaks. Is it Michelin star worthy? Yes, but there's a thin line between 1 star and no star for this place.  

Environment: cozy and quiet. Nice place. Limited seating so book in advance! 

Chefs: not as personable as other sushi places but not rude or anything. 

I would recommend this place.
author: t.s. and r.s. x.

description: I had planned an outing to Omakase before going to Tokyo, which may or may not have been a good decision.  It's become almost tradition that we go out for sushi for Greg's birthday dinner (last year was Kusakabe), but no matter where we were going to go, the inevitable fate of comparing SF sushi to Tokyo sushi was going to happen.  That being said, Omakase does a great job at putting in the effort to making sure you get an authentic experience despite being in Potrero Hill and right by Zynga's headquarters.  We sat at the sushi bar (which needs to be requested during the rez making process - there are two side tables off the sushi bar) and got to see all the live action up close.  We both opted for the $150 omakase option, which was probably the right choice given how fast we were consuming the sushi and all the other delicious appetizers and dessert.  Our Tokyo-born sushi chef was incredibly personal and made a few jokes along the way to ease the tension that sometimes exists in sushi bar settings. I REALLY enjoyed the glass of champagne that was given to us after sitting down, and also really enjoyed the pace in which we were given our food.  Pausing only take a few photos, I'd say that we ate at a fairly "Tokyo" pace where we went through our meal fairly quickly compared to our fellow diners.  I appreciated that our sushi chef observed our pace and took it into consideration when serving us. We had some fantastic nigiri pieces, the highlights being the non-standard fish that were served like the needlefish, but the traditional pieces like the tuna was delicious.  I enjoyed the lobster miso soup at the end, and the very light mango sorbet with sake was a perfect way to end dinner.  All in all, Omakase was creative without being over the top, which seems to place it somewhere in the middle between the crazy/chaotic atmosphere of ICHI and the serene and subtle scene of Kusakabe.  Sure Omakase is a little pricey, and if forced to make a decision, I would say that I prefer the more quieter experience in Kusakabe, but Omakase was definitely a fantastic dinner that's well-deserving of its Michelin star. Definitely fish for Michelin stars here :)
author: Lisa I.

description: Came here for the second time last weekend. This time with my mom and sister (in addition to my boyfriend). Again, 10/10 experience! We previously visited maybe a couple of months after opening. They have now refined their menu a bit, and there are a little more offering in addition to the nigiri. Also, on top of the 14 people bar seating, they've also added a couple of tables that seat two. The menu comes with a few "appetizers" in the beginning, including a sashimi dish, a chawan dish, and a couple of small bits with seafood, followed by nigiri, and end with a dessert dish (they previously didn't have dessert but now they do!). My family is from the same city as Chef Jackson, so we had a great time conversing (again). I caught up with the chef regarding my subsequent sushi experience in the city (tried out Wako a couple of months ago, on top of Kusakabe earlier last year before visiting Omakase for the first time) but prefer the quality of fish at Omasake. My mom was very happy trying all the different fish that are shipped straight from the Tsukiji market. My sister usually hates wasabi, but given the wasabi and sauce are added with the appropriate amount before serving, it just adds to the experience. Toro/Chutoro/Hokkaido Uni were some of the highlights of the nigiri, but man, the tamagoyaki! I'm always impressed by how amazing these tamagoyaki are, tastes just like egg! I was very full at the end of the meal, and the service was impeccable. We've now visited Kusakabe, Wako, and Omakase, and would rank: Omakase, Wako, and Kusakabe in that order. Omakase does have a slightly higher price point, but we prefer to have the fish to speak for itself in terms of quality (Wako tends to have more cooked stuff). We also prefer fish raw or only lightly cooked. The service at Omakase is also the best out of the three (maybe because I've gotten to know the chef and staff here much better). Kusakabe was fine but we didn't find the experience to stand out amongst the rest. Overall, a well deserved Michelin star, great experience, and amazing service. We'll definitely be back soon (again)!
author: Sharon L.

description:
I have to be honest - I was SUPER nervous going into this meal. When it comes to sushi, I stick to what I know (mild white fish, tuna, etc.), and I'm pretty unwilling to try anything outside of my comfort zone.

That said, when my husband and I decided to try Omakase, I made a promise to myself that (for at least $150/pp) I'd at least try everything that was put in front of me.

I did, and I'm so glad.

It turns out I do not like uni or monk fish...but I tried them, so now I can actually say I don't like them...and it turns out I like just about everything else. I am of course, taking my new found love affair with strange and exotic fish from around the world, with a grain of salt. The fish at Omakase was so incredibly fresh, and so thoughtfully prepared, I can honestly say I've never seen or eaten anything like it.

We sat at the sushi counter, and it was so incredible to watch each course prepared. The chef was so talented, and answered all of our questions without hesitation (we had quite a few).

As expensive as this meal was, it was hand's down worth every penny. From watching them prepare your meal, to indulging in some of the most high quality ingredients we've ever had, to the absolutely over-the-top perfect service...Omakase really hits it out of the park.

I can't wait to go back!
author: Carrie W.

description: Hands down best sushi I have ever had in my whole life! Great experience here with the chefs on valentines day! came in with handwritten cards of all the couples attending the restaurant and they gave out a rose too! I am not sure if i remember what I ate but everything was damn delicious. Thank you chef jackson for the great experience! i definitely will be back!!!
author: Ben Z.

description:
Omakase is hands down my absolute favorite restaurant. I've been living in SF for 2 years now and have tried most of the highly rated restaurants (Michelin restaurants like Benu and Gary Danko included), and Omakase still wins as my #1 choice. The seating arrangement is extremely intimate and the sushi chefs have great personalities and knowledge of what the best quality of fish is during the season. Since its opening in the summertime, I have dined at Omakase three times! That averaged about once every 2 months! Every piece of fish is perfectly cut so that it has the right texture of smoothness and butteriness as it enters your mouth. The menu of fish changes depending what the best catch from the famous Tsukiji fish market in Japan is. I have gone so often that the sushi chefs there now know me by first name basis! If you are a sushi fan, absolutely try Omakase. It will redefine the way you eat sushi. Now I never eat sushi anywhere else. :P 

Details about dining experience:
There are two omakase options: the $150 or $200. I have a smaller stomach and so usually opt for the $150, but ask the waitress what the extra items you get in the $200 option is! If you are like my boyfriend and can eat more, I highly recommend the $200 meal. 

Every meal starts with a complimentary glass of champagne and a couple of starter items. Usually there are two starter items to open your palette. I like to also order the tea because it goes extremely well with the sushi. Then the fish assembly and sushi art begins. The chefs will take out freshly cut slices of fish and create the sushi right in front of you. At the end of the meal, you get a delicious shrimp miso broth and mango sorbet.
author: Lydia H.

description:
Bauer reviewed Omakase and said it was the freshest fish in the city. It might be, but for the $$$ they charge, its got some unexpected flaws.  

Pros:
- fresh quality fish
- well executed cuts
- parking was easy on Sunday night
- intimate environment with chefs
- complimentary champagne
- two kinds of toro

Cons
- owner packs the seats in REALLY tight to the point that it was hard to eat comfortably
- for $$$ the diversity in the seafood was lacking, $100 omakase in almost all other japanese restaurants in SF would have more than just fish, no uni, no ankimo, no ama ebi.  These aren't the priciest items.  Saving these for the $150 menu makes the $150 menu makes the restaurant seem overpriced.

Explanatory comments:
- diners paying $100-$200/pp don't expect the chairs to be so close that i'm shoulder to shoulder, elbow to elbow with other customers.  The space is so tight, it was hard to eat with chopsticks and made for uncomfortable eating.  This isn't tokyo nor tsukuji fish market where space is at a premium.  If you want to pack in customers and make a lot of $ I understand that, but at this price point, you're already making $, it's about the experience at this price point.
- service was decent, servers tried to pour our beer in nice cups, but the servers have never drank beer, because the pours were all foam.  This is a lack of training in the wait staff. 

Overall Rating:  3.5*s  I want this restaurant to succeed, the diversity in fish was excellent, however, there's some unexpected flaws that should be resolved before they can truly be at the highest level.
author: Paul C.

description:
Service is great but the food doesn't live up to expectations. Rice could be better. 

Dessert and uni were good though.
author: Moko R.

description: Really is a 3.5 due to the experience but food is good. This place is not cheap. It will def break the bank. We ordered an ala carte uni it was some of the damn best ive ever had. When my bf reserved this place he assumed our dinner wld be at the bar..since it isss an omakase place. But for some odd reason there are two random tables to the side! Though the food was good i felt our experience was dampened by not being able to sit at the bar with the chefs. Instead of enjoying piece by piece and interacting with the chefs, our nigiris came in plates of 3 and served by waitresses in kimonos. It didnt feel like we had the whole omakase experience..but def paid the price. We were also peeved by the hostess bc she insisted that we were told we wld not be at the bar when we made the reservation bc their ipad had said so. No girl. Just bc someone checked your ipad doesnt mean we were told of the seating arrangement.
author: Wing L.

description: WOW. The fish here is TOP quality and so fresh. Dining here was an experience - not just a meal. The service was very attentive and accommodating. They have little compartments for your purse and even offered to coat check our warm winter coats. The sushi chef was very friendly and willing to chat us up and explain what we were eating and the proper way to enjoy it. The flavor profiles and creations were so unique and creative (truffle oils etc) I would very much recommend this place for a date night or special occasion.
author: Leilani B.

description: Always wanted to try this place out and I finally did! Our chef Jackson was amazing. Every piece of fish was super buttery and fresh, can't complain about the quality. Yes it's a pricey dinner but I think it's worth it! You're paying for the experience & Jackson definitely made a memorable one.
author: Julie H.

description:
FIRST AND FOREMOST:
There's a big difference between "going out to dinner" and "having a dining experience."

THAT SAID:
Omakase represents the latter.

BETTER STILL:
They have created a lovely, rarefied and authentic Japanese experience. It's completely immersive. The place is tiny. The Japanese servers are attentive and charming. The chefs are skillful and engaging. And of course the menu is absolutely pristine.

IN BRIEF:
It's exactly as advertised: small bites of luxurious imported sashimi, nigiri and maki. They serve up some very original presentations, like a tiny and remarkably flavorful uni-don and a tekka-maki that is so delicious and simple it elevates the sushi roll to a whole new level.

SO:
It ain't cheap. And if you're the 24-ounce steak-with-potato-and-veggie-side kind of eater, be prepared, because this meal isn't that. Although after the set menu, you can order more if your appetite demands and budget allows. But if you can let the chefs guide your experience and allow every bite to be a universe unto itself, you're in for a treat.
author: Richard L.

description:
My wife and I love sushi, and we're big fans of Yume in Alameda, which also does omakase, so we NEEDED to try this restaurant out, and we're very happy that we did.  We booked the reservations for her birthday at least a couple months in advance without any issues.  At the time of booking, this restaurant had 1 Michelin star, and by December 2015, it had 2 stars - something I think is worth mentioning.

The restaurant is small (as expected) with their limited seating (similar to Yume), so that wasn't a surprise for us.  Service was excellent as the staff were all very attentive and mindful of what was going on.  The chef noticed I'm left-handed, so anything that came out with a utensil was placed on the left hand side; minor detail, but something that I very much appreciated.

Food-wise, everything was amazing.  Everything tasted fresh, delicate, balanced, and just melts in your mouth.  The selection they have is very wide and maybe not so surprisingly, they have tasteful choices of everything including mackerel and uni  - both of which my wife isn't very fond of, but she actually enjoyed them here after a bit of hesitation.

So is this place better than Yume? Yes, but it does come with the higher price tag, so you get what you pay for.  I highly recommend this to fellow East Bay folks who are fans of Yume to try this place out.  It won't disappoint.
author: Vinh N.

description: Finally got around to dining here again, and I still think very highly of this place (many things consistent with my initial review). One of the key aspects that differentiates this place for me is the attentiveness and hospitality of the whole crew in my two visits. Will be back in the future!
author: Gore S.

description: So much food, directly imported from Japan too.  The quality of the uni... I can taste the ocean!  The fish on the nigiri is so buttery and tasty.  Jackson, the friendly humorous sushi chef creates wonderful masterpieces that just goes down so smoothly.  The soup and the ice cream ended the meal beautifully.   Yum, will recommend all of my friends to eat here!
author: Kenney C.

description: We went here last year after opening and it was amazing. We went again in October 2016 for our anniversary and the food was average and far overpriced for this level of dining.  The sushi and dishes were saturated with sauces and 'killed' the flavors. Service in response was apologetic but insufficient.
author: Craig L.

description:
I came here recently in a group of 4 for dinner at 9pm on a Thursday night. Even at 9pm, this place was completely full. We all ordered the $150 omakase menu (there are only 2 choices: $150 or $200). Overall, I thought the nigiri was super fresh -- my favorites were the salmon, toro, and several mackerel varieties. While it is a bit pricey (especially if you include tax and tip), I believe it's still worth trying if you're craving high end sushi in the city. The chefs and waitstaff are also super attentive and friendly.

-L.
author: Leeann C.

description:
I don't usually write reviews, but this place is just insane.  The tiger behind the counter just knows how to serve sushi.  I took my foodie friend to dine with the tiger, and he thinks that the tiger serves better sushi then the sushi that he got a Tsukiji market...and he just came back from Tokyo, the prior day.

Dining at Omakase was nothing short of magical!  Ok, maybe it's the sake talking.  But in all seriousness, I tasted uni, hotate, kampachi and maguro before, and fish (or shell fish) is fish!  But this is what's magical about it....the uni was sweet as mango, the texture on the hotate has more bite then usual, the kampachi just melts in my mouth like it was ice cream!  Last, he serve us the maguro.  Looking at the part, it looks like one of that tough part where you just chew and chew and chew.  But this wasn't.  It was smooth as the fresh snow powder on top of the the Alps just begging you to put on your ski and skid downhill.

Case and point, the last piece that we ate was the tamago yaki.  I'm not much of a fan of tamago yaki, in fact, I would usually turn my nose up side and skip it.  Yet, somehow, I find it in my heart to take the piece into my mouth and really tasted it.  I'm glad I did it...the tamago yaki was well balance between sweetness and saltiness.  At some point, I sat there, chewing on the piece while I searched my soul and questioned myself if I had define these two flavors that I had known since the passing of my grandmother.

So if you are still reading this review, one small advice that I want to give to future diners.  Fish is...fish.  But be nice to the tiger behind the counter.  Load him up with good sake, and tell him to do his magic!  Tell him bring out all...I mean ALL that the knowledge that he managed to learned in the painstaking years of mastering his craft.  And you will leave the restaurant pondering...how did he do that???

Last, a few pointers...service could be refined.  There seems to be a lack in...how can I say this...wabi sabi.  Things that came out of the kitchen can be a hit or miss.  For instance the tamago yaki...man, you hit it out of the ball park.  The miso soup...temperature was off.  I mean I learned from dating numerous Japanese girls, don't screw up on the miso soup.  Period.
author: Jonathan S.

description:
We were a bit disappointed with our last visit.  What happened???  I notice if I go back a few pages on Yelp, I am not the only one recently disappointed!  BTW, why does Yelp bury so many of the not so good reviews?

For such a high cost, we expected fancy something!!!! Nothing really was. Not the fish nor the presentation.  The fish was not premium either.  To be truthful, we both were a bit shocked.  Last time we were served this fancy conch shell filled with conch, shrimp and lobster.  Even though it turns out I do not like conch, visually it was quite impressive. No fireworks this visit. None.  Visits before that I really can't remember the specifics but they were good enough to prompt more visits. 

When your omakase costs so much more than any other omakase experience in the city, you need to amaze!  We just were not amazed.

Our sushi chef was great.  The service excellent.  The fish very good just not great.

Kusakabe remains our true love!
author: Kell M.

description:
Absolutely love this place! Jackson is awesome, food delicious, staff friendly, and experience well worth it. I highly recommend. We did the $150 omakase and was stuffed. They made a nice sign and candle dessert for my friend's birthday. They also let us go behind the bar to take a picture which was very nice.

Would definitely come back!
author: Amy N.

description:
Sat at the bar with a co-worker and we picked the $150 course.  Dining experience was excellent, the fish was very good.  Chatted with the chef about the fish, various add on ingredients and etiquette.

4 stars for the total experience, maybe 3.5 for just the food.  I think the only negative was the price for what we got;  I've had similar sushi experiences in Japan for much less, but I suppose for local eats, this is all we can get.

For food photographers, it looks like the place can get very dark, especially in winter, since the sun goes down so early.
author: ninpou k.

description: This place is definitely worth every penny. Jackson was a delight to have as my chef.
author: Jimmy P.

description: By far the best omakase tasting menu we have ever had. We would fly back to SF only for another meal at Omakase.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Dining at Omakase was a wonderful experience. I took my bf here for his birthday dinner and he loved it.

Be sure to book a reservation in advance. Spots fill up quickly and the place only seats 12 people per night. They offer you complimentary champagne. There was a fly that flew into my champagne and without hesitation the woman in a kimono replaced it right away. We both opted for the $150 and ended up being really full. I couldn't even finish the last course of our meal. You get what you pay for - high quality, fresh, melt in your mouth fish along with great service. Eating at Omakase now scarred me dining at not so high end quality sushi spots, oh no! 

We will be back!
author: Therese F.

description: Omakase was fun and a wonderful dining experience. There are two different price point, $150 or $200 pp. Definatly a special occasion dinner.
author: Teresa L.

description:
Omakase, an unimaginative name, but delivers exactly what the name suggests.  There are two options, $150 and $200, and we opted for $150 choice.  

All the dishes, from light lobster appetizers to a nice variety of nigiris, from the decadent and generous portion of uni to the very light and refreshing mango sorbet, were exactly what I'd expect from a restaurant of this caliber.  The most outstanding dish was the sea bream nigiri, smoky from being lightly torched and fatty from its natural texture, was really special and delicious.  Wish we had ten more of those. 

I liked that we were asked if we'd like to dial up or down on the wasaki level in the nigiris.  I was able to taste the fish themselves rather than simply clearing up my nostrils after the first set of nigiri.  

Beautiful presentations, efficient service, full belly after the courses --- there is really nothing to complain about.
author: Candice B.

description:
My hub and I definitely enjoyed coming here and most of the food was amazing.  Their service is top notch and I definitely recommend this place for the experience.

The reason why I give 4 stars is because the food was not perfect.  I was expecting perfection from Omakase and I don't think that's asking too much.

When I was in Tokyo last time, we walked into some random "kai-ten zushi" and I must say, their sushi was so much better.  That makes me sad. (And we paid 1/3 of the price...)
author: EriCardo F.

description: Recently had dinner and had just an ok time.  For those who are looking for mainly nigiri omakase (me), this place is not for you.  Yes, you get 12 pieces of very, very good nigiri sushi pieces but I prefer to have even more, or just all for dinner.  The sashimi and other items were just ok.  Also, for the price, you can get a lot more at other sushi joints.  Although the service and decor were impeccable, I will not come here again, mainly due to the limited sushi pieces and price.
author: Joe P.

description: NO-makase.  The quality is ok, but the price is not justifiable.  Kusakabe is far, far better.    Actually many places at a fraction of the price could compete with the quality.     Won't be back.
author: Robert P.

description: First time at this restaurant and had a great experience. Small unique place (18 seats total) with awesome service. There's 2 set menus. My friend and I choose the $200 menu and it's worth it. Everything is so fresh. By far, this is one of the best sushi restaurants I've been to in San Francisco. Our chef, Andy, was super nice and friendly. Chef told us that if we like something we had and want to have the same item again, we can always ask them to make more; that's good to know. I will definitely come back to this restaurant again. FYI, you will need to make reservations and cancel within 72hrs and I don't think they take any walk-ins.
author: Cindy W.

description: I had chef Jackson tonight and he was great. He show me and my girlfriend what kind of fish he cutting and how he cutting it so we know what kind is good. I would recommend all my friends to come here to eat and drink. I would come back and eat here again. I want to thank chef Jackson and his crew again for the best experience!!
author: Wilson L.

description: Incredible food. You will be extremely full at the end of your meal. Be sure to pace yourself. Worth the
author: Ernest H.

description:
Sushi was a disappointment, but this place might work for business meals when ambiance, presentation and the title are more appreciated than sushi itself. It's definitely a beautiful space. 

My chef was not Jackson Yu unfortunately. Maybe that's one of reasons sushi was not special at all or rather not good. Sushi can taste very different depending on who actually does the last job even if they use the same block of fish meat and the same bowl of sushi rice.  But it's a Michelin Star restaurant. Skills of chefs shouldn't be too different.

Pros:
- uni chawanmushi (egg custard pudding with sea urchin) was one of the best I've ever eaten in my life.
- a dish of uni and ikura (sea urchin and salmon roe) was delicious.
- presentation of appetizers and miso soup are beautiful/creative.
- their sake list is relatively small but has great selection.
- server knows sake on the list and what she suggested was exactly I described.
- their sake cup (for sake you order) is unique and it makes sake taste better. 
- the place is very clean and beautifully decorated. 
- service is excellent. 

Cons:
- sushi was not tasty. 
- they don't have any additional sushi other than the ones in omakase menu (chef's choice). So all you can do to eat more sushi is to go back to what you had.
author: Akiko O.

description:
Definitely a 'special occasion' place, and now that the positively RAVE review by Michael Bauer was published (for once I am in agreement with him), you'll have to book ahead.  We lucked out and got a reservation same-day, last week as we realized a certain special occasion was already upon us before we realized it ...

Each bite is balanced in flavor and texture.  Each plate is beautiful.  Service is flawless.  Atmosphere is intimate, a little hushed, yet convivial.  

We had an amazing experience.  Highly recommend.
author: Jaina S.

description: Chef and owner Jackson Yu prepared the best sushi experience ever! The service, quality, and experience was first rate. Will be back for special occasions time and time again.
author: Rona m.

description:
I really wish I could give this place a higher rating but it's just not worth it. I think this is the last time I do a meal in SoMa or Mission area, the company just ruins the experience 
The food was 4 stars, very fresh, very fun to watch prepared. Hand ground wasabi, rock salt ground from blocks in front of us. The details were amazing, the chef literally doing surgery on the squid to remove any inedible parts, extraordinary attention for just the intro appetizer. There were some misses, sashimi clam and lobster bland and chewy, the uni not as flavorful as others I have had, dessert also bland
it's just not worth 200$, for the food alone I expected to be blown away. The decor is bland and the space is right next to another sushi restaurant so the sense of this being something unique just isn't so.
but more than anything the company in the restaurant killed it
We were unfortunately seated next to a young couple incessantly photographing their food with flash and posting all over FB and loudly taking  about it and looking at things on their phone. They did so many things that were hysterical in a fancy restaurant that I won't even bother to write about but needless to say this was not what I was expecting in such an establishment
Turns out they are friends of the young owner who came over and just ordered one fancy sake after another and had the most obnoxious conversation right next to me. I thought the conversation hit a low with them comparing how fancy their cars were and bragging about a launch party complete with a limo and suite at the four seasons. But then the man started bragging about his trips to the Philippines and the gentleman's clubs he frequents and call girls he travels all over with when he goes.
From the other reviews you realize I was not spying on them but rather sitting up against them, trying to enjoy my husbands birthday in a very small space
I even asked the woman nicely to stop using flash photos(she would take about 5 pictures of every dish) since it was really distracting, she promptly forgot this and did it the rest of the evening.
I keep trying to make the best of this, after all I was dropping 500$ for my husbands birthday. But every time I got out in SoMa or Mission now I realize this city is unrecognizable and if I am going to fancy it up no way will I do it in a place that seems to be started by and catering to crowds like this
author: Tami R.

description: AWesome experience! Thanks Jackson!!! Michelin Star well deserved!
author: Thomas C.

description: My husband and I dined here about two weeks ago for the first time.  We only made the reservation two-days in advance so did not get one of those seats by the bar. Nevertheless the experience was wonderful- great food, great service. Highly recommended!
author: Jude Z.

description:
I think that it is my best omakase so far
A whole meal 
12 nigiri 
2 appetizers 
2 sashimi 
Desert 
Soup with cod 
And more 
All top quality 
$200 
Worth the high cost
author: Gal R.

description:
I'm not a sushi snob by choice.  I never really even liked sushi much until I tried some really fresh, high quality stuff, so it says a lot that I really love this place.

The freshness, presentation, and service is on par with, if not better than, some of my faves.

If you love authentic sushi (don't use your chopsticks, cut off half of your rice, ask for soy sauce, etc..) and impeccable service, definitely check out Omakase.

I visited when they first opened and now that I've come around to adding my review, I really want to go back.
author: steve c.

description: I give it 4 stars instead of 5 because San Francisco omakase market is very very competitive. Lots of great places with very fresh, rare, and luxury sushi. I had the $150 omakase with appetizers and 10 pieces of nigiri, they were all very fresh and really good quality sushi, but nothing was more outstanding than other highly rated places in the city. Not sure if it was worth the $150. But all that being said, it was still a really good dining experience, and great sake selection, and I really liked the small size of the restaurant
author: Shannon J.

description: This place is the best sushi I have had in the greater sf Bay Area, Jackson the chef makes amazing sushi and is a fun guy to chat with while eating and very well worth the price I highly recommend this restaurant
author: Kevin L.

description: Wow, just wow, freshest and most beautiful fish I've ever had!  Had a chance to eat here when they first opened.  Sat directly in front of the head chef and just sat and enjoyed dish after dish of amazing food.  Aside from the beauty of the plates the tastes were clean and delicious.  The decor was nice as well, very clean and modern.  The plates were gorgeous and each one for the 16 courses were different.  I also loved the different Sake glasses they used.  All in all a great experience.  I recommend the large menu because go big or go home.  The only thing I wish they had when I went was the menu written out because it's hard to remember all the great things I ate and I want to brag to everyone! I guess that's hard when the menu can change nightly.  Great place to bring an out of town friend, someone you love for a special occasion or just a great night out to treat yourself and feel special!  Take a look at my pics, they speak for themselves :)j
author: Kanoa B.

description: Amazing food, service, and company. From the moment you touch the front door, you will be welcome with exceptional service. This place made me feel like a princess. From the coat basket to wiping the drops of sauce on your plate, the servers here are attentive and knowledgeable. It's the little details that matters to me and it really shows that Omakase have a high standard for diners. The ambiance of this place is nice and quiet. I really like their decors and their choice of tableware. The server had a lot of patience with me in explaining their extensive sake menu as well as their omakase choices. If you have a question, just ask them! They will come back with an answer. I even asked them about their decorations on their shelf, lol. As for the food, it was melt in your mouth amazing. My girlfriend and I both opted for the yamato omakase along with the sake pairing. We also added the fresh special of the day, which was called "Dragon fish". I have to say the sake pairing is a must get with the omakase because you get to try a variety of expensive sake and the sake really brings out the flavor of the food. It was also very entertaining watching the sushi chef prepare our food in front of us and you can definitely tell these chefs have experience+skills. At the end of our meals, we were both stuffed and gleaming with happiness. I will definitely return next time as this place is now one of my favorite omakase restaurant. Also their sister restaurant next door called Okane is a must try as well! Overall, I would like to say thank you Omakase for fulfilling my stomach, until next time. ;)
author: Amy T.

description:
Best Sushi Experience Ever!!!!

If you want fresh sushi from all over the planet excellently prepared by a master chef then this is the place for you. There are many good sushi joints in town and this is a quantum leap above all of them.  Chew slowly and experience the magic.
author: James M.

description: This restaurant is the best sushi restaurant I have ever been to. The fish and sushi are extremely fresh and delicious. The staffs are very friendly. Definitely recommend this place!
author: Theresa N.

description:
An intimate evening filled with stunning dish after dish.  My partner and I decided to do the Hideaki Omakase fixed-price tasting menu at $150.00/person.  It was well worth the price tag - everything from the service, timeless and classic decor, and food was resplendent. They even utilize a blow torch at many points throughout the meal, but it is truly understated elegance at its best.  

At first, the quiet and organized atmosphere can be slightly off-putting, but once your secretly cool waitress breaks the ice, relaxation is in store.  My partner and I had a wonderful evening and look forward to returning.
author: Thomas P.

description:
This was a very special and caring way to experience sushi. The chef has a great and whimsical personality that comes out once engaged regarding the dishes. The fish is superbly handled and it's freshness is unquestionable. The service rings traditional Japanese. Overall the experience is exceptional. 
Thank you for taking care of us tonight, we will savor the flavors and will make our way back.
author: Karolina S.

description: 3 of us went to Omakase last week to celebrate all of us September babies! The service was grand and the food was amazing!!! We all chose the $200 option and even added eel nigiri in the end. Everything was bombbb!!! They also gave us a cute orchid to take home for our bday & we even got a picture with the chefs so that was a plus! It's not a place I can go regularly though because it'd def break the bank.
author: Michelle L.

description:
A great date-night place and one of the best sushi we've ever had!

The ambiance was inviting, intimate, and unpretentious. The restaurant has limited seating so it doesn't feel crowded or loud. You can actually carry a conversation with your dinner companion.  The setting is in such a way that you could also talk with the chef and learn about the fishes and the dishes -- which were absolutely delicious and plated beautifully. 

There were many standouts from the 18 course meal, but sadly I can't remember the names of the fishes except 2 (Monk fish foie gras  (my fav) & flying fish) and of course the one I wasn't crazy about (Mackerel - didn't like it as a kid and looks like I'm not changing my mind.) 

Finally, the service was impeccable. These ladies were like ninjas dressed in kimonos -- around when you needed them and out of sight when you didn't!  I also appreciated how the hostess took my purse and coat and put it away for me -- something I can definitely get used to! (It's my pet peeve when I have no place to put my things!)

If you're into great sushi and a little fearless -- because you don't know what will be put in front of you -- then this is the place to go! We will certainly go back!
author: J S.

description: Have been trying out different restaurants for omakase recently. Very disappointed for this one. their fishes  are definitely not for this level.  Kind of chewy and doesn't has the fresh taste.
author: Athena W.

description: Great dining experience, great food! First of all the chefs were friendly and fun, engaging us throughout our dinner to explain about the ingredients. It was a total of 3 hours dinner as we took our time and the chefs were relax, letting us enjoy our food and of course photo session. Will definitely recommend if you love sushi and sashimi.
author: Claudia L.

description: I used to hate raw fish until I tried out Omakase. The fish was incredibly fresh (the most amazing toro I've even eaten). But what I loved most about this place was the service. The waitress was friendly and had a sense of humor. It was great watching the Omakase interact with one another - you can tell they actually like each other and strive to maintain a wonderful dining experience. Would totally fine here again.
author: Melinda C.

description: Great experience overall - one of the best omikase experiences I've ever had. Everything was extremely fresh, very creative and there was plenty of it. To top off the fresh fish flown in every other day from Japan, they have a great sake collection and are not bashful about sharing. They're strict about their reservation time-slots and ask for a credit card to hold them but it makes sense once you see that it's a small space, they need to schedule and budget accordingly. It's worth every penny and any sushi fans and out there should lock up a reservation ASAP.
author: Shaun W.

description:
What a great experience. My wife and I went to Omakase and tried their $150 menu. Such a treat to start with a glass of Krug Champagne. The food was phenomenal and the fish was so fresh. We tried some new fishes that we have not tried before and I love how they pace your meal. It was just the right amount of food for us. We drank more champagne (one of my favorite Ruinart Rose) and some sake. Their Sake selection was great and the quality of the sake we chose was so good.
Service from our lady server was perfect, she always came at the right moment. Our Sushi Chef, Jackson, was so great as well. He is funny and really know his fish. His knife skills are very impressive. 

Some of the highlight were, the Japanses Foie Gras (Fish liver) and the Uni Dish. The other fish were super good too but I could not remember the name.

This new restaurant is perfect for a great special occasion. It made our date night so enjoyable.
author: G R.

description: Good food, good vibe, good chief. The food is great, the service is wonderful. It is the best experience for me.  definitely going back soon
author: Nocc S.

description: Delicious sushi, chef is very skilled. Fish from Tsukiji market in Tokyo. An amazing experience.
author: Edith M.

description: Amazing sashimi and nigiri! Can't believe we have never been here before. We went for the Yamato Omakase, and everything was superb. This is hands down better than Wako.
author: Eve C.

description: Comparing to the Maruya and Kusukabe, the fishes here are fresh and have high quality as same as those two places, but you will feel full after finishing the courses. I met chef Masa who left from Maruya last year. He is currently working here to help his friend (I believe chef Jackson). He made the sushi for me. All pieces were amazing. Some of them were melting in my mount especially Iwashi (sardine) and Kinmedai (golden-eye red snapper) and Toro. I will definitely come back again. For now it is easy to make a reservation, but it will be hard to get the reservation easily soon.
author: Aniwat A.

description: I dream of Jackson! He did it again but this time he took a dream team along with him. Chefs from the best of the best work together to create a tantalizing melt in your mouth experience. The presentation is beautiful and you will not leave hungry. The lobster is a must!
author: T W.

description:
Omakase is not just a foodies dream but an experience. The restaurant is small but the attention to both the layout and detail is apparent in every square inch of the space. Even the plateware is unique and blends antiques with modern artistic design.

The service is excellent and seeing Chef Jackson in his element is always a treat. 

The flavors and freshness of the fish are indescribable and only add to the high level Omakase is operating at.

My boyfriend and I are looking forward to visiting again soon :-)
author: Mariel H.

description: This is the best sushi resturant in San Francisco the fish is so fresh and tasty I will be coming back..
author: Mabel K.

description:
Absolutely worth going! 

Not only the omakase was great, the chef that made our sushi was so funny and fun to talk to. 

It was a great culinary experience all around and worth every penny.
author: Danielle A.

description: We came to Omakase for New Year's Eve and they were serving complimentary champagne! The highlights of the dinner were the scallop and lobster sashimi, the kyoto style nigiri (super cute) and the freshness of all the fish! Unfortunately, I was a little disappointed about the uni I was looking forward to. It was served with house marinated ikura, which imo covered up the uni's nature goodness with the salty flavor. Everything else was tasty, and the squid is probably the best I've had. They scored it so finely and dressed it with lemon juice and seasoning perfectly. Also, the mango sorbet with sake at the end was the perfect refreshing ending to a great dinner.
author: Gillian H.

description: A true 5 star Japanese sushi restaurant. The 10 piece negiri menu was incredible. Spectacular service. Pricey but worth it!
author: Carl N.

description: Really happy a fine sushi dining experience is now in SF but I must admit I was a bit underwhelmed. I went not that hungry and so opted for the $100 meal. It wasn't much food and the $200 long meal seemed a bit tiresome. We were not sitting at the bar, which may have detracted a lot given how everyone on Yelp raves about being ringside. Next time I spend that much on a meal, it'll be at Gary Danko.
author: Shira L.

description: Came here with my boyfriend for a treat. The meal was great and everything was superbly fresh, but I left a bit disappointed as I imagined a more creative dining experience that just quality fish. If you're looking for a traditional meal with melt-in-your-mouth fish, I'd highly recommend this place.
author: Christina C.

description: Very pricey but the experience is flawless. You'll immediately forget that you're a few doors down from a Starbucks in the Design District. The service is impeccable and the attention to detail is impressive. Even the bowls and sake cups were something to appreciate. Food is excellent, as expected. They did prep some lobsters in front of us, so beware if you are squeamish.
author: Tina W.

description:
ho-lee-crapppppp!!  i had heard about this place from some friends that live in the city, and i decided to bring my gf here on our vacation from socal..... and we were both pretty blown away by the quality and friendliness of the chefs!  in LA, we are spoiled by tons of these sushi bars with 10-15 seats, but if you put this joint in socal, it would be some stiff competition.  

this is definitely something SF needed, and im glad we found it!  i cant even tell you what we ate, because they only serve what they can find fresh... so what i ate on this day might be completely different from what you have weeks later.

but we both chose to do the $150 omakase, and were stuffed.... if i were super super hungry after 18 holes of golf, and i had won the round so my challengers would have to pay for my dinner, im sure i could demolish the $200 omakase easy!

***

LIKES:  Everything we had was super fresh, super tasty, and overall affordable for what it is... the chefs work their knife magic, and they're super friendly.

DISLIKES:  It's cold in SF.... 

VERDICT:  $200 is a lot to ask for a meal.... $150 is too... hell.... even $100 per head... but with this level of quality, and comparing it to any other omakase place, its a good value.  Obviously you're not going to come here on a whim unless your company just IPOed and you got some equity to burn.... but definitely a place worth trying if you want to spoil yourself on some raw fish
author: Dennis C.

description: I've been to a lot of sushi places-- Omakase hands down the best in The City.  Chef Jackson is attentive and most importantly for a omakase sushi chef, VERY creative!
author: Vincent Kenman Y.

description: This sushi place is the best. The ambience is breathtaking and fancy. The sashimi is super fresh. Servers are friendly and tentative to your needs. If you want high quality Japanese cuisine try out Omakase . Also , hell of romantic place to talk or spend time with your lover, bussiness, or family.
author: Angel Sela K.

description: Everything was absolutely delicious and so fresh. The whole dining experience was really fun, staff was very sweet, including our chef. Very fun to watch him work, even more fun to eat the fruits of his labor. Sake was great too, and they have an adorable selection of sake sets.
author: Madeline W.

description: Amazing experience! Came here for vday and got free rose and champagne. Lovely decor. The sushi was incredible - every bite took my breath away. It was fun watching our chef prepare the food with a super serious face. The service was on point as well. My gf and I really enjoyed our experience.
author: Rocky Y.

description: Amazing omakase experience at this hidden gem. Sit at the bar and converse with the chef - that's the only way to do this. We didn't do the sake pairing - just ordered our own carafes to try. Pricey but for a special occasion, worth the experience.
author: Linda K.

description:
The real deal.
Pros-
