-Wasabe is grated fresh from root imported from japan. Not the horseradish concoction found in most japanese restaurants in the US
-strong wine list, small but well defined
-quality of the fish has already been stated. shipments tues, fri, sat. from japan
-hokaido uni paired with fresh mendocino uni. would have been nice to have SB uni as well.
-genuine value and excellent service
-customized size of rice is a bit overboard

Cons- saba was a little off. the freshest saba has surprisingly no fishy taste
- too many torched pieces. usually to hide lack of freshness in some pieces but here just masked the inherent quality of fish
author: joe b.

description: This was far and above what I expected.  It is very intimate and distinctive in presentation.  The food was perfectly presented with a brief explanation of each new treat headed directly to your mouth.  Pure excitement and such attention to detail.  Ask about the plates from which you will indulge your palate.
author: Jonathan D.

description: This restaurant has taken me out of lurking status and has made me write my first review. It was fantastic from start to finish. I thought that I would be walking out still hungry but I was so full by mid meal and walked out stuffed. By far my best dining experience ever. My husband and I both got the $200 meal and we weren't disappointed. Highlights of the meal included the complimentary krug, foie gras, wagu, uni from Mendicino and Japan, 12 pieces of melt in your mouth nigiri sushi and a fantastic soup. Take your loved one here for a most memorable dining experience!
author: Mai P.

description: Is it even worth telling you why this place is so amazing? Champagne at the seating, epic closeness - AMAZING - high quality, super-filling, genuine Japanese Sushi experience... Sake menu that rocks and some items - like Conch - that are rarely experienced with Stateside sushi. Every bite was better than the last. Not to mention the wonderful conversation and intimate setting. Highly recommend going here for not just a Sushi dinner - but an international sushi experience that echo's "I dream of Sushi" and the famous master sushi chef - Hiro.
author: Pierre C.

description: Excellent!  Super fresh fish, great service and great food.  They were super accommodating to my pregnancy "diet" and it turned out to be very beneficial as I had uni 3 different times throughout our dinner.  I had the $150 menu and hubs had $200.  It's pricey but worth it for a special occasion.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Beautiful calm space with 14 seats serving an endless array of pretty world-class fish. The three of us didn't have too much trouble getting a reservation a week out, and we all went for the 200$ Omakase menu.
The quantity of food was perfect, we left feeling stuffed but not uncomfortably so, the pacing certainly helped.There are three chefs behind the counter, and they seem to serve only the handful in front of them. Our chef (we didn't get his name) was very friendly and chatted freely, part of what I love about omakase style.

High Points:
- Raw lobster and roe were revelatory
-I have never seen blue-fin tuna so darkly colored, outrageous taste
-I have never seen Japanese beef (or any beef) with that level of marbling, nearly all fat
-Uni was the softest and sweetest I ever had

-Sake tasting, I know nothing about sake except I know I've had the sweeter nigori before. These were mostly dry, in a range of temperatures and flavor and aroma, very distinctive and ridiculously well paired.

The only cons I would list but not dock a star:
-Music was soft but occasionally way too clubby, unzt unzt unzt music that was way out of place, are they trying to be a trendy night life spot?.
-The price was definitely high, a result of SF being where it is today. But I didn't feel cheated.
-One of my dining companions mentioned that the 12pieces of sushi in the middle definitely ran together. I remember thinking nearly everything was outstanding (except the conch) but I can barely remember them individually, there were just a couple too many soft sweet sushi preparations that muddled the progression.

And the big question, I wondered if the chefs were preparing different dishes, We got the 200$ menu, and down the counter we saw folks getting served monkfish liver, which our chef never served. So either the 150$ menu gets some items we didn't, or the chefs vary what they prepare. Not really a complaint, just a question.
author: Rory K.

description:
Had my $150 tasting menu there in mid-September. The dishes were outstanding. I like the complimentary champagne at the beginning, but the chilled tin glasses to keep the Sapporo cold were even better.

As good as the food was, I can't justify spending that much money only to leave and immediately want to hit 25 Lusk down the street for food that is actually filling. Now, the rice is so damn good its-self that I could have a bowl (or two) of it on it's own and walked away satisfied. 

The chef during our meal was great and walked us through the courses and answered any question we had. 

All-in-all, a place to try with very interesting dishes. Just be a light eater or be prepared to spend more money for food later.
author: Amit P.

description: Delicious! The food is amazing. Freshest possible fish. Gorgeous presentation. Impeccable service.
author: K B.

description: Quite a commercial spot and overpriced omakase- expect $400 for two people with tips and taxes for their basic version. Good sushi and decent service but not enough to get you filled up if you are getting the $150pp. Also, what surprises me is that they charge $8 for house green tea and try and sell a la carte fish after the omakase round.
author: Pooja S.

description:
Amazing.  The sushi was very traditional.  Obviously very good products but the execution of each dish seemed elegant - as opposed to other sushi experiences that might have great product and is still confident in its simple presentation - there was more polish.  Flavors were subtle and complex.  Very enjoyable experience.

Chose the high set because it was my birthday, my wife chose the middle set; notable extras were the appetizer's chilled chawanmushi, uni don, steak (and not grilled cod) , and most of the standards (bluefin, mackerel, red snapper, amberjack, butter fish) were outstanding.  The prawn sashimi was delicious but not being a fan of conch or clam, it was nice to see it done so well.

The broth of the prawn was a surprising finish - savory, slightly bitter, it whetted my appetite for more - but then strangely nothing else came.  Sad.  Since these dudes were serving very traditional sushi, I didn't get fried shrimp head at the end.  Also sad.  Because sometimes you just want a fried shrimp head.

Another highlight; got to talk knives with the chef at the far end of the bar.  He had custom nenohi  high-carbon stain-resistant steel (similar to Inox) for both his yanagi and what looked like a sakimaru takobiki.  My eyes are averted - I cannot even perceive on this level.  The other chef said the knives were a bonus gift after 20 visits.

19 more...
author: Jonch U.

description: The food was great. The chefs were pleasant. The service staff were spot on. But at $280 a person, I think it's overpriced by $80-100.
author: John S.

description: Yes, this did hit the spot for delicious sushi.  We had a small group of seasoned  sushi goers and they all thought is deserved four stars. The service was spot on. The taste and the offering's were also spot on. The price was disappointing. I'm sorry but it is overpriced. Needs to be scaled down about 20 to 25% for what you get. Or add more courses. Most diners there that night commented consistently about the cost for what you get. Don't be fooled - it's over priced!!!!
author: JA M.

description: Basically, We paid $600 for a $150 meal. The best thing about the night was the sake pairing, quite enjoyable variation of sakes in a wonderful variety of flasks and cups. The sushi and sashimi, however, were boring, and the presentation was sloppy. The first dish they brought out was a piece of hamachi covered in some sweet syrup that completely masked the taste of the fish. Then they brought out some veggies in a cream sauce that was just blah, if not a bit off. The sushi and sashimi were not horrible but were served with no care in regards to presentation. The one wagyu beef dish they served was not well marbled, even having a solid chunk of fat right in the middle. It would have never been served in any decent restaurant. The seared barracuda even had a burnt taste to it. I can't stress enough how disappointing this night was. At the end, we asked for a list of what was served and was told they do not have a list, but then they asked us if we failed to get any of the dishes. Of course, we didn't know, because we were unsure what was supposed to be served. I could go on, but I don't want to waste any more time on this experience. AVOID this place. There are better places in San Francisco for less than half the costs.
author: Jason D.

description: They are quite attentive so no complaints about the service. The food is good but to be honest, I feel that's it's not much better or more unique than what you could get at many Bay Area Japanese restaurants for about 20% of the price.
author: Scott W.

description: Sashimi lovers must give this a try. Each course is freshly made and perfectly timed. Try their sake pairings with your meal. Perfect for a leisurely meal. Reservations are highly recommended.
author: Elaine Y.

description: This is one of the most amazing sushi experienced I've had! The selection of each fish and seafood item is flown in directly from Tsukiji market in Tokyo three times a week, so the quality is unparalleled. You can also choose the sake pairing with it for extra, but we enjoyed ordering sake carafes from the menu the waitress suggested. Have to say  each bite was mind blowing and thoroughly enjoyed the progression, i.e.) appetizers, sashimi, and the best, most fluffiest tamago I've ever had! Break the bank for the higher tasting option, to me it's the perfect amount of food and allows for the complete Omakase experience, Very traditional Edo style sushi at its best!
author: Su C.

description: They definitely deserve their Michelin star.  The service and cuisine were impeccable.  We went during a weeknight for dinner and everything was fresh, immaculately prepared, and delicious!  We will be coming back for sure!
author: Tanya H.

description: I was very excited about trying this new addition to SF's sushi scene, and while it was good, I don't think it was outstanding.  I'm probably thinking this is more of a 3.5 star review, but am rounding up.  I just wasn't as wowed as other spots, especially for the price.  I think Kusakabe is a better bet for a tasting menu experience.  For just sushi/sashimi, I have had better at Pabu.  It was definitely great sushi and the quality of the fish was excellent.  They had specialty items like Hokkaido uni and bluefin tuna, which should be expected at that price point.  I thought the three starters were fine, but nothing was really exceptional.  Contrast to meals I had in Tokyo or other cities where I can still remember specific courses even years later, I can barely remember what we had just a few days ago.  Service was attentive and the meal was paced well.  I left thinking it was good, but not amazing.
author: Michelle C.

description: By far the best sushi and dining experience in the city.  The Hokkaido uni was the stand out for me. The service made me feel like royalty. This is an experience worth every penny.
author: Lewis H.

description: The food is always fresh and quality is the best!  Have eaten at all the sushi restaurants in town and this one is hands down the best!  I always go for the fresh seafood and this place delivers!  The staff is always friendly! The garlic edamame are killer!
author: Chris L.

description: Boyfriend took me here on my birthday.  Best sushi experience I had in San Francisco!  We opted for the $200 option and had Chef Masa as our chef.  Chef Masa explained where the fish was coming from, why he chose specific fish due to season and locality.  Not only we had awesome food and experience, we also gained knowledge of sushi.  Will definitely come back but will opt for $150 option instead because we didn't see much difference between $150 and $200 options.
author: Avril C.

description: My wife and I had a reservation tonight for her birthday dinner.  Traffic in San Francisco was crazy - it took us 45 minutes to get from our place on Nob Hill to City Hall.  There was nothing we could do.  We called twice from the car letting them know of our difficulties and their response was you have 15 extra minutes to keep your reservation.  That was not enough time - we needed at least another 30 minutes,  We were never told that there was such restriction on the arrival time.  I was charged $200 for missing a reservation that was not our fault.  There was no valet parking, so if you're late don't bother, it's very unforgiving.  For a place that charges such high prices to begin you would expect better service for sure.  With all the options in San Francisco pick another restaurant.  I don't care about their reviews; what I care about is that I didn't get to take my wife to dinner on her birthday.
author: James A.
